Despite this, both companies have kept their 2022 budgets within previously guided ranges, citing strong demand for their products and improved efficiency. The decision is expected to boost shares, but may raise concerns about inflation and supply shortages.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust posts 24.8% drop in H2 DPS; to divest Sydney asset for A$315m
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) posted a 24.8% drop in half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.010695 due to lower retained distributable income of S$4.3m in H1 FY2021. The decline was attributed to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the tourism industry. Despite this, FHT's net property income more than doubled to S$30.9m, driven by higher gross revenue and lower operating costs. The trust will divest its Sydney asset, Sofitel Sydney Wentworth, for A$315m, resulting in a net gain of about A$24.1 million.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies will be as useless in the metaverse as they are now
summary: Cryptocurrency proponents envision the metaverse as a decentralized paradise, but critics argue it's a marketing ploy to make a select few rich. The metaverse, a virtual world with infinite possibilities, is expected to be built on cryptocurrencies and NFTs, but experts say this concept is built on a "hypocritical fantasy" and is actually a way to exploit people's lack of understanding of cryptocurrency. The use of cryptocurrency in the metaverse is seen as unnecessary, as most transactions already exist digitally, and its volatility and exchange fees make it impractical for everyday use.

site_title: Chevron posts highest profit in 8 years on surging oil, gas prices
summary: Chevron Corp posted its highest quarterly profit in eight years, with net income of $6.11 billion, driven by surging oil and gas prices, higher demand, and refining margins. The company's strong results reflect gains from production cuts last year and increased production from Opec partners, despite maintenance shut-ins. Chevron plans to increase oil and gas output by up to 3% annually through 2025, citing "boding well" for higher shareholder returns.

site_title: US: Apple, Amazon knock S&P 500, Nasdaq off record peak at open
summary: The US stock markets, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, dropped from record highs at the open on Friday, October 29, 2021, due to concerns about labor and supply shortages from major companies like Apple and Amazon. The Dow Jones fell 0.05% and the S&P 500 dropped 0.51%, while the Nasdaq fell 0.81%. This move came despite both indexes reaching new highs earlier in the week.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts 20.3% rise in Q3 DPU to 1.48 pence
summary: Elite Commercial Reit reported a 20.3% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.48 pence, surpassing its initial public offering forecast. Revenue rose 61.7% to £9.4 million, driven by its UK acquisition of 58 properties for £212.5 million. The Reit's net asset value improved to £0.63 as of September 30, and its portfolio remains 100% occupied. The company is focusing on growth opportunities through acquisition and re-marketing of its properties, with a target market capitalization of S$1 billion.

site_title: Chinese carmaker BYD seeks up to US$1.8b in share placement
summary: Chinese carmaker BYD is seeking up to $1.8 billion in a share placement to supplement working capital, repay debt, and invest in research and development. The company, which reported a 28% drop in net income for the September quarter, is looking to sell 50 million H-shares at a discounted price of HK$273.5 to HK$279.5 each. BYD's rapid expansion plans aim to boost its annual battery output to 155 gigawatt-hours by 2023, ahead of domestic rivals.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust declares S$0.00545 DPS for advanced distribution, Q3 RevPAU up 49%
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has announced a S$0.00545 per stapled security distribution, marking its advanced distribution following a S$150 million private placement. The distribution will be paid on Nov 9. ART's third-quarter portfolio revenue per available unit (RevPAU) rose 49% to S$70, driven by higher average daily rates and bookings during the Olympic Games period in Tokyo, Japan. The trust will continue to focus on increasing its asset allocation in longer-stay accommodation to 15-20% for income stability.

site_title: Chinese developer Oceanwide's San Francisco project seized
summary: Chinese developer Oceanwide's US project, Oceanwide Center in San Francisco, has been seized by overseas credit holders. The two offshore units' $334 million notes have matured, giving credit holders control of the stalled skyscraper development. Oceanwide has spent $3.5 billion on idle or unfinished US projects, and the company is assessing the impact of the takeover on its operations and finances. This move follows similar troubles with real estate projects in New York, Los Angeles, and Hawaii, as Oceanwide's cash-strapped parent, China Evergrande Group, faces a global crisis.

site_title: ExxonMobil Q3 profits rebound to US$6.8b on higher oil prices
summary: ExxonMobil's Q3 profits rebounded to $6.8 billion due to higher oil and natural gas prices, as well as improving refining margins and supply shortages. The company reported a significant increase in free cash flow, allowing it to reduce debt and cover dividends. Exxon plans to resume share buybacks under a $10 billion plan through 2023, driven by its strong cash flow outlook. This rebound in profits comes after a loss of $680 million in the same period last year amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US consumer spending rises solidly in September; inflation stays hot
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.6% in September, outpacing economists' forecasts, but was partly inflated by higher prices. Inflation remained hot, with the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index rising 0.2% and the core PCE price index increasing 3.6% over the past 12 months. Supply chain constraints and a global semiconductor shortage led to a slowdown in motor vehicle production, curbing spending and boosting prices. The data suggests the Federal Reserve may start reducing its bond purchases next week, aiming to bring inflation back to its 2% target.

site_title: BT Explains: Why is Ong Beng Seng interested in SPH?
summary: A consortium led by Ong Beng Seng, managing director of Hotel Properties Ltd, has launched a surprise rival offer for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), a 65.4% stakeholder in SPH Reit. The consortium, which also includes 2 Temasek-linked entities, aims to acquire SPH and potentially SPH Reit if the offer is successful. Ong Beng Seng, a billionaire businessman, has previously made a bid for steelmaker NatSteel in partnership with Temasek-linked entities. The offer comes after SPH received a privatisation offer from Keppel Corporation earlier this month.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat, but add nearly 5% in October on strong earnings
summary: European stocks ended flat on Friday but gained 4.6% in October, their best month in 7, driven by strong earnings reports and rising bond yields. Insurance stocks and financial institutions were boosted by surging yields, while utilities and real estate sectors declined due to rising yields making their future earnings less attractive. Investors expect the European Central Bank to tighten policy by mid-2022, driving a two-way price action in the markets.

images.alt_text: European equities ended flat on Friday (Oct 29) as a jump in major financial stocks driven by surging bond yields offset weakness in high dividend-yielding sectors and commodity companies reeling from a slide in oil and metal prices.

site_title: G-20 set to commit to cutting period to develop vaccines in pandemic
summary: G-20 leaders are set to commit to shortening the period for developing vaccines, drugs, and tests during a pandemic from 300 days to 100 days, a move aimed at speeding up the development of safe and effective treatments in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. The decision is part of a draft joint document, which also includes a goal to vaccinate 70% of the eligible population globally by mid-2022. The move is seen as crucial in addressing the huge disparity in vaccine rollouts between wealthier and poorer nations.

site_title: Singapore on track for 2022 recovery despite lower factory optimism: Watchers
summary: Singapore's economy is on track for a 2022 recovery despite lower factory optimism, according to business sentiment surveys. The country's manufacturing sector, led by the electronics industry, expects conditions to improve in the next half-year, with a net weighted balance of 16% of manufacturers anticipating better business conditions. The services sector, particularly retail and accommodation industries, also shows optimism, with a net weighted balance of 25% of firms holding a positive view of the next six months. Economists expect Singapore's growth to normalize by 2022, driven by domestically-oriented sectors and robust global demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish week on negative note
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week on a negative note, falling 0.70% to 25,377.24. Concerns about inflation and a surge in COVID-19 cases in mainland China, along with supply chain issues from Apple and Amazon, weighed on markets. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.82% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 1.60%.

site_title: Singapore shares end the week weaker; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Friday, closing at 3,198.17, as investor sentiment remained muted following US tech earnings. Sembcorp Industries was the top decliner, while Jardine Matheson led the gainers with a 1.7% climb. The broader market saw 243 losers and 228 gainers, with 2.9 billion securities changing hands. The decline follows weaker regional markets, with most indices falling between 0.3 and 1.4% on Friday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore manufacturing confidence eased in Q4 2021, despite a positive outlook from the services sector for the next 6 months. Business optimism remained positive, but manufacturers' confidence declined quarter on quarter. The services sector, however, expressed a rosier outlook for the coming months, indicating a potential rebound.

site_title: US labour costs power ahead in third quarter as wage surge
summary: US labour costs surged 1.3% in the third quarter, the largest gain since 2001, as companies boosted wages and benefits amid a severe worker shortage. This increase in labour costs, combined with a 4.5% rise in the personal consumption expenditures price index, suggests inflation could remain high for some time. The surge in wages and benefits, particularly in higher wage industries, is seen as a sign that rising labor costs will be passed on to consumers through higher prices.

site_title: Wilmar's Q3 earnings up 6% to US$568.7m
summary: Wilmar International's Q3 net profit rose 6% to US$568.7 million, driven by improved performance in Feed and Industrial Products and Plantation and Sugar Milling segments. Core net profit reached a record high of US$576.4 million. Despite investment securities losses, the company expects satisfactory performance for the rest of the year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: European stock markets dropped at the open on Friday, October 29, 2021, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.7% to 7,197.57 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined, shedding 0.7% and 0.5% respectively. This followed a recent rally, as traders closed out profits ahead of the weekend.

site_title: Nordic airline Wideroe launches unit for emissions-free flying
summary: Wideroe, the Nordic region's largest regional airline, is launching Wideroe Zero, a subsidiary focused on developing an emissions-free airline business. The company aims to replace its aging fleet with zero-emissions planes, either electric or hydrogen-powered, by 2030-2035. Wideroe plans to have its first zero-emissions plane flying in 2026. The move follows industry disruption and pressure to become more sustainable, with the airline industry accounting for 2.5% of global CO2 emissions in 2018.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie to buy German gas pipeline firm Thyssengas
summary: Australia's Macquarie Asset Management has agreed to buy German gas pipeline firm Thyssengas from DIF and EDF Invest for a potential US$1.17-US$1.40 billion. The sale aims to utilize Thyssengas' grid network to transport climate-friendly gases, such as low-carbon hydrogen. The move follows Germany's phase-out of fossil fuels under tougher climate legislation, and Macquarie Managing Director Hilko Schomerus stated that this is an opportunity to make Thyssengas' grid fit for the future.

site_title: Malaysia mandates companies to have at least one woman director
summary: Malaysia mandates publicly traded firms to have at least one woman director on their boards starting September 1, 2022, for large capital companies and June 1, 2023, for other listed companies. The move aims to increase female oversight and recognize the role of women in decision-making. Currently, about 25% of board compositions for major public companies in Malaysia are female, while 27% of listed companies on the Bursa exchange lack female board membership. The proposal is part of efforts globally to increase female representation on boards, citing benefits such as better decision-making and more effective leadership.

site_title: Seoul: S Korean stocks post sharpest weekly decline in 3 weeks on supply disruptions
summary: South Korean stocks posted their sharpest weekly decline in 3 weeks, falling 1.18% on Friday, as weak economic data and supply chain woes continued to weigh on the market. The Kospi ended down 38.87 points, or 1.29%, at 2,970.68. Factory output snapped 10 straight months of year-on-year growth in September due to global chip shortages, with major corporate earnings highlighting the impact. The won edged up, while the 10-year treasury bond yield surged to its highest in over 3 years.

site_title: Singapore's labour market on the upswing as it gradually reopens borders: economists
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to experience an upswing in the final quarter of 2021, driven by the country's gradual reopening of borders. Employment indicators show an improvement across the board, with resident employment growing more quickly than non-resident workers. Unemployment rates eased for the second straight month, reaching 2.6%, with sectors like information and communications, financial, and professional services benefiting from global economic and demand recovery. However, economists note that the labour force is shrinking, and the impact of reopening borders and new vaccinated travel lanes (VTLs) may be gradual and limited.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index ended higher, adding 0.25% or 72.60 points to 28,892.69, as investors awaited corporate earnings reports. The broader Topix index edged up 0.08% or 1.52 points to 2,001.18. The gains came despite global market uncertainty, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records.

site_title: Roll back crisis-prompted wage policies if business has recovered: NWC
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore recommends that employers roll back wage cuts and cost-saving measures if their businesses have recovered or are recovering. Employers should restore earlier wage cuts, implement a flexible wage system, and consider granting build-in wage increases. The guidelines, which apply from Dec 1, 2021 to Nov 30, 2022, aim to support employers and workers as the economy and labor market recover from the pandemic crisis.

site_title: Thousands mourn south Indian film star Puneeth Rajkumar
summary: Thousands of fans mourned the death of Indian film star Puneeth Rajkumar, who died from a heart attack at 46. The "Powerstar" was known for his action roles in the Kannada-language film industry. Tributes poured in from Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Karnataka chief minister Basavaraj Bommai, and fellow actors like Mohanlal and Chiranjeevi. Authorities enhanced security around his house due to fan violence, but fans were also seen crying and hugging. Rajkumar, known for his child acting career and hits like "Appu," was survived by his wife and two children.

site_title: Australia's CBA pleads guilty to consumer credit insurance fraud charges
summary: Australia's Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has pleaded guilty to 30 charges of mis-selling consumer credit insurance to 165 customers between 2011 and 2015. The charges were brought by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) following a Royal Commission inquiry in 2018. CBA has stopped selling the products and compensated the affected customers. This follows similar lawsuits against other major Australian banks, including Westpac, and a wider ASIC review of consumer credit insurance sales by multiple banks between 2018 and 2019.

site_title: National Wages Council recommends built-in pay rise of 4.5 to 7.5% for lower-wage workers
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) recommends a built-in wage increase of 4.5 to 7.5% for lower-wage workers in Singapore, with a minimum increase of S$70 to S$90. This recommendation aims to promote wage catch-up for lower-wage workers and grow their wages faster than median wages. The guidelines apply to workers earning up to S$2,000 per month and encourage employers to consider higher percentage wage increases for lower-wage workers.

site_title: Japan's ANA posts narrower H1 loss, downgrades full-year outlook
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings reported a narrower first-half operating loss of 116 billion yen, down from 280.95 billion yen in the same period last year. The airline downgraded its full-year outlook to a loss, citing a slower-than-expected passenger recovery. ANA cut its earlier guidance for an operating profit of 28 billion yen to a loss of 125 billion yen for the 12 months to March 2022. Analysts had estimated a full-year operating profit of 89.7 billion yen. The airline's results reflect the ongoing impact of the pandemic on the airline industry.

site_title: Tesla charges to top spot in Singapore sedan sales with 312 registered in September
summary: Tesla's Model 3 became Singapore's top-selling sedan in September, with 312 new registrations, a 89% surge from August. This marks the first time a Tesla has taken the top spot in the country. The US company started selling its Model 3 in Singapore in February, and the vehicle's high price, starting at S$113,245, has made it attractive to environmentally-conscious buyers. Singapore aims to reach net zero emissions by 2040 and has implemented incentives to encourage the purchase of electric vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia to buy Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5 to 11
summary: Malaysia plans to purchase the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5 to 11, following a US expert panel's recommendation for authorization. The country aims to ensure schools can reopen safely. About 62% of teenagers aged 12-17 in Malaysia are fully vaccinated, according to government statistics. Other vaccine options, such as Sinovac BioTech, will also be considered. The decision comes as the US FDA's authorization is still pending.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.55 points to 1,562.31. The index saw 3.035 billion lots traded worth RM2.353 billion, with 495 gainers and 485 losers.

site_title: Cryptocurrency ether hits all time high of US$4,400
summary: Ethereum's price reached an all-time high of US$4,400, surpassing its previous record of US$4,380 on May 12. The token has risen over 60% since its late September trough, driven by a recent technical upgrade to the Ethereum network. This rally is part of a broader surge in cryptocurrency markets, with Bitcoin also reaching a record high of US$61,457. Experts attribute the momentum to the upgrade, calling Ethereum a "beast" that appears "bloody strong" and "fuels the beast."

site_title: SMEs need up to US$50t to meet net-zero transition goals: study
summary: A new study from HSBC and Boston Consulting Group (BCG) finds that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) would need between US$25 trillion and US$50 trillion to decarbonize and deliver net-zero supply chains. The research highlights a 7-step roadmap for transition, emphasizing the need for a "leadership crucible" involving large corporates, governments, and industry bodies to address the sector's complexity. To achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, SMEs require financing, climate technology, and changes in product design and business models, with consumers also playing a crucial role in accepting compromises in price, form, or function.

site_title: Top diplomat says US is committed to helping Taiwan defend itself
summary: US top diplomat Sandra Oudkirk stated that the US is committed to helping Taiwan defend itself, describing US-Taiwan relations as "rock-solid". She emphasized the US's commitment to Taiwan's self-defence, following her first news conference since taking the position in July. This comes amid increasing tensions between the US and China over Taiwan's sovereignty.

site_title: Citi names Singapore-based Victor Alexiev as global head for its internal incubator programme D10X
summary: Citi appoints Victor Alexiev as global head of its internal incubator programme D10X, effective immediately. Alexiev, based in Singapore, will lead a global team to accelerate the development of new solutions for growth and value creation. He has previously led the D10X team in Asia, launching three products with a combined market value of over $500 million. Alexiev will report to the global head of venture innovation for Citi Ventures and will continue to be based in Singapore until next summer.

site_title: Australian regulator provides guidance for crypto-asset products
summary: Australia's Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has introduced guidelines for crypto-asset products, requiring holders of underlying assets to obtain a licence. This move aims to improve transparency and protect investors. The guidelines also provide best practices for monitoring and managing crypto-assets. ASIC Commissioner Cathie Armour emphasized the need to consider crypto-asset risks and existing regulatory obligations. The move follows a senate report calling for new laws to make Australia more competitive in the growing digital asset industry.

site_title: New rules for prime HDB flats should temper speculative demand, price hikes: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Desmond Lee said new rules for prime HDB flats aim to temper speculative demand and dampen price increases. The prime location public housing (PLH) model, announced October 27, aims to keep flats affordable and inclusive. Lee stated that measures will prevent first-time sellers from inflating prices to compensate for HDB clawbacks. The PLH model is expected to help regulate the market and curb price hikes.

site_title: China's Xi to participate in G-20 summit via video link
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will participate in the G-20 summit in Rome on October 30-31 via video link, according to China's foreign ministry. This marks Xi's first appearance at a major international gathering since early 2020. He will deliver a speech at the summit, where leaders from 20 countries will discuss global issues. Xi's participation highlights China's continued global influence despite his limited international travel since the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping will participate in the Group of 20 (G-20) leaders' summit in Rome on Oct 30-31 via video link, according to a notice from China's foreign ministry on Friday.

site_title: Global green bond market set to hit record US$1t by end-2022: research
summary: The global green bond market is expected to reach a record-breaking US$1 trillion by the end of 2022, with US$5 trillion by 2025, according to the Climate Bonds Initiative. The market has seen significant growth, with green bond issuance reaching a half-year record of US$227.8 billion in the first half of 2021. Climate finance is crucial for achieving global warming reduction and mitigating climate change goals set out in the Paris Agreement. The Climate Bonds Initiative's forecast is based on a market survey and its own research, which suggests the green bond market could exceed US$1 trillion by 2023.

site_title: Nomura Q2 net profit plunges on one-off loss for years-old transaction
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, reported a second-quarter net profit of 3.2 billion yen, down from 67.6 billion yen a year earlier, due to a one-off loss from a 2007-2008 transaction. The company booked a 39 billion yen charge related to "legacy transactions in the Americas" and also saw a weaker performance by its global markets trading business. Pretax income for its wholesale business dropped to 25 billion yen from 65.5 billion yen. The results were affected by high market volatility driven by the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020.

site_title: Asia: Markets down as Apple, Amazon results dent optimism
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday as disappointing earnings from tech giants Apple and Amazon dampened investor optimism, despite a record performance on Wall Street. The earnings reports from Apple and Amazon, which cited supply problems, contrasted with positive forecasts-beating profits from other major companies. The US economy expanded at a weaker pace than expected in the third quarter, but a drop in jobless claims and a record high on the Nasdaq helped to temper concerns.

site_title: Australian dollar hits 4-month peak as markets howl for rate hikes
summary: The Australian dollar reached a four-month peak, surpassing US$0.7555, amid expectations of interest rate hikes as early as April. Investors are betting on higher rates, driving bond yields to their highest levels since 2019. The Aussie's gain was 1.0% for the week, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.7183. The strong currency is seen as a positive sign for the economy, but may also increase the cost of imports.

site_title: Big Oil clashes with US Democratic lawmakers over climate 'disinformation'
summary: US oil industry executives faced tough questioning from congressional Democrats over their statements on climate science and green energy efforts. Despite acknowledging climate change and supporting the Paris Agreement, Democrats accused the industry of "greenwashing" due to the gap between public relations and actual actions. The hearing highlighted concerns over climate change amid rising hurricanes and forest fires, with Democrats seeking more transparency and action from the industry.

site_title: South Korea eases curbs in first step towards 'living with Covid-19'
summary: South Korea has eased curbs on restaurants, cafes, and high-risk venues such as gyms and bars, with plans to fully lift restrictions by February. The move comes as the country aims to "live with Covid-19" and follows vaccination milestones, with 72% of the population fully vaccinated and over 79.8% receiving at least one dose. The first phase of the easing will last a month, starting November 1, and will see outdoor sports events allowed to have up to 50% spectators and visits to high-risk venues requiring proof of vaccination or a negative test result.

site_title: Generation gap: Why Japan's youth don't vote
summary: Japan's youth face a significant generation gap in voting, with only 38.2% of 18-24-year-olds casting ballots in the 2021 general election. This is the fifth lowest voter turnout among developed economies, attributed to veteran leaders catering to an aging population, outdated campaign tactics, and inadequate political education. Shoma Motegi, a 19-year-old, is determined to change this trend by participating in the upcoming election and encouraging his peers to do the same.

site_title: Raffles Education breaks down chief executive's remuneration in latest round of RegCo responses
summary: Raffles Education broke down CEO Chew Hua Seng's remuneration, revealing a total of S$2.9 million, including a S$1 million base salary and S$1.8 million in profit sharing. The company had under-provisioned S$90,000 in profit sharing, which was deemed not material. Chew also extended S$3.28 million in cash loans to the company and repaid S$6.3 million. The company has also paid S$60,079 in salary for former non-executive director Liu Ying Chun, who was seconded to a Hong Kong-listed university.

site_title: Evergrande makes overdue interest payment to bond holders: report
summary: Chinese property developer Evergrande has made an overdue interest payment to offshore bond holders, averting a potential default for the second time this month. The payment, made less than two weeks before a grace period expired, has eased investor concerns and helped stabilize the company's finances. Despite this, analysts warn that Evergrande's debt crisis remains unaddressed, with several more dollar bond payments to be made before the end of the year. The company's founder, Xu Jiayin, has been instructed by Chinese authorities to use his personal wealth to alleviate the debt crisis.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.48 points or 0.03% to 1,567.34. The market saw 197.18 million lots traded worth RM72.38 million, with 204 gainers and 114 losers.

site_title: Singapore's labour market improves in Q3, unemployment falls in Sep: MOM
summary: Singapore's labour market showed improvement in Q3, with unemployment rates falling for the second consecutive month in September, reaching 2.6% for residents, 3.5% for residents, and 3.7% for citizens. Total employment, excluding migrant domestic workers, decreased by 3,400, while retrenchments dropped to 2,000, mostly in the services industry. Outward-oriented sectors such as professional services and financial services saw growth in resident employment, but food and beverages services and retail trade trimmed their workforce due to ongoing Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at the opening of trading on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,211.36. Gainers outpaced losers 87 to 27, driven by strong Wall Street performance and a 20.8% year-on-year increase in Keppel Reit's distributable income. The US market also closed higher on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records, while European shares rose 0.2% on robust earnings from food and technology stocks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, Keppel, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Starhill Global Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore-listed companies saw developments that may affect trading on Friday. Hotel Properties (HPL) and its consortium made an offer to acquire Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) for S$2.10 per share. Keppel Corporation reported a 14% rise in 9-month revenue. Frasers Hospitality Trust announced a 24.8% decline in half-year distribution per stapled security. Starhill Global Reit reported a 15.1% jump in Q1 net property income. Meanwhile, Far East Hospitality Trust, CDL Hospitality Trusts, and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust also released business updates. Trading was halted for SPH shares, and shares of Japfa and Sheng Siong fell after reporting lower profits.

site_title: UK cuts last countries from Covid travel 'red list'
summary: The UK government announced it will remove all remaining countries from its travel "red list", allowing foreigners to travel to England without quarantine. The 7 countries (Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Haiti, Panama, Peru, and Venezuela) will be taken off the list on November 1. Britons arriving from these countries will no longer need to spend 11 nights in a quarantine hotel, while nationals of those countries will be allowed to travel to England. The government will also recognize coronavirus vaccines for arrivals from over 30 new countries.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's distributable income rises 12.5% for Q3
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's distributable income rose 12.5% year-over-year to S$13.5 million in Q3 2021, driven by 2.6% increase in net property income. Finance expenses decreased by 18% and Reit manager fees by 0.9% due to lower interest rates and property values. However, the hotel segment's master lease rental remained at the fixed rent level, while the serviced residence segment declined in demand. The trust's portfolio occupancy declined 18.1% to 79.2%, and average daily rate fell 4.3% due to lower government contracts and corporate accommodation needs.

images.alt_text: For the first nine months of 2021, income available for distribution went up by 3 per cent to S$38.8 million. This comes even as net property income weakens by 3.4 per cent for the first nine months, due to lower expenses for the group.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch lower as healthcare boost offsets subdued financials
summary: Australian shares edged 0.1% lower in early trade on Friday, with the ASX 200 index dipping to 7,421.9, despite gains from healthcare-focused stocks like CSL. The country's "Big Four" banks fell between 0.4% and 0.9%, while ResMed's shares jumped 6% after beating earnings estimates. Macquarie's record first-half profit and a2 Milk's 3% gain also contributed to the mixed market. The central bank declined to defend its 2024 bond yield target, setting expectations for a revision at its November meeting.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on October 29, 2021, due to disappointing earnings from tech giants Apple and Amazon, and concerns over the latest Covid outbreak in China. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.35% to 25,466.86, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.91 point to 3,519.33.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses Friday (Oct 29) morning following disappointing earnings from tech titans Apple and Amazon, while traders are also keeping a nervous watch on the latest Covid outbreak in China.

site_title: South Korea's September factory output contracts as auto chip shortage bites
summary: South Korea's factory output contracted 1.8% year-on-year in September, missing forecasts for 1.4% growth, due to global chip shortages. Industrial production fell 0.8% seasonally adjusted, with car production shrinking 9.8% and semiconductor production dropping 1.6%. The country's largest carmaker Hyundai Motor reported lower-than-expected profits, citing the chip crisis. Service sector output expanded 1.3% and retail sales jumped 2.5% despite the decline in manufacturing.

site_title: Gold set for third weekly gain as US bond yields, dollar tumble
summary: Gold prices are poised for a third weekly gain due to a retreat in US bond yields and a weaker US dollar, lifting its safe-haven appeal. Benchmark 10-year US Treasury yields are set for their biggest weekly decline since early September, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde acknowledged higher inflation, but pushed back against interest rate hike expectations. Investors await the US Federal Reserve policy meeting on November 3, as a flat yield curve suggests potential for growth and monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Food tech company Nick's raises US$100m in round co-led by Temasek
summary: Swedish food tech firm Nick's raised US$100 million in a funding round co-led by Temasek, Kinnevik, and Ambrosia Investments. The funding will be used to boost growth in Europe and the US, expand product portfolios, and double its store count in 2022. Nick's has expanded to 6,700 stores in the US and 16 markets globally since its founding four years ago. This brings its total funding to US$160 million, with plans to invest in R&D efforts.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing confidence eases even as services sector plumps for rebound
summary: Singapore's manufacturing confidence has eased to 16% in the final quarter of 2021, down from 20% in the previous poll, despite electronics manufacturers remaining optimistic due to robust demand for semiconductors. In contrast, the services sector has improved, with a 19% net weighted balance of firms expecting a more favorable business outlook. The transport and storage industry has seen the highest optimism, with 35% of firms expecting better conditions. Overall, the economy is expected to see a quarter-on-quarter increase in output in the fourth quarter, driven by petrochemical production resuming after maintenance shutdowns.

images.alt_text: Singapore business optimism remained positive into the final stretch of 2021, although manufacturers' optimism has receded quarter on quarter, even as firms in the services sector took a rosier outlook on the next 6 months.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article provided for a summary.

site_title: Former New York governor Cuomo charged with sex crime
summary: Former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has been charged with a misdemeanor sex crime, forcible touching, for allegedly putting his hand down a woman's blouse and grabbing her breast in December 2020. The charge is the first filed against Cuomo since he resigned in August following allegations of sexual harassment. Cuomo, 63, must appear in court on November 17, 2021, to face the charges. The case comes after a report by state Attorney General Letitia James found Cuomo had sexually harassed 11 women, including former staffers, and Cuomo denies the allegations.

images.alt_text: Former New York governor Andrew Cuomo was on Thursday charged with a misdemeanor sex crime for forcible touching, a court spokesperson said.

site_title: Japan's Sept factory output falls 5.4% m-o-m: govt
summary: Japan's factory output fell 5.4% in September from the previous month, exceeding the market forecast of a 3.2% decline. Despite this, manufacturers expect a 6.4% increase in October and a 5.7% rise in November.

site_title: Macquarie beats expectations with record profit, raising A$1.5b capital
summary: Macquarie Group, Australia's largest investment bank and asset manager, reported a record first half profit of A$2.04 billion, more than double the previous year's, driven by volatile commodity markets. The company raised A$1.5 billion in capital and announced a 50% dividend. Net profit surged 107% year-over-year, with its commodities and global markets unit seeing a 60% rise in profit. CEO Shemara Wikramanayake attributed the growth to capital deployment in opportunities providing superior returns relative to risks, citing a continued favorable outlook.

site_title: CDLHT posts 34.8% rise in Q3 net property income to S$20.5m
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 34.8% increase in Q3 net property income to S$20.5m, driven by strong performance from its New Zealand, UK, Germany, and Italy hotels, as well as Angsana Velavaru in the Maldives. Gross revenue rose 32.8% to S$40m, with Singapore hotels contributing S$33.8m. The improved performance reflects the ongoing recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with leisure demand leading the recovery.

site_title: Oil hits 2-week low on Iran talks resuming, US crude build
summary: Oil prices fell 1% to their lowest in two weeks after Iran said talks on its nuclear program would resume by the end of November, potentially paving the way to lifting sanctions on Iran's oil exports. US crude inventories rose 4.3 million barrels, while petrol stocks fell to their lowest in nearly four years. The market reacted to the news, but analysts expect limited impact due to existing supply levels.

site_title: Temasek-backed Impossible Foods looks to raise US$500m at US$7b valuation: sources
summary: Impossible Foods, backed by Temasek, is in talks to raise US$500 million at a valuation of US$7 billion. The plant-based meat producer is capitalizing on heightened consumer demand, expanding into grocery stores and restaurants. Founded in 2011, Impossible Foods has raised over US$1 billion in funding, including from investors like Bill Gates and Temasek. The latest round would value the company higher than rival Beyond Meat's US$6.2 billion market value. Terms are still being finalized.

site_title: Thailand cuts 2021 GDP outlook after deadly Covid-19 wave
summary: Thailand's Finance Ministry reduced its 2021 GDP forecast to 1% growth, down from 1.3% predicted in July, due to the country's deadliest Covid-19 outbreak. This slower-than-expected growth reflects the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Facebook announces changing parent company name to 'Meta'
summary: Facebook's parent company name is being changed to "Meta" to represent a future beyond its troubled social network, according to a statement by CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The name change does not affect the company's apps and brands, which will remain unchanged. Zuckerberg emphasized that the company has learned from its past struggles and is ready to build the next chapter. The change aims to reflect the company's expanded focus on virtual reality and other emerging technologies.

site_title: Starbucks profits up despite China hit due to Covid-19
summary: Starbucks reported a 31% increase in quarterly revenues to $8.1 billion, driven by higher sales in the US and some overseas markets. However, China sales were impacted by the latest Covid-19 wave, resulting in a hit to the company's operations. Despite this, Starbucks' profits rose to $1.8 billion, up four times from the year-ago level. The company also announced plans to boost wages in the US, with hourly employees expected to average $17 per hour by summer 2022.

site_title: Amazon quarterly profit slips as costs climb
summary: Amazon reported a quarterly profit of $3.2 billion, down from half its net income from the same quarter last year, due to increased costs from the pandemic, hiring, and product shortages. Sales reached $110.8 billion, a significant increase, but the company's profit was impacted by higher costs. This marks a decline in Amazon's profit compared to the same period in the previous year.

site_title: Japan ruling party on defensive to maintain sole lower house majority: polls
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) faces a tough fight to maintain its sole majority in the lower house election, with polls showing it may struggle to hold 233 seats. Despite this, the coalition government is likely to remain safe due to support from junior partner Komeito. The election comes after Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's administration has been criticized for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Kishida's approval ratings have dipped slightly, but he still maintains 47% support among respondents.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records as Wall Street rallies
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Thursday, with the Nasdaq finishing at an all-time high of 15,448.12 and the S&P 500 jumping one percent to 4,596.42. Strong earnings from companies like Ford and Caterpillar, as well as optimism over infrastructure and social spending legislation, drove the rally. Despite disappointing economic growth figures, the market appeared to have "looked through" supply chain challenges, according to Art Hogan, chief strategist at National Securities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also advanced 0.7 percent.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens up with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street as investors awaited corporate earnings reports. The benchmark index rose 0.13% or 38.09 points to 28,858.18. This followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, while Asia markets were influenced by US-EU trade talks and US stock indices reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sheng Siong's net profit rose 8.3% year-on-year to S$34.4 million for the third quarter to September, driven by higher revenue and improved sales mix. Revenue increased 6.4% to S$348.1 million. Micro-Mechanics reported a 6.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$5 million, driven by record quarterly revenue of S$20.5 million. The companies expect demand to taper off as Covid-19 restrictions are relaxed, but remain optimistic about their core competencies and ability to improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust posts 24.8% lower H2 DPS; to divest Sydney asset for A$315m
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 24.8% decline in half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.010695, due to lower retained distributable income. The company's net property income more than doubled to S$30.9 million, driven by higher gross revenue and lower operating costs. Frasers Hospitality Trust announced plans to divest its Sydney asset, Sofitel Sydney Wentworth, for A$315 million, resulting in a 4.1% and 3.3% NPI yield for FY2019 and FY2021, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch higher on strong earnings, ECB maintains status quo
summary: European stocks closed 0.2% higher on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from food and technology sectors. The European Central Bank maintained its stimulus taps open and kept interest rates unchanged, despite concerns over inflation. Key gainers included Anheuser-Busch InBev and Capgemini, while Royal Dutch Shell fell 3.0% after reporting lower-than-expected quarterly profit. Investors questioned the ECB's stance on transitory inflation, which rose more than expected in Germany's largest economy.

images.alt_text: European stocks closed slightly higher on Thursday, buoyed by robust earnings from food and technology stocks, as the European Central Bank kept its massive stimulus taps open and maintained its view that a recent spike in inflation would be temporary.

site_title: HPL, Ong Beng Seng, Temasek units CLA and Mapletree in rival offer for SPH
summary: A consortium led by Hotel Properties (HPL) and including Ong Beng Seng, CLA, and Mapletree has made a S$2.10-per-share full cash offer for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), surpassing Keppel's S$2.099 bid in cash and Reit units. The offer is subject to a scheme of arrangement and has not been finalized, with SPH considering the proposal to maximize shareholder value. The consortium's vehicle, Cuscaden Peak, holds 40% of its shares, while Keppel's offer includes a break fee of S$34 million and a potential conditional cash offer.

site_title: Tissot PRX goes back to the future
summary: A Tissot PRX 20 405 sports watch from the 1970s has gained popularity on social media, particularly among watch enthusiasts, due to its retro design. The watch, which is not a mechanical model, has been featured in a local Facebook group, sparking interest among watch enthusiasts. The article does not provide further details on its impact or sales.

site_title: Australian billionaire Packer admits to 'many oversights' at Crown's governance
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer admitted to "many oversights" in Crown Resorts' corporate governance during a Royal Commission inquiry into handling of money-laundering risks at the Perth casino. Packer, who owns 37% of the A$7 billion company, stepped down from corporate roles in 2018 but remains a major shareholder. The admission comes after damaging inquiries into Crown's other resorts in Sydney and Melbourne.

images.alt_text: Australian casino billionaire James Packer acknowledged "many oversights" in the corporate governance of the company he founded, Crown Resorts, as he fronted a powerful inquiry on Monday into its second-largest resort.

site_title: ECB keeps stimulus on track as inflation surge unsettles markets
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its pledge to conduct emergency bond-buying at a "moderately" slower pace, despite surging inflation prompting interest-rate increase bets. The bank reaffirmed plans to reduce monthly purchases from 75 billion euros, and promised to keep the Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme running until March 2022 or later if needed. This decision aims to stabilize markets and maintain economic growth, as inflation rates reached their highest levels in three decades.

site_title: Advisers to Evergrande, bondholders take step towards debt talks
summary: Advisers to China Evergrande Group and offshore bondholders have signed non-disclosure agreements, taking a step towards debt talks. The ad hoc bondholder group's advisers, including Houlihan Lokey and Moelis & Co, are seeking information on the company's projects, liquidity, and asset valuation. This comes after earlier outreach attempts were rebuffed, and Evergrande scrapped talks to sell a stake in its property-management arm. The move aims to exchange information and address concerns about asset sales during debt discussions.

site_title: Extraordinary times
summary: The Rolex Oyster Perpetual Cosmograph Daytona features a meteorite dial, a rare natural material composed of iron and nickel, extracted from an asteroid or planet millions of years ago. Due to its rarity and difficulty to work with, the watch has a long waitlist. As the world approaches an endemic Covid-19, a sense of normalcy is returning, with border restrictions easing and businesses adapting to the pandemic's impact. Rolex has unveiled new, innovative watch offerings, showcasing their resilience and expertise in the industry.

site_title: Another Chinese developer, Kaisa, is sinking as junk bonds sell off
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese developer, is facing financial difficulties as junk bonds sell off, leading to a record 18% plunge in its Hong Kong shares. Two credit assessors downgraded the company, citing concerns over refinancing dollar debt amid a spike in borrowing costs. Kaisa has a $400 million note due on Dec 7 and $2.8 billion of dollar bonds maturing in 2022, with Moody's and Fitch Ratings cutting its rating to CCC+ from B. At least four Chinese developers have defaulted in October, with China Evergrande Group facing an overdue coupon on Friday.

site_title: Apple profit jumps in quarter but revenue misses mark
summary: Apple reported a record-high revenue of $83.4 billion in its recent quarter, but its net income of $20.5 billion fell short of analyst expectations. The company attributed the revenue increase to new iPhone sales, despite a global electronic chip shortage affecting production. Apple shares slid 3% after the earnings release. The company faces pressure from regulators and developers to loosen its grip on the App Store, and is also struggling with supply chain constraints.

images.alt_text: Apple on Thursday reported that its profit in the recently ended quarter leapt on massive revenue that still fell short of analysts' expectations.

site_title: Euro dips ahead of ECB meet; yen looks past BOJ doves
summary: The euro fell 0.2% to US$1.1586 ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday, as investors await policymakers' views on inflation and interest rate projections. The Australian dollar dipped 0.1% and the yen remained near 4-year lows. The Bank of Japan stuck with its dovish stance, while the Reserve Bank of Australia declined to buy a government bond, fueling speculation about its tightening plans.

site_title: Tightrope election may spell uncertain future for Japan's new PM
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) is at risk of losing its majority in Sunday's general election, potentially turning new leader Fumio Kishida into a short-term prime minister. The LDP, which has ruled Japan for most of the post-war era, will likely stay in power with its junior partner Komeito, but may lose seats in Parliament's lower house. A lacklustre result for Kishida could lead to a push to oust him ahead of next year's upper house vote, potentially triggering policy uncertainty.

site_title: Buzz!
summary: The Les Amis Group has launched two new hawker-style eateries: Cluny Food Court in Botanic Gardens, offering wonton noodles and Texas barbecue, and Socialize Central @Tampines, featuring Smoked Burgers and local beers. Meanwhile, Shangri-la Singapore is offering Middle Eastern cuisine, "Safiya," for takeaway and home delivery, showcasing mezze, kebabs, and other exotic dishes. Both eateries are set to open officially on November 1.

site_title: Fifth Avenue building set to test market for older NYC towers
summary: A 1920s-era office tower on Fifth Avenue, 475 Fifth Avenue, is set to sell for around $300 million, according to CBRE Group broker Darcy Stacom. The 24-storey property, renovated in 2015, is expected to attract investors due to its proximity to Grand Central Terminal. Despite older office buildings struggling to draw tenants, the renovated property's location and recent sales of nearby properties, such as Olympic Tower, suggest growing interest in offices near transit hubs. The sale comes as more companies re-evaluate their office space needs amid the pandemic and hybrid work schedules.

site_title: The hardest gold
summary: A Lange & Sohne's exclusive Honeygold alloy, composed of 75% fine-gold, copper, and zinc, is harder than any gold alloy due to mineral additives and heat treatment. Since its launch 11 years ago, Honeygold has been featured in 12 limited-edition models, including the Zeitwerk Honeygold "Lumen" watch. The alloy was first introduced in 2010 as a tribute to the brand's 165th anniversary. Honeygold models have been released annually, including the 1815 Moon Phase, Richard Lange Tourbillon, and Langematik Perpetual, showcasing the alloy's unique warm glow and durability.

site_title: The Raffles Education-Oei Hong Leong saga
summary: Raffles Education Corporation (REC) is embroiled in a dispute with former substantial shareholder Oei Hong Leong and chairman Chew Hua Seng. The company failed to disclose a writ and statements of claims filed by Affin Bank in Malaysia's High Court in May. As a result, 5 of its directors have been arrested in Singapore since 2020. The investigation has escalated into a full-blown saga, with REC facing scrutiny over its governance and disclosure practices. The incident has raised questions about the company's management and leadership.

site_title: Shedding light on underappreciated artists
summary: A new exhibition space at the National Gallery Singapore, "Dalam South-east Asia," aims to shed light on underappreciated artists from the region. The space showcases the works of late Modern artists You Khin and Chen Cheng Mei, who were technically virtuosic but often neglected in art history. The exhibition features their paintings, notes, and sketches, highlighting their masterful command of color and composition. The space plans to roll out four exhibitions every six months until 2023, aiming to redress the lack of recognition for lesser-known South-east Asian artists.

images.alt_text: Above: You Khin's Untitled (Doha Scene: Pakistani Bakers), 1990. Oil on canvas.
Above: Chen Cheng Mei's Market Scene, Sri Lanka, 1975. Oil on canvas.

site_title: Acceleration to clean energy can fuel Asean's economic growth
summary: Asean countries can fuel economic growth by accelerating the transition to clean energy, addressing energy security challenges, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The region's reliance on fossil fuels and limited energy production capabilities create a pressing need for renewable energy sources. With over 800 clean energy projects in the pipeline, the investment potential is estimated to be over US$316 billion, generating up to 870,000 jobs and reducing emissions by over 229 metric tons of carbon dioxide-equivalent. Governments and the energy sector are under pressure to decarbonize, and the transition to clean energy is seen as a promising solution.

site_title: Art by ex-offenders showcased in exhibition
summary: An exhibition titled Routes features 19 paintings by ex-offenders and their mentors at 10 Square @ Orchard Central from Oct 28 to Nov 2. Organized by Global Cultural Alliance, the artworks showcase the power of art in rehabilitation and hope. The exhibition aims to highlight the transformative process of individuals through the arts, with the goal of promoting health, mental well-being, and social sectors. The artworks are on display and for sale, with proceeds supporting CANVAS, a support group for previously-incarcerated individuals.

site_title: Rolex Explorer scales new heights
summary: The Rolex Explorer, a tool watch designed for mountaineers in the Himalayas, has been reissued with updated features. The new Explorer I features a 36mm case size, similar to the 1953 original, with subtle changes and a two-tone version available. The watch also boasts a lacquered black dial, anti-reflective coating, and improved legibility. The Explorer II, celebrating its 50th anniversary, has retained its distinctive orange second time zone hand and features a new Chromalight display and calibre 3285 movement. Both watches are now available for purchase, with prices starting at S$8,840 for the Explorer I and S$11,740 for the Explorer II.

site_title: Beauty in darkness
summary: The "Lumen" series by Lange offers luminous displays on watches, utilizing a patented semi-transparent sapphire-crystal dial that absorbs visible light and radiates UV light to glow in the dark. This technology requires 90 minutes of direct sunlight or blue-white artificial light to activate. The first "Lumen" watch, Zeitwerk "Luminous," was released in 2010, followed by limited-edition models like the Grand Lange 1 "Lumen" and Datograph Up/Down "Lumen" in 2013, 2016, and 2018, respectively. All "Lumen" timepieces feature luminous displays on visible functions, making them legible in the dark.

site_title: The Serpenti over the decades
summary: Bulgari's iconic Serpenti collection has been a symbol of luxury since the 1940s, with its distinctive snake motif. The brand's popularity soared in the 1960s after Elizabeth Taylor wore the Serpenti bracelet in the movie Cleopatra, making it instantly recognizable worldwide. Over the years, Bulgari produced watches with various designs, including the Tubogas technique, which featured a highly stylized snake motif. The brand's move to produce watches in-house in 1978 marked a significant turning point in its history, and the Serpenti collection remains one of the most identified with the brand, valued at $156.8 million at the time of Elizabeth Taylor's death.

images.alt_text: The Digital Solutions Center in ABB's new Customer Innovation Center, where clients can work with ABB to co-develop solutions for their needs.
bulgari - A Serpenti Bracelet Watch from 1950. Source: Bulgari
The Collaborative Operations Center in ABB's new Customer Innovation Center, showing how ABB's technology can be used to monitor plant operations.
The Serpenti Bracelet Watch was worn by Elizabeth Taylor in 1961. Bulgari produced the first Serpenti watches with the Tubogas (Italian for gas pipe) technique in the late 1940s.
Serpenti Bracelet Watch from 1950.
Serpenti Bracelet Watch from 1948.

site_title: MAS expects slower but 'above-trend' growth in 2022
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects Singapore's economic growth in 2022 to be slower than in 2021 but still above trend, without specifying the exact growth rate. This is in line with private-sector economists' estimates of pre-Covid trend growth ranging between 2 and 4%. The MAS maintained its full-year growth expectation for 2021 at 6 to 7%.

site_title: A homecoming for HSBC Singapore CEO
summary: HSBC Singapore's new CEO, Wong Kee Joo, returns to the city-state after 22 years, bringing a 'glocal' perspective. Wong sees Singapore's strategic importance in the global supply chain, with multinational companies considering moving supply chain parts closer to South-east Asia. HSBC has committed to investing $3.5 billion in the region, focusing on fee-generating businesses. Wong emphasizes the need for a purpose-driven organization, citing his own experience navigating grey areas in international markets. He aims to foster a sense of purpose among staff and encourage younger Singaporeans to explore opportunities abroad.

images.alt_text: HSBC Singapore's CEO Wong Kee Joo is a firm believer in sending younger Singaporeans overseas for exposure.

site_title: NTUC Income ventures into Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia
summary: NTUC Income is launching digital-first micro-insurance Droplet in Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia, its first foray into Southeast Asian markets. Droplet covers commuters against price surges on ride-hailing platforms on rainy days, a product first launched in Singapore in 2018.

site_title: Jazzing up familiar favourites with new dials
summary: Rolex has introduced vibrant new dial designs for its Oyster Perpetual Datejust 36, Cosmograph Daytona, Day-Date 36, and Lady-Datejust watches. The new dials feature unique motifs such as a tropical-forest-inspired palm pattern and a meteorite dial made from siderite, an iron and nickel mineral found in deserts. The watches also include diamond-set models, with the Lady-Datejust featuring 1,089 diamonds. The new designs are available in various colors and materials, including gold, silver, and turquoise, and range in price from S$9,740 to S$47,150.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Lange goes semi-digital in yellow gold
summary: Lange unveils the Zeitwerk, a watch featuring a digital display and a time bridge made of German silver. The time bridge is a nod to the brand's tradition of using this material for movement components. This semi-digital watch is powered mechanically, showcasing precise jumping numerals. The Zeitwerk's distinctive design solidifies its place in Lange's popular lineup, highlighting the brand's commitment to innovative timekeeping and heritage.

site_title: Situation at Westlite Jalan Tukang was unique: Centurion
summary: Centurion Corp, a Singapore-based dormitory operator, responds to claims made in an article suggesting its Sustainability Report does not accurately reflect events. The situation at Westlite Jalan Tukang dormitory was caused by an increase in Covid-positive workers and a delay in sending them to external-care facilities. Centurion worked closely with the Ministry of Manpower and other agencies to address the issue. The company has also improved food quality and provided residents with access to kitchens and a mini mart. Centurion emphasizes its commitment to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) actions and assures stakeholders that its sustainability reports reflect its actions accurately.

site_title: Zenith plays on core strength
summary: Zenith has released new variations of its renowned automatic high-frequency chronographs, building on its 50-year legacy with the Chronomaster Original. The new model features a 38mm steel case, a 5Hz El Primero 3600 movement, and a 1/10th of a second chronograph function, offering improved accuracy and performance. The watch comes in steel and 18K rose gold variations, with the steel version priced at S$12,400 and the rose gold version at S$27,800. A ladies' version, Chronomaster Original (Ladies), is also available, featuring precious stones and a unique design.

site_title: Samsung sees chip crunch persisting after profit tops estimates
summary: Samsung Electronics reported quarterly profit of 12.06 trillion won (S$13.9 billion) despite a chip supply crunch, citing rising prices for its semiconductor business. The South Korean giant expects the chip shortage to persist through next year, impacting industries worldwide. This is due to a global shortage of semiconductors, which are crucial for computers and mobile devices.

site_title: Coming: A bond selloff in Korea and India
summary: Bonds in South Korea and India are vulnerable to a sell-off due to their sensitivity to US inflation break-evens and heavy reliance on energy imports. Rising energy prices in both countries, which are significant importers, contribute to inflation. The two nations' economies are also influenced by rising energy prices, making their bonds more susceptible to a sell-off.

site_title: Bracing for the great ESG talent wars
summary: Singapore's financial sector is facing a significant ESG talent crunch, driven by growing demand for climate-friendly finance and investments. The region lags behind Western peers in addressing sustainability issues, hindering its sustainable finance push. To address this, the sector is exploring solutions, such as upskilling existing staff and attracting new talent. Industry leaders, including BASF and BNP Paribas, are emphasizing the importance of sustainability and ESG expertise in driving business success and social responsibility.

site_title: Eight recommendations
summary: Royston Tan's new film "24" is a 6-year-awaited feature that shifts focus from visuals to sound design, following a dead sound recordist as a spirit who records sounds at 24 places. The film features James Choong in a lead role and incorporates actual sound recordings. Tan's previous films are known for their visuals, but "24" marks a departure. The film's unique approach is Tan's first feature in six years.

site_title: Lloyds Q3 profit surges as UK economy revives
summary: Lloyds Bank reported a 20% increase in net income to £4.1 billion in Q3, driven by improved economic outlook and robust credit performance. The bank's underlying profit before impairment rose 27% from the previous quarter. Lloyds upgraded its full-year guidance, expecting an improved net interest margin and recovering pandemic-related costs. The bank's average interest-earning assets increased, driven by strong mortgage sales and government-backed lending. This marks a trend seen in the UK banking sector, with the bank's Q1 profit almost eight-fold year-on-year.

site_title: ANZ reports big profit jump but says it fell behind in home loans
summary: ANZ Banking Group reported a 65% profit jump to A$6.2 billion in its annual results, but acknowledged falling behind in home loans. Despite a surge in nationwide home prices, its Australian home loan volumes fell 1% to A$278 billion. The bank's CEO, Shayne Elliott, attributed the underperformance to not preparing well for the pandemic-induced boom. ANZ aims to grow its home lending market share and has launched an online banking and lending service, ANZ Plus, to address the issue.

site_title: New York schools ban Squid Game Halloween costumes
summary: The Fayetteville-Manlius school district in New York has banned Squid Game Halloween costumes due to concerns they may glorify violence. The district cited the show's violent themes and games, including marbles and tug of war, as reasons for the ban. Superintendent Craig Tice stated that schools aim to avoid scary or gory costumes that may frighten younger students. The ban applies to 6 schools with children aged 5-10, following similar warnings from schools in England.

site_title: Tudor dresses up the Black Bay collection in new materials
summary: Tudor has introduced three new versions of its Black Bay collection: the Black Bay Fifty-Eight 18K gold, the Black Bay Fifty-Eight 925 silver, and the Black Bay Fifty-Eight Bronze. The watches feature a 39mm case size, matte satin finish, and open caseback showcasing the COSC-certified manufacture calibre MT5400. Prices range from S$5,960 for the silver version to S$6,510 for the ceramic model. Each watch comes with two straps, including a green Jacquard fabric strap and a brown alligator strap.

site_title: Embracing an unloved grape
summary: Scott Kirkpatrick and his wife Allison Watkins, co-founders of Mountain Tides, have dedicated themselves to producing high-quality petite sirah wines that are energetic, fresh, and light, challenging the traditional perception of the grape as a powerful and tannic variety. Since 2016, they have explored the grape's potential in California, making 8-10 different cuvées this year, including single vineyard expressions, blends, and a carbonic fermented petite sirah. Their approach aims to showcase the grape's versatility and nuance, offering a new style of petite sirah that can be enjoyed with food and paired with energy and joy.

site_title: Consumer demand for gold in Singapore fell in Q3: WGC
summary: Consumer demand for gold in Singapore fell 23% year-on-year in Q3 to 2 tonnes, driven by a 14% decline in gold jewellery purchases. The World Gold Council attributes this decline to intermittent lockdowns and the perception of gold as a "discretionary spend". However, central bank purchases have doubled to 393 tonnes and jewellery demand is expected to recover as vaccination rates increase and lockdowns ease. Global jewellery demand surged by 50% in the first 3 quarters of 2021, reaching 1,750 tonnes, but still below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: The best of the rest
summary: TAG Heuer has reimagined its iconic Carrera watch collection, introducing four new models with a focus on legibility. The collection, which debuted over 60 years ago, now features 13 pieces, including the Day Date 41mm, Twin-Time 41mm, Date 39mm, and Date 29mm. The new models retain the motor racing heritage and sportiness of the original collection while emphasizing readability. This revival marks a significant update to the classic Carrera design, ensuring its continued relevance in the watch industry.

site_title: San Francisco's empty offices delaying apartment-rent recovery
summary: San Francisco's apartment market remains stagnant, with only Equity Residential reporting no full recovery to pre-pandemic rents. The halting return of employees to offices is limiting demand, hindering rent increases. Chief Operating Officer Michael Manelis stated that the return of employees to offices is still weighing down apartment demand, affecting how much Equity Residential can raise rents. This delay is attributed to the ongoing office space vacancy in the city.

site_title: Strong V-shaped recovery for travel in 2022: AirAsia executive
summary: AirAsia's CEO, Amanda Woo, expects a V-shaped recovery in the travel industry over the next 12 months as countries reopen their borders. The airline's Super App now has over 700 airline partners, offering flights to 3,000 destinations worldwide. Woo aims to capture a 30% market share in the region and expand travel options to destinations outside AirAsia's current network. The app also plans to collaborate with Indonesian ride-hailing and logistics companies in 2022.

images.alt_text: The travel industry is expected to experience a V-shaped rebound over the next 12 months as countries gradually reopen their borders, a senior executive at Malaysia's AirAsia Group said on Thursday.

site_title: SGIFF goes back to the cinema
summary: The 32nd Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) returns to physical form with over 110 film titles, all to be shown in cinemas. The festival features pandemic-themed and women-led films, including "Vengeance Is Mine, All Others Pay Cash" and "Rehana Maryam Noor", which are co-productions with Indonesia and Bangladesh. The festival aims to increase female representation in front of and behind the camera, with local female talent making up a significant portion of the lineup. Tickets go on sale on November 8, marking a return to normalcy for the film industry after the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tilda Swinton stars in Apichatpong Weerasethakul's Memoria, one of the over 110 films showing at the Singapore International Film Festival.
The award-winning opening film, Vengeance Is Mine, All Others Pay Cash, is a co-production of Singapore, Indonesia and Germany.
Wes Anderson's acclaimed The French Dispatch makes its South-east Asian debut at the festival.
Scene Unseen is a film by the late Abdul Nizam and his friends about Singapore's underground music scene, featuring bands such as Opposition Party (pictured) and The Oddfellows.

site_title: How FSIs are protecting digital assets in today's digital economy
summary: Digital assets, including cryptocurrencies, non-fungible tokens, and central bank digital currencies, are gaining popularity due to the digital economy boom. However, this increased adoption has also led to heightened levels of volatility, regulatory risks, and an increase in ransomware attacks. Financial Service Institutions (FSIs) need to work together with technology and regulation to protect digital assets from fraudsters. Implementing robust cybersecurity measures, such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, is crucial in detecting and preventing fraudulent activities. FSIs must also adopt a proactive role in protecting digital assets and ensure that regulations are informed by actual use cases and consultations with technology innovators.

site_title: A must for Cartier connoisseurs
summary: Cartier has revived its iconic 1970s Tank Must watch for a new generation, with subtle updates to the original design. The watch features a monochromatic dial, interchangeable bracelet, and three sizes in steel models with automatic or quartz movement. A limited-edition SolarBeat model, powered by light, is also available, along with a sustainable strap made from plant matter and waste from apple production. Prices start at S$3,700 for the Tank Must and S$19,400 for the Tank Louis Cartier.

site_title: New innovative material takes centre stage
summary: IWC highlights 2021 with two new timepieces in sand-coloured ceramic material: a perpetual calendar and a basic time-only model with an anti-magnetic shield. The sand-coloured ceramic material, called Ceratanium, is a breakthrough material that combines the strengths of ceramic and titanium, offering exceptional hardness, lightness, and skin-friendliness. The new watches, part of the TOP GUN collection, are designed to withstand the toughest conditions, with features such as titanium cases, corrosion-resistant materials, and advanced mechanical complications. Prices range from S$22,500 to S$175,000.

site_title: Glow of delight
summary: A Lange & Sohne has unveiled the Zeitwerk Honeygold "Lumen", a limited-edition timepiece featuring a patented semi-transparent coating that glows in the dark. The watch is part of the brand's exclusive Honeygold and "Lumen" collections, with the Zeitwerk being the only model to appear in both. With a 41.9mm wide case, jumping numerals, and a 72-hour power reserve, the Zeitwerk Honeygold "Lumen" is priced at S$175,000 and available exclusively in Lange boutiques.

images.alt_text: lange - Zeitwerk Honeygold _Lumen_ ALS_142_055_B08_Day_Zeitwerk_Honeygold_Lumen_2021_2258380 Source: A. Lange & Söhne
lange - Close-up of Zeitwerk Honeygold _Lumen_ at Night ALS_142_055_B07_Night_Zeitwerk_Honeygold_Lumen_2021_2259059 Source: A. Lange & Söhne
Zeitwerk Honeygold "Lumen" features jumping numerals and is powered by a movement with power reserve of 72 hours, double that of previous Zeitwerk models.
Zeitwerk Honeygold "Lumen" features jumping numerals and is powered by a movement with power reserve of 72 hours, double that of previous Zeitwerk models.

site_title: Airbus clings to jet delivery goal despite supply snags
summary: Airbus maintained its forecast for 600 jet deliveries this year despite supply chain snags, citing a recovery in air travel demand. The company reported a 19% drop in third-quarter operating profit, but lifted full-year profit and cash targets. CEO Guillaume Faury said labour shortages worldwide are impacting all sectors, but Airbus can manage supply chain issues. Airbus shares rose 1% after the announcement, with analysts praising the decision to maintain deliveries, seen as a boost to the industry after years of turmoil.

site_title: The Omega James Bond watch to die for
summary: The Omega Seamaster Diver 300M 007 Edition watch is a real-life replica of the fictional watch worn by James Bond in the movie No Time To Die. The watch features a coiled mechanism that creates an electromagnetic pulse, allowing Bond to short out hard-wired networks. In reality, the Omega Seamaster Diver 300M 007 Edition is a Master Chronometer-certified timepiece, meeting the Swiss industry's highest standard of precision and magnetic-resistance. The watch is available for purchase and pays homage to the fictional watch worn by Bond in the film.

site_title: Time for an upgrade
summary: Omega has released upgraded versions of its iconic Speedmaster Moonwatch, Seamaster 300, and Seamaster Diver 300m Black Black, all Master Chronometer certified for extreme magnetic resistance and precision. The Speedmaster features a classic asymmetrical case and step dial, while the Seamaster 300 has a domed sapphire crystal and vintage Arabic numerals. The Seamaster Diver 300m Black Black boasts a black ceramic case and integrated rubber strap. Prices range from S$8,700 for the Speedmaster to S$12,400 for the Seamaster Diver.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on earnings despite mixed economic data
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday despite mixed economic data, driven by strong earnings from companies like Merck and Caterpillar. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6%. The US economy grew 2% in the third quarter, down from 6.7% in the prior quarter. Investors shrugged off the data, citing "backward-looking" reports and improving jobless claims data. Markets are also monitoring Washington talks on infrastructure and social spending legislation.

site_title: A little something for everyone
summary: Tissot has reissued three iconic watch collections: Seastar 2000, Heritage Memphis Limited Edition, and Tissot T-My Lady. The Seastar 2000 is a contemporary tool watch with anti-magnetic and anti-shock properties, available for $1,480. The Heritage Memphis Limited Edition features bold and colorful designs inspired by 1988's Memphis Group collaboration, priced from $540. The Tissot T-My Lady is a refined and elegant watch for women, priced from $610, with a mechanical self-winding movement and diamond accents.

site_title: Bulgari in the spotlight
summary: Bulgari has launched new watch novelties, including three new Serpenti Seduttori styles, a Bulgari Aluminium GMT, and a limited edition Bvlgari Bvlgari Fragment Fujiwara #2. The Serpenti Seduttori watches feature a drop-shaped case and a flexible, hexagonal-link bracelet, while the Bulgari Aluminium GMT is a two-time zone travel watch with a new function. The Bvlgari Bvlgari Fragment Fujiwara #2 is a limited edition watch combining Bulgari's Bvlgari aesthetic with Hiroshi Fujiwara's "fragment" style. The watches are priced between S$6,760 and S$165,000.

site_title: Higher interest rates, inflation could dent UK government's finances: analysts
summary: UK economists and Conservative politicians express concerns over Finance Minister Rishi Sunak's latest Budget, citing higher interest rates and inflation as potential financial risks. Analysts warn that expanding the state and raising taxes may hinder wealth creation and rely on uncertain outcomes. The UK economy has already shrunk for the second month, adding to the challenges facing the government.

site_title: Nanofilm's Shi Xu named SBA's Businessman of the Year
