summary: Thailand is set to reopen to fully vaccinated visitors on November 1 after 18 months of COVID-19 travel curbs, aiming to revive its tourism sector. The country expects at least a million visitors by March and $30 billion in revenue through 2022. Fully vaccinated visitors from 40 "low-risk" countries, including the US, China, and Europe, will be allowed to enter with a negative COVID test and retesting upon arrival. Authorities hope a phased plan to lift quarantine rules and end a ban on booze in bars and restaurants will lure visitors back.

site_title: IMF sees strong foundations for global recovery, big downside risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has expressed strong foundations for a global economic recovery, but warns of downside risks from new virus variants, inflation, and supply-chain disruptions. The IMF trimmed its 2021 global growth forecast to 5.9% from 6.0%, citing supply chain disruptions and inflation pressures. Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva urged bold action to end the pandemic and create a more sustainable economy.

site_title: Thailand readies for tourism reboot with reopening test-run
summary: Thailand held a dry-run for its quarantine-free reopening to vaccinated travelers, simulating the arrival of a plane full of visitors at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport. The test aims to test electronic screening measures, which will include passengers' QR codes and insurance details. Thailand has targeted 100,000 arrivals this year, down from nearly 40 million in 2019, due to the pandemic. The reopening is expected to bring an increase in flight bookings, with vaccinated visitors from eligible countries able to skip quarantine starting from November 1.

site_title: Prince Charles to deliver opening address at COP26
summary: Prince Charles will deliver the opening address at COP26, a day after Queen Elizabeth II withdrew due to health concerns. The 95-year-old queen had planned to attend but will instead deliver a recorded message. Prince Charles, 72, will welcome world leaders, following in his father's footsteps, and will be joined by his son Prince William and wife Kate, who have also spoken out on environmental issues. COP26 aims to slow rising temperatures and persuade leaders to adopt tougher climate targets.

site_title: Nanofilm's founder Shi Xu takes the long view, after the IPO glow, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Nanofilm, a Singapore-based company, has agreed to acquire the remaining 35% stake in Sydrogen from Temasek for S$15 million. This deal marks a significant milestone for Nanofilm, expanding its ownership in the company. The acquisition is expected to enhance Nanofilm's position in the market and provide access to Sydrogen's technology and expertise. Temasek, a Singaporean state-owned investment firm, has been a key investor in Sydrogen. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to be completed in the coming months. Financial details of the deal have not been disclosed.

site_title: How green is your pantry? Carbon labels can tell you
summary: A project backed by 27 companies, including Nestle and Pepsico, is introducing a color-coded label to grade products' environmental impact from farm to store. The label aims to reduce the 35% of greenhouse gas emissions attributed to the food industry. Animal-based products generate 57% of the industry's emissions, with packaging, processing, and transportation also contributing to carbon emissions. The initiative is part of a larger effort to green up the supply chain, with an estimated cost of $350 billion over the next decade.

site_title: Emerging markets at different points of net-zero journey
summary: Emerging markets are at varying stages of implementing climate change mitigation strategies, with some countries, such as China, aiming to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2060 and others, like India, focusing on reducing emissions intensity by 35% by 2030. Brazil has committed to climate neutrality by 2050, while others have yet to declare significant policies. Companies in emerging markets are decarbonizing through various means, including technology adoption and green business models, and investors are seeking opportunities in sectors such as renewable energy and electric vehicles.

site_title: Education plays crucial role in enabling push towards sustainability
summary: New Zealand's education system is prioritizing sustainability, with institutions like the University of Auckland and Lincoln University incorporating the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) into their curricula. The country is also offering sustainability-focused programs and online courses to equip students with real-world skills. A recent survey found that 92% of students believe universities should promote sustainable development, and 81% of teachers in New Zealand allow students to learn about ecological and conservation issues. This shift towards sustainability is seen as crucial for addressing global challenges such as climate change, poverty, and inequality.

site_title: McDonald's profits jump on higher price as more markets reopen
summary: McDonald's reported a 22% increase in net income to $2.1 billion in its third-quarter earnings, driven by strong US sales growth fueled by price increases and fewer closures in overseas markets. The company saw higher sales in Britain, Japan, and Latin America, and solid sales in Canada, France, and Germany. Global comparable sales increased 10% over 2019, driven by an omnichannel experience focused on customer needs.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust's Q3 net property income rises 8%
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported an 8% increase in net property income to S$39.9 million for the third quarter ended Sep 30, 2021, driven by income contributions from the Anchor Annex and aVance 6 buildings. However, the growth was offset by lower occupancy and utilities income due to the impact of Covid-19. Total property income rose 4% to S$48.9 million.

site_title: Novavax files for UK authorisation of Covid protein shot
summary: Novavax has submitted for UK authorization of its Covid-19 protein shot, the first of its kind in the region. The vaccine mimics the coronavirus's spike protein, requires two doses, and can be stored at refrigerator temperatures. Shares of Novavax rose 16% after the announcement. The company's vaccine was developed after losing out in the initial phase of vaccine development to rivals.

site_title: Singapore's daily Covid cases hit new peak of 5,324; MOH monitoring 'unusual surge'
summary: Singapore reported 5,324 new Covid-19 cases on Oct 27, the highest daily peak, with 4,651 in the community and 661 in migrant worker dormitories. The ministry is investigating the sudden surge. Ten people aged 54-96 died from Covid-19 complications, with underlying medical conditions. This brings Singapore's death toll to 349. The community cases included 728 seniors over 60, and the total cases now stand at 184,419.

site_title: US capital goods orders increase for a seventh straight month
summary: US capital goods orders increased for a seventh consecutive month in September, rising 0.8% after a 0.5% increase in August, according to Commerce Department figures. Core capital goods orders, excluding aircraft and military hardware, reached record levels, while bookings for all durable goods decreased 0.4% due to declines in aircraft and cars. Unfilled orders for manufactured durable goods climbed 0.7%, and inventories increased 0.9% for a second month, highlighting ongoing production constraints and long lead times faced by manufacturers.

site_title: US trade deficit widens in September; inventories mixed
summary: The US trade deficit in goods increased 9.2% to $96.3 billion in September, driven by a 4.7% decline in exports and a 0.5% gain in imports. Wholesale inventories rose 1.1% and retail inventories fell 0.2% in September, with retail inventories excluding autos increasing 0.6%. The data suggests the US economy likely grew at a 2.7% annualized rate in the third quarter, a step-down from the 6.7% rate in the second quarter.

site_title: China will defer some taxes for manufacturing firms due to high costs
summary: China's Cabinet announced a tax deferral for manufacturing firms for three months from November, totaling around 200 billion yuan (S$42.1 billion) for small firms, due to high raw material prices and production costs. This move aims to help resolve operational difficulties faced by coal companies and heating firms. The country's GDP expanded 4.9% in July-September, the weakest pace since 2020, prompting policymakers to consider more supportive measures. The government will study tax reduction policies and fine-tune macro policies to steady a slowing economy.

site_title: Malaysia says risk from biscuits low after HK group's warning
summary: Malaysia's Health Director General Noor Hisham Abdullah stated that the health risk from cancer-causing substances in biscuits is low, citing monitoring data showing an average acrylamide level of 246 micrograms per kilo, below the European Union's 350 microgram threshold. A Hong Kong consumer watchdog found carcinogens in 60 samples of biscuits, including those made by Malaysia's Hup Seng Industries, which had misleading nutrition labels. Hup Seng's shares remained unchanged despite concerns raised by the Hong Kong Consumer Council.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust grows its revenue and property income on lower rental rebates, lease termination compensation
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 11.5% increase in gross revenue and a 10.7% rise in net property income for the half-year of FY 2022, driven by lower rental rebates and lease termination compensation. Distribution per unit (DPU) grew 5.3% to 4.39 Singapore cents. The trust's total investment value reached over S$8.7 billion, with a flat net asset value per unit of S$1.72.

site_title: China urges Evergrande's Hui to tap wealth; firms to repay
summary: China has urged companies to make timely payments on their offshore bonds, with China Evergrande Group's billionaire founder Hui Ka Yan facing pressure to tap his personal wealth to ease the company's debt crisis. Officials have warned developers that missing payments must be reported immediately, while Hui is under pressure to use his $7 billion in dividends to help the embattled developer. The company's bonds are set to mature, and a debt restructuring is expected, which could be one of the largest in China.

site_title: GM upbeat on full-year earnings despite quarterly profit drop
summary: General Motors reported stronger-than-expected third-quarter results despite a drop in revenue and profit, citing the global semiconductor shortage. The company's adjusted earnings per share fell to $1.52 from $2.83 a year earlier. Full-year earnings are expected to approach the high end of GM's previous forecast, with EBIT-adjusted in the range of $11.5 billion to $13.5 billion. Strong pricing on full-size pickups and SUVs and an agreement with LG Electronics to cover recall costs partially offset the negative impact.

site_title: Fashion retailer Love, Bonito bags US$50m to fund international expansion
summary: Fashion retailer Love, Bonito has secured US$50 million in funding from China-based private equity firm Primavera Capital Group to fuel international expansion. The funding, led by Primavera Capital, is Primavera Capital's first investment in South-east Asia. Love, Bonito plans to double down on existing markets and drive expansion in Hong Kong, Japan, the Philippines, and the US, with a focus on reaching the Asian diaspora. The company aims to push global expansion across three key regions: South-east Asia, East Asia, and the US and Australia.

site_title: Malaysian undersea cable installer OMS Group exploring IPO
summary: OMS Group, a Malaysian undersea cable installer, is exploring an initial public offering (IPO) that could value the company at over $500 million. The company has asked banks to submit proposals for the potential IPO, which could take place as soon as next year. Possible venues for the listing include Australia, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Singapore. OMS Group provides integrated solutions for sub-sea cable installation and maintenance projects, with completed projects globally, including the Papua New Guinea National Submarine Fiber Cable Network and the Asia Submarine-Cable Express.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts 8.4% rise in Q3 distributable income
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported an 8.4% rise in Q3 distributable income to US$15.9 million, driven by recent acquisitions and stronger portfolio performance. Net property income rose 5.6% to US$21.7 million, with 100% occupancy in both acquired buildings. The company's aggregate leverage stood at 37.7%, and its top 10 tenants, mostly tech companies, contribute 22% of cash rental income. The office market is seeing a 15-month high in demand for space, providing income resilience for the company.

site_title: Boeing reports Q3 loss as 787 woes drag down results
summary: Boeing reported a Q3 loss of $109 million, down from a loss of $449 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the decline to ongoing issues with the 787 Dreamliner, including $1 billion in new expenses announced. The loss is part of Boeing's ongoing efforts to recover from earlier stumbles and fully address the 787 woes.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after upbeat earnings reports
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Wednesday, driven by upbeat earnings reports. The Dow Jones rose 0.22% to 35,835.43, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.12% and 0.26%, respectively. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Deutsche Bank extends profit run on boost from dealmaking fees
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 7% increase in profits in the third quarter, its fifth consecutive quarter in the black, driven by dealmaking fees and a decrease in provisions related to the coronavirus pandemic. The bank's shares were down 6% despite beating analyst expectations. The result is seen as a victory for CEO Christian Sewing, who oversaw a US$10 billion overhaul of the bank in 2019. Analysts praised the bank's efforts to drive efficiencies and maintain controls, but noted that its investment bank business still faces challenges.

site_title: Raffles Education not exiting education; suggests shareholders ask Oei Hong Leong about 'feud' with CEO
summary: Raffles Education, despite cumulative losses of over S$150 million from its core business over 10 years, will not exit the education business. The company clarified its businesses include education assets management and real estate investment linked to education. CEO Chew Hua Seng's profit-sharing is based on pre-tax profit, including unrealized fair value gains. Chew waived his profit-sharing for 2018. The company is set to reward Chew with S$2.89 million in total remuneration, which will be reviewed annually. Shareholders have questioned the justification, particularly regarding Chew's remuneration and the "feud" with billionaire shareholder Oei Hong Leong.

site_title: Amazon's new 100,000 sq ft corporate office makes it Asia Square's anchor tenant
summary: Amazon has opened its 100,000 sq ft corporate office in Asia Square, Singapore, marking the tech giant as the anchor tenant. The office, spanning three floors, will house over 30 teams and up to 700 employees. Amazon plans to create over 200 new jobs in Singapore by end-2022, expanding its offerings and supporting local businesses. The new office features collaborative spaces, training rooms, and facilities for work and learning, demonstrating Amazon's commitment to invest in Singapore's digital economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks dip with eyes on earnings, elections
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on October 27, 2021, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.03% and the Topix index down 0.2%, following profit-taking after previous rallies. Investors watched corporate earnings and Japan's upcoming general election.

site_title: Hackers-for-hire are biggest cybersecurity threat, says EU agency
summary: The European Union's cybersecurity agency ENISA has reported that hackers-for-hire are the biggest threat to online security over the past 15 months. The Covid-19 pandemic and home working created opportunities for cybercriminals, with high-profile ransomware attacks targeting the Colonial Pipeline and JBS. The health sector was a significant target, with hackers seeking vaccine information. Cryptocurrency was the preferred payment method, and other growing threats include cryptojacking, misinformation, and disinformation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Wednesday, down 1.12 points to 1,583.08, following a day of trading with losers outnumbering gainers 632 to 386. The market saw a significant volume of 4.016 billion lots worth RM2.503 billion.

site_title: Finnish scientists create 'sustainable' lab-grown coffee
summary: Scientists in Finland have developed a method to grow sustainable coffee in a lab, using coffee plant cells in a bioreactor under controlled conditions. The lab-grown coffee is not ground from beans but rather grown from cells and can be brewed like conventional coffee. Researchers believe it could reduce the environmental impact of coffee production, including deforestation and fossil fuel use. While the taste is currently being tested by a panel of sensory analysts, the team estimates it could take four years for the product to gain regulatory approval and commercial backing.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore is set to unveil a new public housing model for HDB flats in prime locations, in response to public demand to limit resale in these areas. A taskforce has also called for a tighter review process for employment passes and unemployment benefits for professionals and managers. Meanwhile, six countries from South Asia will be allowed to enter Singapore after October 26, subject to a 10-day stay-home notice. The government has also extended the Stabilisation Phase of its economic support measures until November 21, providing an additional S$640 million in support for firms.

site_title: Japanese insurers cautious on foreign government bonds, shrug off dollar rally
summary: Japanese insurers are becoming more cautious in buying foreign government bonds without a currency hedge, citing the recent dollar rally against the yen. Only two of the top 10 insurers plan to increase foreign bond holdings without a hedge between October and March. Insurers prefer investing in corporate bonds and local yen bonds, seeking to meet regulatory requirements and capitalize on higher returns. Industry leaders expect the dollar to decline, with Nippon Life forecasting a return to 108 yen by March, and many insurers are taking out currency hedges or limiting their foreign bond exposure due to low returns.

site_title: Singapore shares gain even as regional markets fall; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, bucking regional trends, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,218.17. Jardine Matheson and Hongkong Land were top gainers, while ComfortDelGro fell 1.3%. Regional markets fell, with Hong Kong and mainland China shares leading losses. Analysts attribute the decline to negative news from China, including Covid-19 cases and real-estate bond defaults.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.57% on Wednesday, with tech firms taking a heavy hit after US authorities banned China Telecom from the country over national security concerns. The Hang Seng Index fell 409.53 points to 25,628.74, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The move ramps up tensions between the US and China, affecting global markets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower as Germany cuts growth outlook
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened lower on Wednesday due to Germany's cut in growth outlook, with London's FTSE 100 index shedding 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX index losing 0.2%. The German economy is projected to expand by 2.6% this year, slower than expected, largely due to supply chain bottlenecks. The news also affected Paris' CAC 40 index, which opened with a 0.1% loss.

site_title: Tharman sees a place for crypto in Asia finance hub
summary: Singapore's central bank chairman, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, believes cryptocurrencies can have a role in the nation's financial sector if regulated. He mentioned stablecoins could complement traditional payment systems, but emphasized the need for regulation to combat illicit finance activities like anti-money laundering. Tharman's comments come as Singapore aims to establish itself as an Asian finance hub.

site_title: Sunak announces UK growth upgrade, pledges to control inflation
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak announced a revised economic growth forecast, predicting 6.5% growth in 2021, higher than the initial 4.0% estimate. This growth is attributed to the country's swift recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic and vaccination program. Sunak pledged to control inflation, increase public spending, and reduce borrowing, while also implementing new rules to govern borrowing and ensure fiscal discipline. The revised forecast is close to the International Monetary Fund's estimate of 6.8% growth in 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Analysts predict a minimal impact of Singapore's new HDB prime model on the private market. Amazon plans a 100,000 sq ft corporate office in Asia Square, creating over 200 new jobs by end-2022. Love, Bonito raised US$50m to fund international expansion. Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) expects improved leasing sentiment with relaxed Covid restrictions, while ESR-Reit reported a 1.7% rise in Q3 DPU. The STI rose 0.4% to close at 3,218.17, despite regional markets falling. Design Studio Group filed a winding up application, and FCT posted a 39.3% rise in H2 DPU.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on profit-taking
summary: South Korean stocks fell on Wednesday, October 27, as traders booked profits after two consecutive sessions of gains. The benchmark Kospi ended 23.59 points lower, or 0.77%, at 3,025.49. Heavyweight chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix dropped 1.41% and 0.49%, respectively. Foreigners were net sellers of 293 billion won worth of shares, and the won weakened, ending at 1,170 per dollar. The most liquid 3-year Korean treasury bond yield rose by 9.4 basis points to 2.041%.

site_title: Indonesia central bank may stick to loan rules on vehicles, property until 2023
summary: Indonesia's central bank may extend its "loose macroprudential policy" on vehicle and property loans until 2023 to support national economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the policy aims to ensure sufficient credit for businesses, and its extension will be evaluated until 2023.

site_title: Design Studio Group files winding up application
summary: Design Studio Group, a Singapore-based design studio, has commenced a winding up application against the company due to its inability to pay debts and cash flow insolvency. The company's subsidiaries have also filed for creditors' voluntary liquidation. The decision follows a rejected creditor scheme and withdrawal of an appeal. The winding up application is scheduled for November 19, 2021, and will result in the company ceasing to submit a proposal for share trading resumption. The move is deemed the most time-efficient and cost-effective manner to liquidate the company under court control.

site_title: Fintech BondEvalue levels playing field for retail bond investors
summary: BondEvalue, a blockchain-based fractional bond trading platform, aims to level the playing field for retail investors by making bond investing quicker and more accessible. Founded by Rahul Banerjee, the platform enables investors to buy bonds digitally and on the go, with prices transparent and settled in a few milliseconds. Regulated as a recognised market operator by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, BondEvalue has integrated with global custodians, including Citibank and Northern Trust. The platform hopes to address investor pain points, including lack of transparency and liquidity, and is expanding into new markets, including digital bond funds and local currency bond markets.

site_title: FCT eyes relaxed Covid restrictions to bring shoppers back as retail rental reversion dips
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is optimistic about improving leasing sentiment in Singapore as the retail sector experiences a "sustainable reopening" following the easing of Covid-19 restrictions. The trust's retail rental reversion fell to negative 0.6% in FY2021, but occupancy improved to 97.3% and sales remained resilient at 93-98% of pre-pandemic levels. FCT expects improved shopper traffic and footfalls as the government implements measures such as booster shots and vaccinated travel lanes. The trust's distribution per unit rose 39.3% to 6.089 Singapore cents for the second half of FY2021.

site_title: Choon Kim House up for collective sale again; owners hope to fetch S$55m
summary: Choon Kim House, a four-storey mixed-use building in Singapore, is being offered for collective sale by tender for the third time. The owners aim to fetch around S$55 million, with 87% consent from owners and 84% consent from strata area. The building spans 14,988 sq ft and features 7 retail units, 13 offices, and 10 residential apartments. The sale is seen as a potential "bite-sized investment property" with a well-diversified tenant mix, allowing investors to keep the building for existing use without making a redevelopment application.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 1.1% dip in Q1 free cash flow to equity
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 1.1% decrease in Q1 free cash flow to equity to S$44.7 million, despite a 6.3% rise in operational cash flow to S$56.8 million. The trust's expenses increased 47.2% to S$12.1 million, driven by a 22.4% increase in operational cash flow from its distribution and network business. KIT is expected to complete the acquisition of a 30% stake in the SingSpring Desalination Plant in Q4, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: B2B marketplace network Proxtera expands its reach
summary: Proxtera, a B2B marketplace network, has expanded its reach to serve approximately 400,000 small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through 13 marketplace partners across 7 countries. The company plans to continue growing its network in Asia and Africa next year, aiming to provide domestic ecosystems with easy access to the global digital economy. Proxtera will also expand its embedded financial services, offering a wider set of financial empowerment tools through third-party providers.

images.alt_text: Proxtera works with its partners to assist SMEs with procurement and connect businesses with other wholesale sellers as well.

site_title: Thai September factory output falls 1.28% y-o-y, smaller drop than forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) in September fell 1.28% from the previous year, a smaller drop than forecast. This marks a reversal from the 4.71% decline in August, following the easing of coronavirus restrictions. The reading is better than the 3.0% fall predicted in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Keppel to roll out energy-as-a-service infrastructure for S$50m
summary: Keppel Infrastructure secured a S$50 million contract to roll out energy-as-a-service (EaaS) infrastructure at Perennial Business City in Singapore. The project includes efficient chiller systems, photovoltaic solar panels, and electric vehicle charging stations, aiming to reduce carbon emissions and achieve Green Mark Super Low Energy certification. Keppel Corp does not expect this contract to impact earnings, with shares rising by S$0.01 to S$5.40 after the announcement. The project will generate 1,200 megawatt hour of renewable energy per year and reduce 500 tonnes of annual carbon emissions.

site_title: Japan Exchange Group looking to extend Tokyo bourse trading hours
summary: Japan Exchange Group is considering extending Tokyo bourse trading hours by 30 minutes in the latter half of 2024, aiming to improve market efficiency and competitiveness.

site_title: Covid infections in Beijing at its highest level in 8 months
summary: Beijing is experiencing its worst COVID-19 outbreak in over 8 months, with 20 infections reported in the latest flare-up fueled by tourists returning from northern provinces. A couple from Beijing who ignored health warnings and played mahjong with friends despite high fevers sparked the outbreak, infecting hundreds of people. The city has taken drastic measures, including closing apartment buildings, shops, and public spaces, and requiring visitors to produce negative COVID tests and undergo health monitoring. The delta variant is driving the outbreak, complicating China's efforts to eradicate the virus and maintain its "Covid Zero" approach.

site_title: Work arrangement changes, inflation continue to put pressure on Mapletree Industrial Trust
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) faces pressure from changing tenant usage patterns and inflation, which may squeeze its margins. The trust's business park segment will continue to come under pressure as hybrid work models take hold, with occupancy rates declining to 93.9% from 97.8% in Q2. MIT's manager expects operating expenditure to increase by about S$200,000 per month due to rising energy prices and service contract costs. Despite this, the trust's distribution per unit rose to 3.47 Singapore cents, and net property income grew 47.4% to S$120.3 million.

site_title: Blockchain tech is an 'enabler'; collaboration makes it work
summary: Blockchain technology, used in Singapore's digital travel pass, is seen as an "enabler" rather than a standalone solution, requiring collaboration among stakeholders to be successful. The technology's potential was highlighted during the Covid-19 pandemic, with applications in digital identities, travel verification, and financial assets. Temasek's Blockchain@Temasek initiative focuses on programmable money, decentralized finance, and digitalizing financial assets, but also emphasizes the need for caution and protection mechanisms to prevent potential risks.

site_title: UN urges G-20 to ensure finance sector's climate pledges are solid
summary: The United Nations has urged G-20 nations to ensure financial institutions' net zero commitments are robust and backed by science, with a focus on ending financing for new fossil fuel projects. The UN Environment Programme Finance Initiative has provided 11 recommendations to policymakers, including setting science-based targets and aligning lending with global warming goals. Financial institutions must also report annually on progress and incentivize companies to act. The call comes ahead of crunch climate talks in Glasgow, Scotland, amid concerns that current pledges are too weak.

site_title: Asian players more open to innovations: UOB
summary: UOB believes Asian capital markets are more open to innovations due to fewer legacy systems and regulations. The bank is tapping blockchain and distributed ledger technology to streamline processes, citing partnerships with digital asset platforms Marketnode and ADDX. Programmable securities and tokenisation of assets can improve efficiency and provide more investment opportunities. UOB has seen significant uptake of digital solutions, including a 53% rise in online transactions and 83.4% take-up rate for its digital banking platform, UOB Infinity. Despite challenges, UOB is working to overcome industry standards and regulatory hurdles to further digitalize trade finance and capital markets.

site_title: Hot stock: Koh Brothers Eco up as much as 29.8% after securing PUB contract
summary: Koh Brothers Eco's shares surged 29.8% after securing a S$200.7 million contract with the Public Utilities Board, making it the most actively traded stock by volume. The company's sustainable engineering solutions provider reached a high of S$0.075 and closed at S$0.065 on Oct 27.

site_title: Stablecoin operator Circle pads up cash reserves ahead of US SPAC listing
summary: US-based stablecoin operator Circle has bolstered its cash reserves ahead of a planned listing on the New York Stock Exchange via a $4.5 billion blank-cheque deal. The move comes as regulators express concerns over the liquid assets backing stablecoins, which have surged in value due to the booming crypto market. Circle aims to fortify its reserves to alleviate these concerns, demonstrating its commitment to regulatory compliance as it prepares to enter the regulated public stock markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as inflation data stokes rate-hike bets
summary: Australian shares ended flat at 7,448.7 points, despite a 6-year high in core inflation and concerns of interest rate hikes. The metals and mining sector declined 1.2% on weak iron ore prices, while gold stocks fell 11.1%. The Australian dollar firmed 0.4% and short-term bond yields touched their highest since 2019. The benchmark ASX 200 index was unchanged.

site_title: Beijing tells Evergrande boss to pay firm's debts with own cash: report
summary: Chinese authorities have told Evergrande founder Xu Jiayin to use his personal wealth to alleviate the company's debt crisis, according to reports. The liquidity crunch has hammered investor sentiment and rattled China's real estate market, raising concerns of a possible contagion. Evergrande recently paid interest on an offshore bond, avoiding a default and providing a reprieve. The move is seen as a step to stabilize the company and the broader economy.

site_title: Lower trading fees, variety of order types, give FTX an edge
summary: FTX, a Bahamian-based cryptocurrency exchange, has gained significant traction with over 1 million users and $10 billion in daily trading volume. The company has a tiered fee structure and offers various order types, giving it an edge over competitors. FTX co-founder Sam Bankman-Fried attributes the company's rapid growth to its lower trading fees and excellent order selection. With a valuation of $25 billion, FTX is expanding into the Asian region, including Singapore, and prioritizing offices in jurisdictions without travel restrictions.

site_title: Some airlines risk failure if they do not cut emissions faster: industry report
summary: Airlines risk failure if they don't cut carbon emissions quickly, with a mismatch between short-term corporate travel targets and the industry's 2050 net zero goal. Industry report CAPA/Envest warns that major fund managers, such as BlackRock, are expressing concerns about climate change, putting pressure on airlines to accelerate their journey to net zero. Companies like HSBC and Zurich Insurance Group have already announced plans to cut business travel emissions by 70%. Low-cost carriers with newer fleets and higher load factors were among the best performers, while struggling airlines like Turkish Airlines and Japan Airlines were among the worst.

site_title: HSBC issues Singapore's first EFS-green loan worth S$6m to Durapower
summary: HSBC Singapore has issued Singapore's first EFS-green loan worth S$6 million to Durapower Group, a tech company developing high-tech energy storage solutions for the Tuas Mega Port. The loan, facilitated by the Enterprise Financing Scheme-Green (EFS-Green Scheme), enables Durapower to accelerate the development and distribution of its solutions, supporting Singapore's ambition to create a greener port. This partnership aims to mobilize more enterprises in the journey towards a low-carbon economy and provide environmental and social benefits.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse sees profit drop as major IPOs delayed
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, reported its second quarterly profit decline due to China's crackdown on sectors and delayed major IPOs. Net income fell to HK$3.3 billion in the 3 months through September, down from HK$3.4 billion a year earlier. The exchange's introduction of MSCI A50 futures is expected to boost earnings prospects, but a dry patch in Hong Kong's primary-listing market may impact growth. China's regulatory scrutiny has clouded investment sentiment, with several billion-dollar IPOs put on hold.

site_title: Easing SMEs' insurance needs through tech with Business@Pulse
summary: Prudential's Pulse app, a digital health and wealth platform, is expanding to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore with insurance and employee benefits management. The new "Business@Pulse" platform aims to simplify access to insurance and wellness resources for SMEs, who often lack the resources to manage their employees' insurance needs. The platform will offer digital tools for policy management, claims processing, and employee benefits management, and is expected to reach customers through existing group policies and new onboarding.

site_title: Hot stock: Vividthree sees heavy trading on potential blockchain, NFT collaboration
summary: Vividthree Holdings OMK shares experienced heavy trading on October 27, 2021, after the company announced its exploration of gaming opportunities to increase revenue streams. The counter reached a high of S$0.08 and ended 2.4 cents higher at S$0.069, with 18.9 million shares changing hands. No married deals were recorded, according to ShareInvestor data.

site_title: MAS tests central bank digital currencies with global counterparts
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is testing central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) with global counterparts as part of Project Dunbar. The initiative aims to develop a shared platform for cross-border transactions using multiple CBDCs, potentially reducing settlement risks and enabling instantaneous, real-time settlement. The MAS is collaborating with central banks in Australia, Malaysia, and South Africa, and has launched a global competition to encourage innovative retail CBDC solutions. Challenges include security, convergence in standards, and the potential displacement of the correspondent banking system, but the project seeks to improve foreign-exchange liquidity and cheaper payments.

site_title: FCC revokes authority of China Telecom's US unit
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) revoked the authorization of China Telecom's US unit, citing "significant" national security risks due to its ownership and control by the Chinese government. The decision orders China Telecom America to discontinue service within 60 days, ending a nearly 20-year operation in the US. The FCC cited risks of espionage and other harmful activities against the US, highlighting the importance of safeguarding telecoms infrastructure.

site_title: Gold eases on firmer US dollar, yields ahead of central bank meetings
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,788.66 per ounce, retreating from the $1,800 mark, due to a stronger US dollar and elevated bond yields ahead of key central bank meetings. Benchmark 10-year US Treasury yields rose, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold. The Bank of Japan and European Central Bank meetings on Thursday are expected to influence gold prices. Despite concerns about inflation, US consumer confidence unexpectedly rose, and China's net gold imports surged in September.

site_title: New rules for prime HDB flats not likely to impact private market: analysts
summary: Singapore's new prime-location public housing (PLH) model, announced by the Ministry of National Development, aims to keep prime HDB flats affordable and inclusive. The model includes a 10-year minimum occupation period (MOP) and additional subsidies clawed back upon resale. Analysts say the new rules are unlikely to impact the private market, as buyers can afford private homes with better facilities and price appreciation. The PLH flats' purchase eligibility conditions will be the same as BTO flats, but priority quotas for the Married Child Priority Scheme will be reduced.

site_title: Australia core inflation speeds to six-year high in Q3, feeds rate fever
summary: Australia's core inflation accelerated to a six-year high of 2.1% in Q3, surpassing expectations and pushing the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2% to 3% target range for the first time in six years. The trimmed mean measure of core inflation rose 0.7%, above forecasts, and led to a surge in interest rate expectations, with markets betting on earlier rate hikes. Investors dumped shorter-dated bonds, and yields on key bonds rose, challenging the RBA's commitment to keeping cash rates near 0.1%.

site_title: Tapping the network effect for a sustainable future
summary: Mastercard is leveraging its global network of 3 billion cardholders and 70 million merchants to drive sustainability through the "network effect". The company is collaborating with partners to bring environmental solutions to market, such as its Priceless Planet Coalition programme, which aims to restore 100 million trees by 2025. Mastercard's sustainability innovation lab will develop eco-conscious digital solutions, including a carbon calculator, to help consumers make better consumption decisions. The company aims to bring 1 billion people and 50 million micro and small businesses into the digital economy by 2025, with a focus on financial inclusion and sustainable finance.

site_title: Partior looks to grow and scale beyond existing partners in next 15 months
summary: Partior, a blockchain-based technology firm, aims to scale its ecosystem to support financial institutions beyond its existing partners over the next 15 months. The company's CEO, Jason Thompson, emphasizes the need for new infrastructure to support central bank digital currencies and global payment flows, which are expected to reach $156 trillion next year. Partior's platform achieved end-to-end settlements in under 120 seconds in its first pilot with participating banks, and the company plans to expand its open ecosystem to allow vendors and banks to participate.

site_title: UK's Sunak tries to move on from Covid-19 with new spending plans
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak will announce a multi-billion-pound investment plan to help Prime Minister Boris Johnson meet his spending promises, focusing on public transport, skills training, and other projects. The plan aims to "level up" poorer regions and advance the government's low-carbon credentials ahead of the COP26 climate summit. Despite a significant tax increase, Sunak will keep a tight grip on day-to-day spending, which could slow Britain's recovery. The government's borrowing forecast has been upgraded, giving it more room for manoeuvre.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth accelerates in September despite cost pressures
summary: China's industrial firms saw a 16.3% year-on-year increase in profits to 738.74 billion yuan in September, driven by strong growth in mining and raw materials industries. However, power firms were squeezed, with profits falling 24.6% due to high coal prices and supply shortages. The industrial sector has been impacted by surging prices, supply bottlenecks, and power rationing. Despite this, Beijing has implemented measures to curb elevated metals prices and ease power crunches, and analysts expect the People's Bank of China to refrain from stimulating the economy until the first quarter of 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.16% and the Topix index down 0.05%, following sharp rallies in the previous session. Investors are closely watching corporate earnings this week.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday on profit-taking after sharp rallies in the previous session, as investors closely watched this week's corporate earnings.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong leads stocks lower as US ban on China Telecom fans tensions
summary: Hong Kong's stocks fell as US banned China Telecom, adding to tensions between the US and China. Despite a strong corporate earnings season, investors are cautious due to ongoing friction between Washington and Beijing. The ban on China Telecom has sparked concerns about inflation and national security, casting a dark shadow over trading floors.

site_title: Blending green finance with technology to be a force for good
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched Project Greenprint, a technology platform aimed at promoting a sustainable financial ecosystem. The platform seeks to bridge the gap in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) data, enabling financial institutions to mobilize capital for green projects. With the goal of developing Singapore's fintech ecosystem and enhancing its role as a regional green finance hub, Project Greenprint will promote a greener financial ecosystem through three pillars: mobilizing capital, monitoring commitment, and measuring impact.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.93% at the opening of trading on October 27, 2021, due to US officials banning China Telecom from operating in the country over national security concerns. The Hang Seng Index fell 243.10 points to 25,795.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The ban heightened tensions between the US and China, impacting global markets.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,209.42 at the open on Wednesday, driven by stronger overseas markets and positive business updates from real estate investment trusts. Banking stocks were mixed, while tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.1% in the US. European stocks rose, and Tokyo stocks opened lower on profit-taking.

site_title: More information needed from requisitioning shareholders calling for EGM: ecoWise
summary: Ecowise Holdings has issued a response to shareholders calling for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove its deputy chief executive Cao Shixuan and appoint new directors. The EGM requisitionists, who collectively own 12.5% of the company's shares, failed to specify the background and reasons for each proposed resolution, including qualifications and roles for proposed new directors. Ecowise intends to reach out to the relevant shareholders for the necessary information and will provide its views on the requisitionists' proposed resolutions in due course.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.65 points or 0.17% to 1,586.85 on Wednesday, driven by a gain of 165 stocks over 130 losers. The index saw 204.98 million lots traded worth RM173.07 million.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust prices S$400m perps at 3.725%; redeems 4.18% perps
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) priced S$400 million of fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities at 3.725% and plans to redeem all outstanding 4.18% perps at par on Nov 25. The new securities will have a reset rate equivalent to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average Overnight Indexed Swap rate plus 2.485%. The trust posted a 19.2% year-on-year rise in distributable income to S$93.4 million in the second quarter, with a distribution per unit growing 5.7% to 2.173 Singapore cents.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as miners and Woolworths drop, inflation data hurts
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.3% on Wednesday, erasing early gains, due to losses in mining and gold stocks amid falling commodity prices and a sharp decline in Woolworths Group. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,425, snapping a five-session rally. Core inflation jumped to a six-year high, and the gold sub-index fell 1.4% due to dollar strength. Telecom stocks rose 1.7% to top the index, led by a 2.2% gain in Telstra Corp.

site_title: Listing success stories will boost SGX liquidity: Temasek unit CEO
summary: Temasek's 65 Equity Partners, a unit managing a S$1.5 billion co-investment fund, aims to boost liquidity on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) by backing high-growth companies for eventual listings. The Anchor Fund @ 65, announced in September, will support companies in Singapore and the region, and may invest in pre-IPO rounds or as a cornerstone investor at IPO. CEO Tan Chong Lee believes success stories will attract more companies to list locally, creating a benchmark and changing perceptions of low liquidity.

site_title: ESR-Reit Q3 DPU rises 1.7% to S$0.00712 on enlarged unit base
summary: ESR-Reit's third-quarter distributable income per unit (DPU) rose 1.7% to S$0.00712, driven by broad-based year-on-year increases in gross revenue and net property income. The growth is attributed to the acquisition of 46A Tanjong Penjuru and the absence of Covid-19 rental rebates. The company's portfolio occupancy rate remained resilient at 91.2%, and the year-to-date rental reversion was 2.2% lower due to lower renewal rates. ESR-Reit's debt maturity profile is well-staggered, with a weighted average debt expiry of 2.6 years.

site_title: Robinhood shares drop below IPO price in after-market trading on crypto slowdown
summary: Robinhood Markets' shares fell 8.77% to $36.10 in after-hours trading, below their initial public offering price of $38, after reporting softer-than-expected revenue for the third quarter. The slowdown in retail trading, particularly in cryptocurrencies like dogecoin, led to a 27% decline in equities trading revenue and a 78% drop in crypto revenue. Total revenue rose 35% to $365 million, but missed analyst expectations. The company attributed the slowdown to a decrease in new funded accounts and a decrease in crypto activity.

site_title: Hatcher+ and partners launch agritech fund
summary: Hatcher+, a venture investment management platform, has partnered with Tiverton Agriculture Impact Fund and First Degree Global Asset Management to launch the agritech fund, CarbonNation, in Singapore. The fund will invest in sustainable, carbon-credit producing farming properties, with a minimum size of US$20 million. The consortium plans to build a portfolio of 8-10 properties over the next 18-36 months, with its first project being a 100-year-old property in Queensland, Australia, which has been re-engineered to produce crops and carbon credits while protecting local wildlife.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust posts 39.3% rise in H2 DPU at S$0.06089
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) posted a 39.3% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.06089, driven by a 159.9% rise in gross revenue to S$167.5 million. Net property income and distributable income also grew significantly, up 213.2% and 243.9% respectively. The improved performance is attributed to the acquisition of AsiaRetail Fund and lower rental rebates.

site_title: TikTok, YouTube and Snapchat defend impact on kids at US hearing
summary: US lawmakers held a hearing on the impact of social media platforms on children, with representatives from TikTok, Snapchat, and YouTube defending their safety measures. Despite concerns over mental health and safety risks, the platforms argued they are built to protect against these issues. TikTok emphasized its unique platform, which focuses on watching and creating content, while Snapchat highlighted its default image deletion feature. YouTube claimed to have removed nearly 1.8 million videos that violated child safety policies. However, lawmakers questioned the platforms' efforts, with Senator Marsha Blackburn calling for greater regulation to prevent the promotion of dangerous content for young users.

site_title: Australia lifts international travel ban for citizens
summary: Australia has lifted its international travel ban for fully vaccinated citizens, allowing them to travel overseas without permission. The ban was in place for over 18 months. The move comes as the country's adult double-dose vaccination rate approaches 80%. Skilled workers and international students are also expected to be allowed to enter the country by year's end.

site_title: US panel recommends Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine for younger children
summary: A US medical panel has endorsed the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5-11, with 17 experts voting in favour and one abstention. The panel concluded that the known benefits of vaccination outweigh the risks, particularly in preventing hospitalizations and deaths from Covid-19. The FDA is expected to approve the vaccine soon, making 28 million young Americans eligible by mid-November. Experts noted that the theoretical risk of myocarditis is likely to be low, but some cautioned that vaccination should remain a personal decision for families.

site_title: Google-parent Alphabet profit soars to over US$18b
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported a profit of over $18.9 billion in the recently-ended quarter, a 41% increase from the same period last year. The company's revenue reached $65.1 billion, driven by strong ad sales and cloud services. Alphabet's CEO Sundar Pichai attributed the success to investments in artificial intelligence, which are enabling the company to build more helpful products. Despite increased regulatory pressure, Alphabet remains a dominant force in the online advertising market, with a 28.6% share.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 edge up to fresh records amid earnings deluge
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gaining 0.1% and 0.2% respectively, driven by better-than-expected earnings and strong consumer confidence data. The Nasdaq Composite Index also reached a record, amid a rebound in consumer confidence and sales of new homes surging 14% in October. Individual companies like Facebook, Apple, and Amazon advanced, while United Parcel Service and Hasbro rose, while Lockheed Martin fell.

site_title: Republican leaders blame stimulus for rising US inflation
summary: US Republican leaders blame the recent surge in inflation on the pandemic stimulus package, with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell arguing that the flood of money has led to rising prices, including petrol prices over $3 a gallon. The US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen attributes the spike in inflation as "transitory," while Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell suggests that price pressures will fade as pandemic effects are worked out. The Democratic-led Senate is working on two spending packages, one for infrastructure and another for social programs, despite concerns over the potential impact on inflation.

site_title: Australia's Crown branded 'disgraceful', gets two years to fix Melbourne casino
summary: A Royal Commission in Victoria, Australia, has deemed Crown Resorts "disgraceful" for its actions, including enabling money laundering and misleading regulators. Despite this, the commission allowed Crown to continue operating its Melbourne casino under supervision for two years. The company's billionaire owner, James Packer, was ordered to reduce his stake to 5% by 2024. The report also recommended boosting the maximum penalty for casino wrongdoing to $100 million and increasing oversight of the casino. Crown's shares rose 7.5% after the decision, providing relief for investors.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence falls in October
summary: New Zealand business confidence fell in October, with a net 13.4% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, according to an ANZ Bank survey. This represents a decline from the 7.2% pessimism level in the September poll. Despite this, 21.7% of respondents expected their businesses to grow in the next 12 months, up from 18.2% in the previous month. The decline in business confidence was attributed to intensifying cost and inflation pressures due to Covid-19 uncertainty.

site_title: WTO wades in on Australia-China wine spat
summary: Australia has secured a dispute panel at the World Trade Organization (WTO) to investigate China's imposition of anti-dumping and countervailing duties on imported Australian wine. The decision comes after China blocked Australia's first request, and Australia's second request was automatically granted. The customs barriers have almost closed the most important export market for Australian wines, worth around US$840 million. The WTO will examine the matter, which could take several years to resolve, as Australia and China engage in a long-standing trade dispute.

site_title: 8 lessons from owning a 193-year-old Singapore company for 15 years
summary: A 193-year-old Singapore conglomerate, Boustead Singapore Limited, has survived and thrived under CEO FF Wong's leadership for 15 years. The company has demonstrated resilience through various business ventures, including its geospatial division, which has seen significant revenue growth, and its healthcare division, which has reported steady revenue despite the pandemic. Boustead Singapore has also successfully disposed of underperforming divisions and established a private fund, generating significant returns. The company's consistent dividend payments and prudent management have made it a dependable investment choice, with a track record of 17 consecutive years of dividend payments.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Industrial Trust, Koh Brothers Eco, FCT, ESR-Reit
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 11.9% growth in Q2 FY21/22 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.00347. Koh Brothers Eco Engineering secured a S$200.7 million contract from the Public Utilities Board. Shares of MIT closed 0.4% lower at S$2.73, while Koh Brothers Eco shares were halted before trading.

site_title: Oil benchmarks settle at highest since 2014 on short supply
summary: Oil benchmarks reached their highest levels since 2014 due to a global supply shortage and strong US demand. Brent futures rose 41 cents to $86.40 a barrel and WTI crude rose 89 cents to $84.65. Analysts expect US oil inventory data to show a 1.9 million-barrel build, supporting the price rally. Opec+ is raising production, but analysts expect prices to remain high due to lagging supply and strong demand. Goldman Sachs predicts Brent will reach $90 a barrel, while BlackRock expects oil to reach $100.

site_title: Eradicating coal: One step forward, two steps back
summary: The global energy crisis has led to a resurgence of coal usage, despite efforts to reduce carbon emissions. The current energy crunch, driven by supply chain issues and increased demand, has prompted nations to turn to coal as a means of meeting their energy needs. The rapid growth of renewable energy sources, particularly solar and wind power, has been hindered by geographical and financial constraints. As a result, coal-fired power plants continue to be built, particularly in developing countries, and China's own domestic network of coal-fired power plants is expanding. The lack of investment in coal mining and the resulting supply shortages have exacerbated the crisis, with prices soaring and power outages becoming a concern.

site_title: Tikehau Capital submits application to SGX for S$200m SPAC IPO
summary: European asset manager Tikehau Capital, in partnership with Financiere Agache, has submitted an application to list a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to raise S$200 million. The SPAC, Pegasus Asia, will focus on technology-enabled new economy sectors with operations in Asia-Pacific. This is likely one of the first SPAC listings in Singapore, which could provide a boost to the local capital markets. Other players, including private equity firms and local private companies, have also expressed interest in the SPAC framework.

site_title: Nintendo hopes smartphones will be fertile soil for Pikmin Bloom
summary: Nintendo has partnered with Niantic to release Pikmin Bloom, a new smartphone game that marks a rare collaboration between the two companies. The game, launched in Australia and Singapore, involves walking to cultivate animated plant-like characters using smartphone cameras and augmented reality features. Pikmin Bloom aims to make daily walks more enjoyable and is designed to be a free game, following the success of Niantic's Pokémon Go. The partnership reflects Nintendo's ongoing collaboration with Niantic and seeks to replicate the success of Pokémon Go with a new title.

images.alt_text: Pokemon Go maker Niantic on Tuesday began rolling out a Pikmin Bloom smartphone game in its latest collaboration with Japanese video game icon Nintendo.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher on Tuesday
summary: European stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by strong earnings from mostly companies and a rebound in US consumer confidence and new home sales. The Dow and S&P 500 in the US finished at fresh all-time highs, while the euro hit a 20-month low against the British pound. The European Central Bank's upcoming policy meeting on Thursday is expected to influence monetary policy, with traders anticipating possible interest rate hikes. Despite inflation concerns, most companies have outperformed, and investors are focusing on surging demand as a driver for earnings growth.

site_title: UK retailers warn of pre-Christmas price rises
summary: UK retailers warn of pre-Christmas price rises, citing smallest year-on-year decline in average selling prices since before the pandemic. Shop prices rose 0.4% in October, driven by higher food costs. Three in five retailers plan to raise prices before Christmas, with rising costs from labor shortages, supply chain issues, and commodity prices. This could lead to a shift away from discretionary spending, according to market research company NielsenIQ.

images.alt_text: British retailers warned on Wednesday of pre-Christmas price rises after they reported the smallest year-on-year decline in the average selling price of goods in their stores since before the start of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Gender-lens investing: Asset managers and women in leadership
summary: The CFA Society Singapore has highlighted the growth of gender-lens investing, with 27 global and regional equity funds available to individual investors, totaling US$3.47 billion in assets under management (AUM) as of June 30, 2021. This represents a 32% growth rate in the first half of 2021. Meanwhile, progress for women in corporate leadership remains slow, with the US Securities and Exchange Commission approving Nasdaq's board diversity rule, and global asset managers having varying levels of stewardship policies and statements to support growth in corporate women-in-leadership.

site_title: Maximising opportunities from the pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought both challenges and opportunities for businesses, prompting finance leaders to seize long-term growth prospects. Companies like Marriott Vacations Worldwide, Singapore Exchange, and SATS have leveraged innovation and digital solutions to navigate the crisis. Marriott adopted virtual tours and digital contracting, while Singapore Exchange issued convertible bonds to diversify funding sources. SATS implemented a new ERP system and invested in staff redeployment and reskilling. These transformations aim to drive growth, improve efficiency, and enhance sustainability in the post-pandemic landscape.

site_title: US Treasury distributed nearly US$2.8b in rental aid in September
summary: The US Treasury distributed nearly $2.8 billion in rental aid in September, bringing the year-to-date total to $10.3 billion. About 510,000 households received aid to pay rent, utilities, and arrears, up from 459,000 in August. The program, which aims to prevent evictions, is still behind pace, but officials say it's on track for 3.5 million payments for 2021. Regional differences in disbursement remain a concern, with some cities and states performing well, while others lag.

site_title: Facebook invests billions in metaverse efforts as ad business slows
summary: Facebook has invested billions in its metaverse efforts, with a focus on augmented and virtual reality labs, as its ad business slows. The company reported a 17% profit increase in Q3 but warned of uncertainty due to Apple's new privacy changes. Facebook Reality Labs will be reported as a separate unit, with an estimated $10 billion reduction in operating profit in 2021. The company also plans to hire 10,000 employees in Europe to work on the metaverse initiative. Despite this, Facebook's Q3 revenue fell short of expectations, and its shares were up 1% in after-hours trade.

images.alt_text: Facebook CEO Zuckerberg says: "We basically believe that the metaverse is going to be the successor to the mobile Internet."

site_title: Plotting a path to responsible AI is essential
summary: Financial institutions in the Asia-Pacific region are heavily investing in artificial intelligence, with spending forecasted to grow 22.1% annually to $4.9 billion by 2024. However, the lack of explainability around AI algorithms, known as black-box decisioning, creates enormous legal vulnerabilities and business risks. Without a comprehensive understanding of machine learning algorithms, businesses are unable to monitor AI solutions and prevent undetected biases from delivering skewed outcomes. To mitigate these risks, businesses must develop rigorous processes and formal model development governance that spot and remove bias across the model development lifecycle.

site_title: Hong Kong to further tighten Covid-19 travel restrictions
summary: Hong Kong will further tighten its COVID-19 travel restrictions, with most arrivals required to undergo 14-21 days of hotel quarantine. The city's leader, Carrie Lam, announced the move to align with the Chinese mainland's strict restrictions. Quarantine exemptions for certain groups, including diplomats and business leaders, will be canceled, leaving only essential workers, such as cross-border truck drivers, exempt. The decision aims to persuade China's leaders to restore travel with the mainland, with Lam citing the importance of maintaining anti-Covid-19 practices in line with the mainland.

site_title: Wellington launches 4 funds for Singapore retail investors
summary: Wellington Management has launched four funds in Singapore targeting retail investors, marking its first foray into the market. The funds focus on income and growth, with a focus on sustainability. The four core funds include the Wellington Credit Income Fund, Wellington Global Property Income Fund, Wellington Next Generation Equity Fund, and Wellington US Quality Growth Fund. The move aims to provide "under-appreciated and untapped opportunities" to Singapore investors, with plans to expand its Undertakings for the Collective Investment in Transferable Securities (UCITS) range. Wellington Management manages over $1.3 trillion in assets globally.

site_title: Tesla zooms past US$1t market cap on Hertz order
summary: Tesla surpassed $1 trillion in market value after landing its largest-ever order from rental car company Hertz, ordering 100,000 vehicles by the end of 2022. The deal reinforced Tesla's ambitions to top the entire auto industry in sales over the next decade. Tesla shares surged 14.9% to $1,045.02, making it the world's most valuable automaker. The order from Hertz, a major milestone, indicates electric vehicles are no longer a niche product but will dominate the mass car market in the near future, according to Tesla CEO Elon Musk.

site_title: Investment outlook for China amid tightening policies
summary: Chinese assets are trading at an attractive valuation, rewarding patient investors amid tightening policies. The country's economy has slowed, with regulators increasing scrutiny in the consumer Internet sector and implementing cybersecurity regulations. Measures to restrict online game access for minors and reforms in the after-school tuition sector have also been introduced under President Xi Jinping's "common prosperity" slogan. Despite challenges, China remains a rising superpower with opportunities for investors.

site_title: Biden has a chance to pick a new kind of Fed chair
summary: President Joe Biden will soon have the opportunity to appoint two new members to the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors and renew or replace the chair and vice-chair. This move could allow him to reshape the Fed's approach to regulating the economy and appoint officials who are not beholden to special interests. Traditionally, ideal governors are impartial and skilled in high finance, but Biden's appointments could bring a fresh perspective to the Fed's leadership, potentially changing the way the national and global economies are safeguarded.

site_title: Aramco warns of rapid fall in world's spare oil supplies
summary: Saudi Aramco's CEO Amin Nasser warns of a rapid decline in the world's spare oil supplies, citing a shrinking supply deficit. He forecasts that the situation could worsen next year if the pandemic eases and air travel increases, depleting remaining spare capacity. The company is investing billions to raise its daily capacity from 12 to 13 million barrels, but its forecasts differ from those of some Wall Street banks and OPEC+ members.

site_title: Chinese developer Modern Land misses payment on dollar bond as spotlight shifts again to Evergrande
summary: Chinese developer Modern Land missed a US$250 million dollar bond payment, marking another sign of stress in the indebted real estate sector. This comes ahead of a test for China Evergrande Group on an overdue coupon and amid a broader clampdown on excessive leverage. Economists have lowered growth forecasts for China due to power shortages and a worsening property market downturn, while experts suggest Evergrande's crisis will be resolved according to market principles. Defaults by Chinese borrowers have reached a record US$8.7 billion this year, with the real estate industry accounting for one-third of that amount.

site_title: Dollar lacks momentum ahead of central bank meetings
summary: The US dollar struggled to gain momentum ahead of central bank meetings this week and next, with most major currency pairs remaining unchanged. The Bank of Canada, Bank of Japan, and European Central Bank meetings are set to take place, with the US Federal Reserve meeting next week. The dollar index held steady at 93.724, down 0.1% due to improved risk appetite and a flattening US yield curve. The Canadian dollar is expected to raise its inflation forecast, while the Australian dollar rose 0.3% and the New Zealand dollar 0.4% ahead of their meetings.

site_title: ST Telemedia is well placed to snap up telco network assets that are up for sale
summary: ST Telemedia, a Keppeled-owned telco and technology investor, is well-positioned to acquire telco network assets from Singtel and StarHub as the local telcos consider monetizing their infrastructure. Following M1's deal with Keppel DC Reit (KDC) to offload assets, ST Telemedia's ability to manage telco infrastructure and its existing relationship with StarHub make it a natural buyer. The trend of telco asset sales is expected to continue, with infrastructure funds or Reits being potential buyers, and ST Telemedia should be viewed as a serious contender for action on the local telco asset scene.

site_title: After 24 years, conductor Antonio Pappano returns to the Met Opera
summary: Conductor Antonio Pappano returns to the Met Opera after 24 years, leading Richard Wagner's Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg from Oct 26 through Nov 14. This marks Pappano's first appearance at the Met since his 1997 debut with Eugene Onegin. Pappano, 61, will leave his positions at Covent Garden and Rome in 2024 to become the chief conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra at the Barbican Centre, replacing Simon Rattle. This appointment reunites Pappano with an orchestra he has worked with for decades, bringing a welcome return to the Met Opera stage.

site_title: Climate change and human activity threaten Libya's Ashaafean nature reserve
summary: A nature reserve in Libya's Nafusa mountain range, Ashaafean, is threatened by climate change and human activity. The reserve, added to the UN's biosphere reserve list, is home to rare birds, plants, and the houbara bustard. Ongoing climate change and drought have led to repeated fires in recent years, making the reserve vulnerable. Libyan Wildlife Trust officials warn of the reserve's decline due to these factors, highlighting the need for conservation efforts to protect this unique ecosystem. The reserve's future remains uncertain, emphasizing the urgent need for climate action and conservation measures.

site_title: Why insurers are delving deeper into real estate as low interest rates linger
summary: Insurance firms are investing heavily in real estate due to persistently low interest rates, seeking stable returns. Companies like Ping An and Samsung Life have made significant investments, with Ping An buying stakes in six Chinese developments and Samsung Life acquiring a stake in Savills Investment Management. Insurers are targeting higher yields or returns, with 32-40% of executives expecting to increase allocations to commercial real estate equity or debt in the next 12-24 months. The trend is expected to continue, driven by insurers' need for long-term assets to match their liabilities, and the ability to borrow cheaply in a low-interest rate environment.

site_title: Singapore will donate S$7.9m of medical supplies to Asean stockpile
summary: Singapore has pledged S$7.9 million to support a regional reserve of medical supplies, ramping up cold chain logistics services and expanding vaccine manufacturing capabilities. The country is also contributing to the Covid-19 Vaccine Global Access (Covax) facility and will donate to other member states. Singapore is also urging its regional counterparts to ratify the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and calls for the progressive reopening of economies as the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Hong Kong rejects plea from global banks to scrap zero-Covid
summary: Hong Kong's government has reaffirmed its "zero infection" strategy for Covid-19, rejecting a plea from global banks to ease its strict quarantine policy. The city's top priority remains reopening travel to the Chinese mainland, citing concerns from other areas that have relaxed their strategies have seen increased infections and hospitalizations. Despite international pressure, Hong Kong's strict measures have kept local infections low, with the economy showing encouraging signs of recovery. The government will continue to maintain stringent anti-epidemic measures, despite warnings from the Asia Securities Industry & Financial Markets Association that the hardline approach is putting Hong Kong's status at risk.

site_title: China's property tax could lower interest rates, says economist
summary: China's planned property tax could lead to a long-term decline in interest rates as construction of new homes peaks and reduces support to credit creation, according to Hongta Securities Co. The real estate sector has driven credit creation, fueled urbanization, and created debt pressure. A property tax would reduce demand for new houses and shift focus to renewing old districts. China has announced plans to expand property tax reform trials to more areas, starting in the next 5 years, as part of a new growth model less dependent on debt.

site_title: China's IPO flops raise red flag over pricing of new shares
summary: China's initial public offerings (IPOs) are experiencing a downturn, with four companies seeing their shares drop below the offer price. Wayz Intelligent Manufacturing Technology, Cofoe Medical Technology, Sinocat Environmental Technology, and another unnamed company plummeted 13%, 4.4%, 6.9%, and below their IPO prices, respectively. This trend raises concerns about the pricing of new shares in the Chinese IPO market, potentially signaling a riskier market.

site_title: Dutch pension fund ABP to sell 15b euros of fossil fuel assets
summary: Dutch pension fund ABP plans to sell 15 billion euros of investments in fossil fuel producers by 2023, citing concerns over global warming. The decision marks a major shift for the fund, which had previously stated that exiting fossil fuel investments was not a solution. ABP aims to increase investment in renewable energy and engage with large consumers of fossil fuels to encourage sustainability. The move comes ahead of the COP26 United Nations climate conference and is part of a broader trend among asset managers to prioritize emissions and the energy transition.

site_title: Singapore to welcome vaccinated travellers from Australia, Switzerland from Nov 8
summary: Singapore will welcome vaccinated travellers from Australia and Switzerland starting Nov 8, with no quarantine requirement. The move is part of the country's "calibrated" steps to reopen its borders, with the current VTL quota increasing from 3,000 to 4,000 daily arrivals. Fully-vaccinated travellers from these countries can enter Singapore with a Covid-19 PCR test upon arrival.

site_title: Razer launches regional headquarters in Singapore, plans to grow local staff count to 1,000
summary: Razer has launched a regional headquarters in Singapore, marking a significant expansion into the South-east Asia market. The company plans to grow its local staff count to 1,000 employees, up from 600, with the new headquarters featuring 180,000 square feet of net lettable area and eco-friendly features. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of intellectual property and innovation in driving economic growth, as Razer continues to invest in research and development, holding over 1,200 patents and 550 design applications.

site_title: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong further sells stake in Raffles Education; now owns less than 1%
summary: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong has further sold his stake in Raffles Education, cutting his ownership to less than 1% amid ongoing disputes with the company's founder and CEO, Chew Hua Seng. Oei had previously sold down his stake from 10.16% to 7.34% in October, causing the shares to hit a 52-week low. The disputes revolve around corporate governance, salaries, and related-party transactions. Several directors are now under investigation over the firm's delayed disclosure of a lawsuit against Raffles Education's Malaysian units.

site_title: UBS joins Wall Street rivals with Q3 profit surge
summary: UBS Group, a Zurich-based bank, reported a surprise jump in profit in Q3, exceeding expectations on key metrics. Investment banking pre-tax profit was nearly double analysts' predictions, while wealth management fees surged 23% due to client activity. The bank also saw a significant increase in recurring fee income and net new fee-generating assets, reaching almost $19 billion. This follows Wall Street rivals in seizing on the deal boom, marking a notable shift in the banking sector.

site_title: US consumer confidence rebounds; spending plans rise strongly
