summary: The Virginia gubernatorial election is expected to be a close contest, with former Governor Terry McAuliffe running as the Democratic candidate and business executive Glenn Youngkin running as the Republican. The election has become a referendum on the Biden presidency, with voters in the state expressing growing discontent with President Biden's policies. The Democratic Party is facing internal divisions, with a growing progressive wing pushing for more left-leaning policies, while centrist Democrats and some Republicans are seeking a more moderate agenda. The election outcome could impact the nation's political map ahead of the 2022 mid-term elections.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: Alset International, a CATALIST-listed property investment and development company, announced the successful acquisition of 19.5 acres of land in Houston, Texas, to develop an eco-friendly home community called Alset Villas. The project aims to build 70 eco-friendly homes with clean energy ecosystems, promoting electric vehicle usage. The acquisition is expected to have minimal impact on the company's financial statements. This project strengthens Alset International's single-family home portfolio and showcases its commitment to sustainable development.

site_title: South Korea plots course to scrapping Covid-19 curbs by early 2022
summary: South Korea has unveiled a three-phase plan to lift COVID-19 curbs by February 2022. The first phase, starting next Monday, will drop operating-hour curbs on restaurants and businesses, with some restrictions on gatherings and mask mandates. The country has been successful in managing the pandemic through intensive testing, tracing, and vaccination efforts. With over 70% of its population vaccinated, South Korea aims to return to normalcy, with all distancing curbs scrapped except for mask mandates, by the end of February.

site_title: Greenhouse gas levels reach new record high: UN
summary: The United Nations reported that greenhouse gas levels reached a record high in 2021, surpassing the yearly average between 2011 and 2020. The World Meteorological Organization attributed the increase to continued rising emissions, despite a temporary decline during the COVID-19 pandemic. If emissions continue, global temperatures will rise, exceeding the Paris Agreement targets of 1.5 to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The UN Climate Change Conference COP26 is being held in Glasgow, with WMO chief Petteri Taalas warning that the world is "way off track" in meeting mitigation goals.

site_title: Towngas China raises US$360m from Affinity in smart-energy push
summary: Towngas China Company Ltd has secured US$360m from Affinity Equity Partners to support its transition into an integrated clean-energy provider. The Hong Kong-listed firm plans to issue new shares and convertible bonds to raise HK$2.8 billion, with part of the proceeds allocated to its "smart-energy" business, including renewable energy generation and carbon management services. This investment aligns with China's pledge to peak greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and become "carbon neutral" by 2060, requiring approximately 140 trillion yuan in green investment over 40 years.

site_title: Tesla Model 3 is the first electric car to top European sales
summary: Tesla's Model 3 became the first electric car to top European sales in September, outselling rival models with gasoline engines. The US automaker's most affordable vehicle beat out cars like Renault's Clio and Volkswagen's Golf, with 24,591 units shipped to customers. This milestone marks a significant shift in the automotive industry's pivot towards electric vehicles, despite a grim backdrop of declining European auto sales due to the global semiconductor shortage.

site_title: Lendlease announces board changes effective Oct 26
summary: Lendlease announced changes to its board composition effective October 26. Tony Lombardo will resign as non-independent, non-executive director and cease to be a member of the audit and risk committee, following his appointment as global CEO in June. Justin Gabbani, previously Asia CFO, was appointed as group Asia CEO and will join the board as a non-independent, non-executive director and audit and risk committee member, replacing Lombardo. The Reit's share price fell 0.6% on the announcement.

site_title: Moderna says Covid shot for younger kids shows strong results
summary: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine showed a strong immune response in children aged 6-12 in a late-stage clinical trial. An interim analysis found protective antibody responses after two 50 microgram doses spaced 28 days apart. The company plans to submit data to the FDA and other regulators, aiming to vaccinate younger children before the holiday season. The trial data also showed a favorable safety profile, consistent with earlier results in adults and adolescents. This follows Pfizer's mRNA vaccine clearance for adolescents in May, and Moderna is expected to submit for clearance in this age group soon.

images.alt_text: Health officials are aiming to get immunisations to younger children before the holiday season, when travel and indoor activity can bring an increased risk of infection.

site_title: Standard Chartered appoints Vinay Gandhi in regional private banking roles
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed Vinay Gandhi as regional head of Asean and global head of global South Asian community for its private banking segment. Gandhi, with 30 years of international experience, joins from Bank J Safra Sarasin in the first quarter of 2022. Gandhi's expertise in wealth management and leadership will reportedly aid in growing the bank's business. The appointment is subject to regulatory approval and will see Gandhi based in Singapore, reporting to Raymond Ang, global head of affluent coverage.

site_title: Harvard-trained designer creates China business software unicorn
summary: A Harvard-trained designer, Fan Ling, has turned his content marketing platform Tezign into a China business software unicorn after completing a Series D round led by Temasek Holdings, boosting its valuation to over $1 billion. Tezign connects designers with businesses and manages digital content, aiming to double revenue to $40 million this year and expand to 1,000 large-enterprise clients by 2024. The startup plans to generate 30% of revenue from outside China and venture into markets like Japan, South Korea, and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit Q3 DPU up 4.5 per cent to S$0.02462
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 4.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02462 for its third quarter, driven by contributions from DPU accretive acquisitions and asset enhancement initiatives. Gross revenue rose 2.5% to S$69.3 million, while net property income grew 2.3% to S$63.8 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy reached a record high of 98.1% and its weighted average lease expiry was 7 years.

site_title: Facebook, alarmed by teen usage drop, left investors in the dark
summary: Facebook has lost popularity with teens and young adults, with a 16% year-over-year decline in "time spent" on the platform and a 5% decrease in time spent by young adults. The company's internal documents, obtained by whistleblower Frances Haugen, reveal a decline in new teen sign-ups and an increase in duplicate accounts. Despite this, Facebook's market value is nearly $1 trillion, and the company has been prioritizing profits over user safety and security. Facebook's failure to disclose these issues to investors and advertisers has led to a formal whistleblower complaint with the SEC.

images.alt_text: In March, a group of researchers inside Facebook Inc compiled a report for one of the company's most powerful executives, chief product officer Chris Cox. The paper included a series of charts and data highlighting a troubling trend that seemed to be accelerating: Facebook was losing popularity with teens and young adults.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has advised employers to treat unvaccinated employees as unvaccinated, allowing them to terminate workers who refuse to disclose their Covid-19 vaccination status. The country also saw higher-than-expected inflation in September, with core and headline inflation rates marginally up. Meanwhile, Singapore aims to decarbonize its power sector and has awarded a 2-year trial project to import 100 MW of electricity from Malaysia. Additionally, wealth management platform iFast expects to accelerate growth in Hong Kong, and the government has relaxed dine-in restrictions for the Bloomberg New Economy Forum.

site_title: Singapore shares slip on Monday, amid mixed trading in region; STI down 0.1 %
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% on Monday to close at 3,201.86, amid mixed regional trading. The decline follows a retreat in US technology stocks and renewed Covid-19 outbreaks in China. Locally, HongkongLand was the worst performer on the STI, while CapitaLand Investment was the top gainer, rising 0.9%. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but the Monday decline suggests a defensive start to the week.

site_title: Keppel Offshore & Marine sued for over US$800 million in US over investment loss
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (KOM) is facing a US$819.85 million lawsuit in the US, including punitive damages and pre-judgment interest, over an investment loss. KOM's US counsel believes it has strong defences to the claim. The lawsuit, filed by EIG Energy Fund XIV, was sought in the US District Court for the Southern District of New York. KOM's conglomerate parent, Keppel Corporation BN4, reported the lawsuit in a Singapore Exchange update.

site_title: Hertz said to have ordered 100,000 Teslas in car-rental market shake-up
summary: Hertz Global Holdings Inc has ordered 100,000 Tesla Model 3 sedans, valued at approximately $4.2 billion, in a significant shift towards electrifying its rental-car fleet. The order, equivalent to about 10% of Tesla's annual production, is expected to be delivered over 14 months and will be available for rent at Hertz locations starting in early November. This move signals Hertz's intent to disrupt the industry and capitalize on growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.14 points to 1,587.94. The index saw a volume of 3.877 billion lots worth RM2.462 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 568 to 457, indicating a negative trend in the market.

site_title: Truth Warriors website puts up correction notices after Pofma direction over Covid-19 claims
summary: A Singapore local website, Truth Warriors, has published correction notices on its webpage after the Ministry of Health (MOH) instructed the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) Office to issue a correction direction. The website had made false claims about Covid-19 vaccines and ivermectin's effectiveness, which the MOH has debunked. The website has been required to publish correction notices at the top of affected webpages, and criminal investigations will be conducted over the claims. Failure to comply with the correction direction can result in jail time or fines up to S$20,000.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust posts Q2 DPU up 5.7% to S$0.02173; manager eyes 'substantial' acquisitions
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) posted a 5.7% increase in its second-quarter distributable income (DPU) to S$93.4 million, driven by accretive acquisitions and higher occupancy from a logistics park. The trust's DPU rose to 2.173 Singapore cents. The manager expects "substantial" acquisitions this year, with a focus on Japan, Australia, and Korea, and plans to divest smaller logistics properties. MLT's gross revenue and net property income also increased 25.2% and 21.5% year-over-year, respectively.

site_title: Peter Hargreaves builds family office for his US$4b fortune
summary: Peter Hargreaves, worth about $4 billion, is expanding his family office to utilize his growing fortune outside of Hargreaves Lansdown. He has sold £850 million of Hargreaves Lansdown stock since last year and has also invested in private-equity funds. The 75-year-old has plans to consider his family office's investing focus and has not named the firm. Hargreaves Lansdown, co-founded by him in 1981, has reported assets of £136 billion on its platform, an increase of 30% from the previous year.

site_title: YTL PowerSeraya wins Singapore's 2-year trial project to import 100 MW of electricity from Malaysia
summary: YTL PowerSeraya has won Singapore's 2-year trial project to import 100 MW of electricity from Malaysia, beating out major energy players like Tuas Power and Sunseap Group. The project, expected to start in early 2022, aims to diversify Singapore's energy sources and enhance energy security. YTL PowerSeraya will work with its Malaysian parent company to import electricity via existing interconnectors, with the goal of eventually incorporating low-carbon energy sources into Singapore's mix.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi faces another 18 charges; allegedly swindled 2 investors out of S$20 million
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, accused of Singapore's largest investment fraud scheme, faces 69 charges. He allegedly swindled 2 investors out of S$20 million, duping them into investing in fictitious receivables for nickel trading. Ng now reserves the right to ask for his S$4 million bail to be raised. Investigations against Ng are ongoing, with his next court mention set for Dec 20.

site_title: Payments unicorn Nium launches crypto product for financial institutions
summary: Nium, a Temasek-backed payments unicorn, has launched a cryptocurrency product for financial institutions, allowing them to embed digital currency services into their applications. The product, which is available in the US and Asia-Pacific markets, supports 5 cryptocurrencies in the US and plans to expand to 20 currencies across 35 territories next year. Nium takes care of KYC, regulatory, and compliance monitoring, and provides brokerage, custody, and processing services. The company plans to add other crypto services, including stablecoin wallets and crypto payment acceptance, as it eyes a New York initial public offering and expands its presence in North America.

site_title: China to strengthen tax reforms to attain 'common prosperity': Xinhua
summary: China plans to strengthen tax reforms to boost revenue and achieve "common prosperity" by adjusting income distribution. The country aims to create an "olive-shaped" income structure with a large middle class and reduced wealth gap. A property tax is expected to be implemented, which will deter speculative purchases and cool home prices. The tax will also affect well-off homeowners of multiple properties. The move is seen as a significant change to China's real estate policies, with potential effects on investor purchases and developer cash flows.

site_title: Sembcorp to build integrated solar and energy storage systems with Indonesia's PLN Batam and Suryagen
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed an exclusive joint development agreement with Indonesia's PLN Batam and Suryagen to develop a large-scale integrated solar and energy storage project in Indonesia's BBK region, generating approximately 1 GWp of solar power and supporting local communities and Singapore's clean energy needs. The project is expected to create 1,000 direct and indirect jobs and enhance skills of local engineers. This marks another step in Sembcorp's transition towards sustainable solutions, aligning with Singapore's plans to harness regional clean energy sources and import up to 4 GW of electricity by 2035.

site_title: ecoWise shareholders call for yet another EGM to remove deputy CEO, appoint new directors
summary: A group of 14 ecoWise Holdings shareholders, holding 12.5% of the company's shares, have requested a third extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove deputy CEO Cao Shixuan. The previous attempt was blocked by a High Court injunction. The EGM is scheduled for November 26, with the shareholders, including founder and CEO Lee Thiam Seng, seeking Cao's removal. The move follows a publicized tussle between Cao and Lee.

site_title: Volvo pares back size of planned IPO to US$2.3b
summary: Volvo Car Group reduced its initial public offering (IPO) from $2.3 billion to $3.1 billion, citing decreased investor appetite due to a glut of similar IPOs and concerns about valuing its stake in electric sportscar-maker Polestar. The company, owned by China's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co, now plans to sell shares to raise approximately $3.1 billion at a price of 53 kronor per share. Volvo aims to use the funds to expand carmaking capacity and achieve its goal of selling only fully electric vehicles by the end of the decade.

site_title: PayPal says it's currently not pursuing Pinterest deal
summary: PayPal is not pursuing a US$45 billion acquisition of Pinterest, contrary to days of speculation. The companies had discussed a potential deal with Pinterest valued at around US$45 billion. PayPal's decision ends days of market speculation and follows a statement from the company saying it's not pursuing an acquisition. The news boosted PayPal shares, while Pinterest shares dropped. Analysts expressed perplexity over the potential transaction, citing a lack of strategic rationale.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO sees business travel recovering faster than thought
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr expects business air travel to recover faster than initially thought, reaching 90% of pre-pandemic levels in the medium term. Private travel is also seeing a strong recovery, with an "extension of the summer season" as people catch up on flights. Spohr attributes this to a positive trend in business travel, particularly in German, Swiss, Austrian, Belgian, and northern Italian markets, where flights have been added. This optimism contrasts with the global air travel disruptions caused by the pandemic.

site_title: New fund by UOBAM to focus on ESG efforts in Singapore
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has launched the United Smart Sustainable Singapore Bond Fund to invest in Singapore's sustainability efforts. The fund will focus on high-quality green, social and sustainability-linked bonds with strong environmental, social and governance mandates. A majority of the fund will be allocated to bonds in Singapore, with a goal of financing up to S$19 billion of public sector infrastructure projects through green bond issuances. The fund will utilize technology and ESG rating models to track investments and measure their environmental impact.

site_title: Economists raise inflation forecasts after Sep core, headline inflation rates surprise on upside
summary: Singapore's core and headline inflation rates rose marginally in September, surprising economists who had expected them to hold steady. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport, rose to 1.2% from 1.1% in August. Headline inflation, including accommodation and private transport, rose to 2.5% from 2.4%. Economists have revised their inflation forecasts upwards, with Barclays raising its 2021 full-year forecasts to 0.8% for core inflation and 2.1% for headline inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintained its inflation forecasts for 2021 and 2022, but shifted its outlook to expect significant upward pressures.

site_title: PayPal says it is not pursuing acquisition of Pinterest
summary: PayPal has stated that it is not pursuing an acquisition of Pinterest, contradicting reports that the two companies were in talks for a deal worth up to $45 billion. PayPal had reportedly offered $70 per share, mostly in stock, but did not provide further details. The news follows a 11.5% drop in PayPal shares since the talks emerged.

site_title: Gan explains easing of dine-in rules for Bloomberg forum
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong announced that dine-in restrictions for Bloomberg New Economy Forum (NEF) delegates will be eased, allowing groups of up to five to dine together, but not for locals. Delegates must be vaccinated and undergo daily testing. The decision aims to create a safe environment for business networking events, which Gan considers crucial for Singapore's strategic position as a business hub and a vote of confidence in the country's Covid-19 management.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders eye China outbreak, inflation
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as investors monitored a fresh Covid outbreak in China, which could impact the economy. Despite inflation concerns, a healthy earnings report tempered those worries. Tech firms' earnings and forward guidance will be closely followed, with potential interest rate hikes looming. Oil prices surged, and the Turkish lira fell after President Erdogan's comments. Markets in Hong Kong and Shanghai fluctuated, and there are fears of a wider lockdown in China, which could weigh on economic growth.

site_title: The world's most consumed edible oil is facing a supply crunch
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production is expected to hit its weakest point in five years due to a severe labor shortage, with output potentially falling below 18 million tons this year. The shortage, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, has resulted in lower yields and a missed opportunity for peak production. The country's palm oil industry is losing around 20-30% of potential production and will miss out on significant revenue, with the industry in "uncharted waters" due to high prices and price volatility.

site_title: Amnesty to quit Hong Kong, citing fears under security law
summary: Amnesty International is shutting its Hong Kong operations due to fear of "serious reprisals" under China's national security law. The human rights organization cited the law's impact on its ability to work freely, with at least 35 civil society groups closing in the wake of security legislation. The group will shift regional advocacy work to new locations, following other organizations such as the city's largest teachers' union and a decades-old group that ran an annual vigil for the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.

site_title: 'Friends' actor James Michael Tyler dies at 59
summary: Actor James Michael Tyler, best known for playing Gunther on the sitcom "Friends," has died at 59. He passed away at his Los Angeles home after battling prostate cancer, which he was first diagnosed with in 2018. Tyler appeared in over 150 episodes of "Friends" and other roles, including "Scrubs" and "Sabrina the Teenage Witch." A representative described him as a loving husband, actor, musician, and cancer-awareness advocate. Warner Bros. TV mourned the loss of the "beloved actor and integral part of our FRIENDS family."

site_title: White Star Capital raises US$360m for third fund; to open Singapore office
summary: White Star Capital, a technology investment platform, has raised US$360 million for its third fund to support global entrepreneurs. The firm plans to deploy initial investments in 15-20 startups across North America, Europe, and Asia in sectors like AI, digital health, and fintech. This is White Star Capital's third fund, following US$70 million and S$180 million previous funds. The firm has also opened a Singapore office and appointed key staff members. The third fund will invest in emerging technology companies, building on its track record of 10 exits, two IPOs, and backing of unicorns and over US$2 billion in raised capital.

site_title: iFast eyes growth in Hong Kong, targets more licences in bid to scale abroad
summary: iFast Corporation, a wealth management platform, expects to accelerate growth in its Hong Kong business over the medium term, driven by its new ePension division. The company aims to pursue more financial licences and increase the scale and quality of its existing business to build a "truly global business model". Strong growth is anticipated in 2024 and 2025, with the ePension division starting to make contributions from 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close barely moved
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Monday, following last week's gains, amid developments in China's Covid outbreak. The Hang Seng Index rose 5.10 points to 26,132.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw minor gains. Traders continue to monitor China's situation, but the market remains stable.

site_title: Australia: Mining, energy stocks help shares end the day higher
summary: Australian shares closed higher on Monday, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks due to strong commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 7,441, led by a 2.6% rebound in energy stocks. Telstra rose 3% after agreeing to buy Digicel Pacific in a $1.19 billion deal. Energy stocks were boosted by oil prices hitting multi-year highs amid tight global supply and solid fuel demand.

site_title: India's ICICI Bank jumps to record high on robust Q2 profit
summary: ICICI Bank, India's second-largest private sector lender, reached a record high of 867 rupees after reporting a 30% increase in quarterly profit to 55.11 billion rupees. Strong loan growth, driven by a recovering economy and low interest rates, contributed to the profit jump. The bank's net interest margin rose to 4% and its domestic loan portfolio grew 19%. ICICI's asset quality also improved, with gross bad loans declining to 4.82%. The stock is up 42% this year, outperforming the Nifty Bank index.

site_title: Food price hike fuels higher-than-expected September inflation
summary: Singapore's core and headline inflation rates rose marginally in September, exceeding economists' expectations, with core inflation at 1.2% and headline inflation at 2.5%. The rise was driven by higher food inflation, electricity and gas costs, and accommodation inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintained their inflation forecasts for 2021 and 2022 but expect significant upward pressures. They attribute the rise to global inflation, supply-demand mismatches, and bottlenecks in transportation, with core inflation expected to increase in the quarters ahead.

site_title: Australian publisher calls government on Facebook, regulator concerned
summary: A small Australian publisher, The Conversation, is calling on the government to enforce a new law requiring Facebook to negotiate a content deal. The law, implemented in March, mandates deals with Australian outlets to drive traffic and advertising. Despite Facebook's claims of signing deals with over 200 newsrooms, The Conversation and another outlet, SBS, claim to have been unfairly spurned. The government and regulator express concern over Facebook's behavior, with the regulator stating the company's approach is "not in the right spirit."

site_title: ECB charts lonely course through inflation spike
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is under pressure to respond to rising inflation in the eurozone, with prices increasing 3.4% year-on-year in September, a 13-year high. ECB policymakers will meet on Thursday to discuss potential interest rate hikes or changes to the pandemic-era stimulus program. Despite concerns, ECB President Christine Lagarde has stated the bank will not "overreact" to transitory inflation, while other central banks, including the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England, are expected to take action.

site_title: Singapore grants in-principle approval to import 100 MW solar power from Indonesia
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) has granted in-principle approval for a pilot project to import 100 MW of solar power from Indonesia to Singapore. The project, developed by a consortium of companies, will supply renewable energy by installing solar panels at Bulan Island in Indonesia. The project aims to power over 144,000 HDB flats and offset 357,000 tonnes of carbon emissions annually. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to diversify its energy supply and cut emissions, following similar projects with Indonesia, Malaysia, and Laos.

site_title: HSBC Q3 profit up 74%, beats estimates, announces up to US$2b buyback
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 74% increase in Q3 profit to US$5.4 billion, beating market estimates. The bank released US$700 million in cash set aside for pandemic-related bad loans, citing improved economic conditions and better-than-expected loan performance. HSBC also announced a US$2 billion share buyback to return excess capital to shareholders. The results contrast with rivals Citigroup, which is riding a M&A boom, and reflect HSBC's focus on returning capital to shareholders.

site_title: DBS appoints Soh Kian Tiong as chief risk officer
summary: DBS Group has appointed Soh Kian Tiong as its new Chief Risk Officer (CRO), effective November 4, 2021. He replaces Tan Teck Long, who is leaving to return to a customer-facing role after a stint as OCBC's head of global wholesale banking. Soh has over 25 years of experience with DBS, including roles as head of credit risk and head of the Financial Institutions Group. The bank's CEO Piyush Gupta praised Soh's experience and leadership, saying the appointment is a testament to DBS's ability to groom leaders from within.

images.alt_text: DBS Group has named career banker Soh Kian Tiong as its new chief risk officer (CRO) with effect from Nov 4, 2021.

site_title: Bukit Timah, Duke's Road mixed-use sites relaunched for sale with lower S$53.8m guide price
summary: A mixed-use redevelopment site in Singapore's Bukit Timah area has been relaunched for sale with a lower guide price of S$53.8 million, down from S$62.5 million previously. The 16,479 sq ft freehold site, zoned for residential and commercial use, has a land area of 7,727 sq ft and 8,752 sq ft, respectively. The site can be redeveloped into a boutique development with 32 residential units and retail spaces. The tender exercise closes on December 2, and the property is 300 meters away from Botanic Gardens MRT Interchange.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.4% to 7,233.61 points. HSBC's strong earnings and plans to buy back shares contributed to the gains. Investors are now focusing on upcoming events, including the European Central Bank's rate decision and the UK government's budget announcement on Wednesday.

site_title: China will uphold world peace, Xi says on anniversary of return to UN
summary: China's President Xi Jinping vowed to uphold world peace and international rules, calling himself the "builder of world peace" and "protector of international order" on the 50th anniversary of China's return to the UN. China has been increasing its assertiveness globally, sparking concerns from the US and other countries over its claims to disputed territories, including Taiwan and the South China Sea. Xi also urged global cooperation on issues such as regional conflicts, terrorism, and climate change, while opposing hegemony and power politics.

site_title: LNG importer Pavilion working with EMA to ensure market supplied
summary: Singapore-based LNG importer Pavilion Energy is working with the Energy Market Authority (EMA) to ensure the domestic market is well-supplied amid recent gas shortages caused by production issues in Indonesia. Pavilion supplies over a third of Singapore's natural gas needs through piped gas from Indonesia and LNG imports. The company's interim CEO, Alan Heng, confirmed that gas supplies have continued to flow into Singapore, and the company is working closely with EMA and customers to maintain reliable energy for their needs.

site_title: A round-up of Singapore electricity market exits so far
summary: Singapore's largest independent electricity retailer, iSwitch Energy, is exiting retail operations from next month, marking a significant blow to the city-state's liberalization of the power sector. This decision comes amid record wholesale prices. Additionally, other power retailers, including 3C Energy and Powerhouse, have also announced their exit from the market. The news has raised concerns about the impact on competition in the sector.

site_title: No vax, no hire; employers can also terminate unvaccinated workers as last resort
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has issued an advisory stating that employees who refuse to disclose their Covid-19 vaccination status can be treated as unvaccinated. Employers can also terminate workers who do not comply with workforce vaccination measures as a last resort. Companies can require vaccination upfront when hiring new staff and request staff to show vaccination status through various apps and physical cards. For unvaccinated employees, employers may allow remote work or redeployment to suitable jobs, but may place them on no-pay leave or terminate employment as a last resort.

site_title: Evergrande, electric vehicle unit shares jump after chairman signals business shift
summary: Evergrande, China's struggling property developer, shifted its focus towards electric vehicles, with Chairman Hui Ka Yan announcing the business would become its primary focus within 10 years. This move, driven by Beijing's support for electric vehicles, led to a 6-17% surge in Evergrande's shares and its EV unit. The company aims to scale down its massive landbank and reduce liabilities, but it remains unclear how this will affect its asset disposal plan. Evergrande has averted a costly default and is working to address its debt issues, with a next payment deadline looming on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on tech slump
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, October 25, 2021, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.71% or 204.44 points to 28,600.41. The decline was led by tech shares, as investors focused on corporate earnings and Japan's upcoming general election.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday (Oct 25), led by declines in tech shares with investors cautiously focused on corporate earnings and Japan's upcoming general election.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower ahead of election
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.92% and the Topix index dipping 0.59%. The decline was attributed to investors awaiting corporate earnings and Japan's upcoming general election.

site_title: New Zealand reports 2nd-highest daily Covid-19 cases in pandemic
summary: New Zealand reported 109 new locally acquired Covid-19 cases, its 2nd-highest daily infection since the pandemic, primarily in Auckland. The country, once a model for Covid-19 elimination, has switched to living with the virus due to the surge in cases. 71% of eligible New Zealanders are fully vaccinated, with 77% in Auckland. The number of cases has reached 2,681 and 28 deaths have been recorded. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that lockdown measures will only be lifted when 90% of the population is fully vaccinated.

site_title: Hong Kong's zero-Covid policy undermining financial hub status: industry group
summary: Hong Kong's zero-Covid policy is threatening its status as a financial hub, with 48% of financial industry members considering moving staff or functions due to operational challenges. The city's strict travel restrictions and lack of a plan to open up to international travellers are major concerns. Industry group ASIFMA has recommended publishing a roadmap to exit the zero-Covid strategy and prioritizing vaccinations. Hong Kong's financial hub status and long-term economic recovery are at risk, with regional rival Singapore re-opening its borders and prioritizing vaccinations.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher, investors eye key corporate earnings
summary: South Korean shares ended higher on Monday, with the Kospi benchmark closing 0.48% higher at 3,020.54 points. The won strengthened, and bond yields rose ahead of key corporate quarterly results. Tech giant Samsung Electronics fell 0.28%, while SK Hynix rose 1.52%. Meanwhile, the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip Securities initiates Del Monte with 'buy', S$0.60 target price
summary: Phillip Securities has initiated a "buy" call for Del Monte Pacific with a target price of S$0.60, following the US subsidiary Del Monte Foods' profitable FY2021. Analyst Vivian Ye expects further growth opportunities, including higher gross margins, and notes that the company's undervaluation may be justified due to debt levels. Del Monte Pacific has reduced its net debt over the past 5 years, but interest expenses are expected to take another 3 years to fall below US$100 million.

site_title: EMA, JTC launch S$6m open call for clean energy innovations on Jurong Island
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) and Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) have launched an open call for clean energy innovations on Jurong Island, with a joint funding of S$6 million. The initiative aims to accelerate the development of renewable energy, energy storage systems, and low-carbon technologies. The projects will be funded for prototyping and demonstration over the next two years, supporting Singapore's long-term emissions reduction targets and the country's transition to a sustainable energy and chemicals park.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.41% lower on Monday, following a healthy run-up last week, amid concerns over a fresh Covid outbreak in China. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,020.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index shed 0.23% to 3,574.26. Traders are cautious, watching the situation closely.

site_title: Exxon Mobil keen to build carbon storage hubs in South-east Asia, similar to Houston project
summary: ExxonMobil plans to build carbon capture storage (CCS) hubs in South-east Asia, similar to its Houston project, with potential storage sites in Indonesia and Malaysia. The company's president, Joe Blommaert, said 11 companies are discussing plans to capture and store up to 50 million tonnes of CO2 per year by 2030. However, critics argue that CCS will extend the life of dirty fossil fuels, while advocates see it as essential to meet net zero emissions. A transparent carbon price is needed for CCS to attract investment and become economically viable.

site_title: Australia regulator says 'concerned' about Facebook approach to media licensing law
summary: Australia's Competition and Consumer Commission Chair Rod Sims expressed concern over Facebook's approach to media licensing law, seven months after the rule took effect. Under the News Media Bargaining Code, Facebook and Google must negotiate with news outlets for content driving traffic to their websites, or face government intervention. Google is still finalizing deals with news media companies, but its approach seems cooperative, unlike Facebook, which has raised concerns.

site_title: Singapore to continue decarbonising electricity generation with new solutions
summary: Singapore aims to decarbonize its power sector by importing up to 30% of its electricity from low-carbon energy generators overseas by 2035. The city-state plans to import 4 gigawatts of electricity, with a focus on natural gas, solar, and waste-to-energy power generators. Additionally, Singapore will provide grants for power generation companies to adopt energy-efficient technologies and ramp up efforts to harvest solar energy, including the launch of the world's largest floating solar farm.

site_title: UK announces £6b health spending ahead of key budget
summary: The UK government will announce a £6 billion health spending package in the upcoming budget, aiming to tackle pandemic-era backlogs in the National Health Service. The funding will support diagnostic centers, innovative health projects, and coronavirus treatments. The move is seen as a "game-changing investment" to improve patient care, but critics worry about the source of the funding, particularly tax hikes. The package also aims to ease the cost-of-living crisis and support businesses affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Freehold commercial building along Hindoo Road for sale at guide price of S$23.5m
summary: A freehold commercial building at 7 Hindoo Road in Singapore is for sale at an indicative guide price of S$23.5 million, equivalent to S$1,682 per square foot. The four-storey building sits on a 3,519 sq ft land with a total floor area of 13,970 sq ft. The sale will be led by PropNex's senior associate division director Loyalle Chin and will close on Dec 21, 2021.

site_title: Spillover from China's property debt risks is controllable: Xinhua
summary: China's property debt default risks are generally controllable, according to a Xinhua article. The country's financial industry can predict and mitigate the risks of spillover from struggling property companies. China Evergrande Group, which is facing over $300 billion in liabilities, has averted a default and resumed work on projects. The Chinese property sector, worth a quarter of the economy, is experiencing a string of default announcements and rating downgrades, but the government will steadily advance real estate taxation reform to address the issue. Contagion concerns remain, but the risks are controllable.

site_title: Gold flat after last session's retreat from 1-1/2-month high
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,792.95 per ounce on Monday after cutting gains on US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's comments that inflation could ease next year and the central bank may start tapering stimulus. This followed a rally to its highest since early September on Friday.

site_title: Australia looks to roll out Covid-19 booster shots soon as curbs ease
summary: Australian officials plan to roll out Covid-19 booster shots soon as the country shifts from its "Covid-zero" strategy to suppressing the virus through higher vaccinations. With over 87% of adults vaccinated, officials aim to offer booster shots six months after the second dose. The move comes as residents in Sydney and Melbourne enjoy more freedoms after months-long curbs, with Victoria set to ease restrictions on gatherings and movement on Friday. Double-dose vaccination rates in Victoria's adult population are expected to top 80% by then, with NSW nearing 90%.

site_title: Australia: Mining and energy stocks push shares higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, extending a five-session gain, driven by mining stocks and strong oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7462.6 points. Energy stocks led the gains, with Beach Energy and Woodside Petroleum rising 2.9% and 1.7% respectively. Mineral Resources, a lithium and iron ore miner, also gained 7.2%. Tech stocks fell 1.2%, while Telstra Corp gained 1.6% after agreeing to buy Digicel Group's Pacific operations.

site_title: Singtel divests payment card compliance business for US$80m
summary: Singtel divested its payment card compliance business, SecureTrust, to Sysnet Global Solutions for US$80 million. This sale is part of Singtel's strategic review of its digital businesses to optimise resource allocation and reposition assets for growth. The divestment will allow Trustwave to focus on managed threat detection and response, managed security services, and consulting services. The cyber security business in Asia Pacific will become one of the largest, with a revenue of over S$350 million, and certain Trustwave assets will move into Singtel and its subsidiaries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Singtel, SATS, Sembmarine
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw significant developments that may impact their trading on Monday. CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported a 132% increase in Q3 net property income and gross revenue, while Singtel announced the divestment of its payment card industry compliance business for US$80 million. SATS appointed a new CEO, and Sembmarine clarified reports on the Johan Castberg vessel project. iFast reported a 23.3% increase in Q3 profit, and ComfortDelGro's Australian unit forecast profitability. Trading was halted for Koh Brothers Eco Engineering pending an announcement. Shares of these companies fluctuated on Monday, with some rising and others falling.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% on Monday, opening at 3,201.94. Trading was evenly matched, with 71 gainers and 71 losers. Notable movers included ComfortDelGro, which gained 0.6%, and Hatten Land, which fell 2.9%. In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record, while European stocks rose on technology stocks and strong earnings. Asian markets, including Tokyo, fell due to corporate earnings and election uncertainty.

site_title: Tesla postpones release of new autonomous driving software
summary: Tesla has postponed the release of its new autonomous driving software, FSB 10.3, due to issues found during final tests with the beta version. CEO Elon Musk announced the delay in a Twitter post, stating that the company will roll back to version 10.2 temporarily while working to fix the issues. The release had been announced for October 22, with a possible one-day delay previously mentioned. There is no new release date announced at this time.

site_title: UK's Sunak to raise minimum wage and public sector pay: Sun
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak plans to raise the minimum wage to £9.45 per hour and unfreeze public sector pay in his upcoming budget. This move aims to address rising inflation and economic concerns. The decision comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, dealing a blow to opposition leader Keir Starmer's chances.

site_title: Japan's Kishida suffers by-election setback before national vote
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's ruling party suffered a setback in a by-election, losing one seat in the upper house. Opposition-backed Shinnosuke Yamazaki won the election in Shizuoka prefecture, while the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) won the other seat in Yamaguchi prefecture. The LDP's loss is a test of Kishida's support ahead of a national general election on October 31, where he aims to win over voters with economic and social pledges. The outcome may impact Kishida's young government and its chances of survival.

site_title: EMA and Envision ink S$4m partnership to grow local green-tech expertise
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has partnered with green-tech solutions provider Envision Digital on a S$4 million deal to develop local expertise in green technology solutions. The partnership aims to support Singapore's net-zero carbon emissions ambitions by focusing on renewable energy, urban energy efficiency, and low-carbon solutions. Selected companies will receive mentorship, research and development funding, and the opportunity to onboard their solutions on Envision Digital's operating system to expand internationally. The partnership is supported by Enterprise Singapore's "Open Innovation" initiative.

images.alt_text: The partnership will focus on developing local companies' capabilities in renewable energy, urban energy efficiency and low-carbon solutions in support of Singapore's net-zero carbon emissions ambitions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 2.12 points or 0.13% to 1,590.20. Trading volume was 264.75 million lots worth RM138.75 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 208 to 203.

site_title: Yellen expects high inflation through mid-2022 before easing
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expects high inflation to persist through mid-2022 before easing, citing temporary pain from supply bottlenecks and a tight labor market. She rejected criticism that the US risks losing control of inflation, stating it will end as the economy returns to normal. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has also expressed concern over persistently high inflation, but remains patient on raising interest rates. Yellen emphasized the need to raise the US debt ceiling, calling it a "housekeeping matter" to pay the government's bills.

site_title: Manoeuvre with greater agility
summary: Global supply chain disruptions continue to worsen, with many industries severely impacted. Experts stress the need for organisations to build a more nimble and resilient supply chain, leveraging technology, data, and cross-functional teams to identify potential bottlenecks. Key lessons include the importance of real-time data, supplier redundancy, and digitalisation to mitigate risks and disruptions. Businesses must adapt to the "new normal" by investing in technology, simplifying supply chains, and prioritising resilience and agility.

site_title: Pelosi says 'we're almost there' on huge US legislative bills
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi expressed optimism on Sunday that a huge social spending package and a cross-party infrastructure bill will be agreed upon and voted on this week, saying "we're almost there." The agreement comes after months of fierce political wrangling, with President Joe Biden aiming to secure passage before his departure for a climate summit in Glasgow. Pelosi mentioned that 90% of the bill has been agreed to, with the remaining decisions to be made, and that the package is larger than previous efforts to address American family needs.

site_title: Oil-reliant Saudi Arabia faces questions over 'net zero' pledge
summary: Saudi Arabia's pledge to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2060 is under scrutiny, with experts questioning the plan's seriousness amid plans to increase oil production. The country aims to raise its oil production capacity from 12 to 13 million barrels a day by 2027. Critics argue that the pledge is a strategic move to alleviate pressure ahead of the COP26 climate summit. To achieve net zero, Saudi Arabia must focus on energy efficiency and decarbonizing the power sector, according to experts.

site_title: Grab partners APSN to provide opportunities to students
summary: Grab Singapore and APSN signed a two-year Memorandum of Understanding to prepare students with mild intellectual disability for employment in the F&B and retail sectors. The partnership will integrate Grab's food delivery services into APSN's training curriculum and provide work attachments and employment opportunities. The goal is to promote inclusive employment practices and benefit around 400 special needs students. The partnership aims to unlock students' potential and contribute to the digital economy.

site_title: Citi becomes first Wall Street bank to agree to racial audit
summary: Citigroup has become the first Wall Street bank to agree to a racial audit, conducted by Covington & Burling, to assess its business practices and contributions to racial discrimination. The audit aims to address the persistent racial wealth gap in the US, where white families have a significantly higher average net worth than Black families. The move follows similar efforts by BlackRock and comes after a year of racial injustice protests and President Joe Biden's executive order to advance equality.

site_title: Hong Kong banks to disclose related property of clients who breach security law
summary: Hong Kong banks are advised to disclose related property of clients who breach the city's national security law, according to guidelines from the Hong Kong Association of Banks. The move follows China's imposition of national security legislation in Hong Kong last year, making certain activities punishable by up to life in prison. The guidelines, which were updated on October 22, advise banks to report and disclose related property when clients are arrested or charged with a national security offence, or when they have knowledge or suspicion of such property.

site_title: South-east Asia's young startup alumni are changing the face of investments
summary: South-east Asia's young startup alumni are increasingly investing in angel investments, a previously exclusive asset class. Many have benefited from payouts after their companies were acquired or went public. Angel investors, often in their 20s and 30s, are backing people they know, pooling their cash to invest in smaller cheque sizes. Formalized networks are lowering barriers to angel investing, with over 50 angel investors joining a pre-seed round of Rocket Academy in August. Young angel investors value their industry connections and sharp advice over financial firepower, and some are even becoming venture capitalists or investors in funds.

site_title: Telstra to buy Digicel Pacific in Australia government-backed US$1.6b deal
summary: Telstra Corp agreed to buy Digicel Pacific's operations in a US$1.6 billion deal, largely funded by the Australian government. The deal aims to block China's rising influence in the region and support the development of secure infrastructure in the Pacific. The Australian government will provide US$1.33 billion, with Telstra contributing the remaining US$250 million. The transaction, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to take up to six months to complete. Telstra will fully own and operate Digicel's Pacific operations, including in Papua New Guinea, Fiji, Samoa, and Vanuatu.

site_title: Eleven Picasso artworks in Las Vegas fetch more than US$100 million
summary: Eleven Picasso artworks were sold at a Sotheby's auction in Las Vegas for over $100 million. The auction took place at the Bellagio hotel, where the works had been on display, two days before Picasso's 140th birthday. The highest price was fetched by a 1938 painting of Marie-Therese Walter, sold for $40.5 million. The sale is part of MGM Resorts' effort to diversify its art collection, which now boasts 900 works by 200 artists, including pieces by Bob Dylan and David Hockney.

site_title: Auditor issues disclaimer for Singapore Kitchen Equipment's FY2020 report
summary: Accounting firm BDO issued a disclaimer of opinion in its audit report on Singapore Kitchen Equipment's FY2020 financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence, primarily linked to 8 flagged transactions reported to the Minister for Finance. The transactions involved reimbursement of $1.4 million paid by SKE on behalf of its major shareholder, QKE Holdings, between 2018 and 2019. The audit found potential misstatements in revenue, costs, and administrative expenses, and management made adjustments and restatements. BDO was unable to verify the accuracy and completeness of certain transactions and balances.

site_title: Pandemic nudging sustainability into the spotlight
summary: The pandemic has heightened the focus on sustainability, with companies realizing the need to adapt to a new reality. Lawyers, including Dentons Rodyk's Ipshita Chaturvedi, are urging companies to prioritize sustainability and innovation to ensure a resilient future. Despite growing awareness, some companies are reluctant to invest in sustainability due to financial concerns, and mandatory regulations or litigation are needed to drive change. A recent dialogue, themed "Sustainability and innovation for a more resilient future," highlighted the need for businesses to deliver for all stakeholders and avoid environmentally destructive investment patterns.

site_title: Unvaccinated barred from workplaces from Jan 1, 2022; Singapore approves Sinovac use
summary: Singapore will require only fully vaccinated individuals to return to the office from January 1, 2022. Unvaccinated staff can return if they test negative for COVID-19 or have recovered within 270 days. The government has also added China-made Sinovac vaccines to the national vaccination program to encourage higher vaccination rates. Over 84% of the population is fully vaccinated, with around 113,000 unvaccinated employees. The move aims to make workplaces safer and support the economy's reopening.

site_title: Improved operating metrics and DPUs as S-Reits kick off reporting
summary: Five S-Reits, including SPH Reit, AIMS Apac Reit, Ascendas Reit, Sabana Reit, and Suntec Reit, have kicked off the reporting season with improved operating metrics and increased distributions per unit (DPU). These S-Reits reported a cautiously optimistic outlook for the year-end, driven by market recovery in Singapore and Australia, with tenant sales in Australia returning to pre-Covid levels despite a lockdown in July.

site_title: Vietnam eating places reopening cautiously
summary: Vietnam's restaurants in Hanoi have reopened after almost three months of lockdown, but the decision has been met with caution due to concerns about the coronavirus. Many restaurants have closed permanently since the start of the pandemic, with estimates suggesting up to a third have shut down. Proprietors are reopening cautiously, watching the industry and waiting for the situation to return to normal. Low vaccination rates and a lack of manpower are also major challenges, with the food and beverage industry expected to see limited investment in the near future.

site_title: iFast Q3 net profit up 23.3% to S$7.6m; group unveils 5-year plan
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 23.3% rise in group net profit to S$7.6 million for its third quarter ended Sep 30, 2021, with revenue increasing 23.4% to S$55.5 million. The company's assets under administration (AUA) reached a record S$18.38 billion, a 46.1% year-on-year increase. iFast has set a 5-year plan focusing on growth in Hong Kong, licensing, and building a global business model, aiming to reach S$100 billion in group AUA by 2028.

site_title: China's Evergrande resumes work on more than 10 projects
summary: Evergrande Group, China's second-largest property developer, has resumed work on over 10 projects in six cities, including Shenzhen, after a recent bond coupon payment. The company, facing over $300 billion in liabilities, had halted work on some projects due to payment delays and negotiations to resume construction. Resumed projects are at various stages, including interior decoration, while others have recently finished construction. The move aims to boost market confidence, but concerns remain over the company's ability to pay debts and avoid default.

site_title: Dollar pares losses with bond taper signals
summary: The US dollar pared losses on Friday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled a potential reduction in asset purchases and hinted at faster interest rate hikes, citing still-low employment and fading Covid-19 pressures. The dollar index fell 0.10% to 93.64, but investors took profits, and the euro gained 0.09% to US$1.1636. Powell also mentioned the Fed's commitment to tapering its bond purchase program, which is expected to start in November, and may lead to interest rate increases in mid-2022.

site_title: Michael Jordan sneakers sell for nearly US$1.5m, an auction record
summary: A pair of Michael Jordan's game-worn Nike Air Ships from 1984 sold for nearly US$1.5 million at an auction, setting a record price for game-worn footwear. The shoes, worn by Jordan in his rookie season with the Chicago Bulls, predated the iconic Air Jordan line. The sale breaks the previous record held by a pair of Nike Air Jordans that sold for US$615,000 in 2020. The market for rare sports shoes continues to rise, with several recent record-breaking sales.

images.alt_text: A pair of sneakers worn by NBA superstar Michael Jordan early in his career sold for nearly US$1.5 million on Sunday, setting a record price at auction for game-worn footwear, Sotheby's said.

site_title: Before you take the plunge into property . . .
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing uncertainty due to changing demographics and potential government policies. Investing in property can provide a stable rate of return, but it's essential to consider overlooked risks and do your sums carefully. Aspiring homeowners should have a long-term view and understand the different aspects of financing a property, including interest rates and loan terms. Buying a second property incurs additional fees, and investors should assess the ease of renting the property to meet mortgage payments. Alternative options, such as real estate investment trusts (Reits), can provide exposure to residential and commercial properties with lower volatility.

site_title: Focus on transmission risks to unvaccinated and elderly could help justify curbs
summary: Singapore is expanding Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) and community visit programs for migrant workers, despite prolonged social gathering curbs, as evidence suggests low transmission risks. Data from VTLs and community visit schemes shows few cases among participants. However, the public is questioning the relevance of curbs, especially for vaccinated individuals, and wants to know if they effectively protect vulnerable populations, such as the elderly and unvaccinated. The government may consider easing curbs in areas with low risk, but further clarity on transmission risks is needed to justify restrictions.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for October 22, 2021, states that the Capesize market was under pressure across all routes, with the 5TC and BCI showing minimal improvement mid-week before closing on a weaker note on Friday.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong cuts Raffles Education stake; Shi Xu ups position in Nanofilm
summary: Raffles Education Corp. saw its shares plummet 25.6% on Oct 18 after Oei Hong Leong, the second-largest shareholder, sold 38.9 million shares, reducing his stake to 7.3%. The sale was worth S$2.7 million. Authorities have begun investigating disclosure issues. Meanwhile, Nanofilm Technologies' chairman Shi Xu increased his stake to 54.09% after buying 200,000 shares for S$741,580. Metal Component Engineering's chairman Chua Kheng Choon has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to dispose of 20 million shares.

site_title: Ron Sim, Taha Bouqdib to bring TWG Tea, Bacha Coffee under V3 Gourmet Group
summary: Ron Sim, founder of V3 Group, is joining forces with longtime business partner Taha Bouqdib to set up V3 Gourmet Group, investing over US$100 million for growth in the food and beverage sectors. The new venture will house TWG Tea and Bacha Coffee, with Sim as chairman and Bouqdib as CEO. The companies aim to capitalize on the growing affluent population in Asia, focusing on quality of life and affordable luxury. V3 Gourmet plans to expand globally and acquire new brands, with a focus on innovation and sustainability.

site_title: Bollywood stars, Indian celebrities launch NFTs amid global craze
summary: Indian Bollywood stars and cricketers are launching NFTs, digital memorabilia using blockchain technology, to cash in on the growing interest in such assets. Global NFT sales reached $10.7 billion in Q3 2021, an eightfold increase from the previous quarter. Bollywood superstars Amitabh Bachchan and Salman Khan plan to launch NFTs, including autographed posters and digital art reels. While some, like Indian cricketer Dinesh Karthik, have had success, others have yet to receive bids. Celebrity participation is expected to create excitement in the NFT space, potentially garnering more awareness for digital assets.

site_title: ARA Logos minorities may support merger with ESR-Reit, but not because it's a good deal
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust's unitholders have no compelling reason to support the proposed merger with ESR-Reit, as the trust has a market capitalization of nearly S$1.4 billion and is trading at a lower yield and higher premium to book value than ESR-Reit. The proposed merger may actually spur support among unitholders due to the scramble for assets, but the trust's independent pursuit of acquisitions could make the merger less desirable.

site_title: Europe: Evergrande relief, earnings prop up stocks
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% on Friday, logging their third consecutive week of gains, driven by strong earnings from L'Oreal and a surprise interest payment from debt-ridden China Evergrande Group. The Stoxx 600 reached six-week highs, outperforming its European peers, and tech stocks rose 1.5%. Investors appeared to look past a slowdown in euro zone business activity, citing upbeat earnings and comments from CEOs suggesting supply chains are being managed.

site_title: Positive outcome essential at COP26 as planet heats up
summary: World leaders and over 20,000 scientists, diplomats, and activists are gathering in Glasgow for COP26, a UN Climate Change Conference. A positive outcome is crucial, with countries needing to commit to limiting global temperature increases to 1.5°C by 2030 and reducing carbon emissions to zero by 2050. Natural disasters, such as hurricanes and wildfires, have caused $5.2 trillion in losses since 1980, with $1.03 trillion in total losses over the past five years. The conference aims to address the energy crisis, finance green infrastructure, and accelerate the transition to clean energy.

site_title: China widens property tax trials with levy on home owners
summary: China's State Council has approved a plan to expand property-tax reform trials to more areas, starting to tax residential property owners. The five-year plan aims to guide rational property buying and control speculators. China's property market has seen skyrocketing prices since private home ownership was introduced in 1998, with authorities struggling to control speculators. The new plan follows a recent slowdown in the market, with new-home prices falling for the first time in six years and sales plummeting 16.9% in September. The exact details of the plan remain unclear.

images.alt_text: China's State Council Will Expand Property-tax Reform Trials To More Areas And Start Taxing Residential Property Owners, Official News Agency Xinhua Reported.

site_title: Chinese economy risks deeper slowdown than markets realise
summary: China's economy is at risk of a deeper slowdown than expected, with growth potentially falling below 5% this year and 2022, according to Bank of America and Citigroup. The slowdown is attributed to President Xi Jinping's efforts to regulate sectors such as real estate and technology, as well as power shortages and the pandemic. Economists predict a 7.7% growth this year and 4% in 2022, but some warn of a more severe downturn, with a "bearish scenario" involving a 10% drop in property prices and growth of 2.2% in 2022.

site_title: ICICI Bank posts record profit boosted by strong loan growth
summary: ICICI Bank posted a record profit of 55.1 billion rupees in the second quarter, a 30% increase from the same period last year, driven by strong loan growth. The bank's bad loan ratio narrowed to 4.82% and it set aside 27.13 billion rupees in provisions. ICICI Bank's domestic loan portfolio grew by 19% year on year, benefiting from improved consumer demand after a drop in coronavirus cases. The bank's optimism on the Indian economy's growth is reflected in its plans to grow its core operating profit in a calibrated manner.

site_title: Credit robots take over junk bond markets
summary: Credit-trading robots are increasingly taking over the junk bond markets, with Bank of America executing 2.7 times more trading volume through its credit bots in the first half of 2021 than in the first half of 2020. JPMorgan Chase's algorithms now trade thousands of bonds in the US and Europe, and Barclays' algorithms price more than half of quote requests globally. The pandemic has sharpened algorithms, allowing banks to process more trades and focus on larger, more complicated transactions. As the corporate bond market grows, automation is becoming more necessary to respond to increased inquiries.

site_title: JPMorgan's ex-global commodities head joins Millennium
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co's former global commodities head, Jeff Katz, has joined hedge fund Millennium Management as the global head of commodities risk. Katz left JPMorgan in the summer, replacing Kapil Bhatia, who will take over Katz's role. Katz joins a team with over $57 billion in assets under management, and the fund has also expanded its offices in Singapore and Dubai. The move comes as Katz transitions from his role at JPMorgan, where he was previously with Goldman Sachs Group. Details on the move were not immediately commented on by JPMorgan or Millennium.

site_title: Singapore reports 15 more Covid-19 deaths, 3,383 new infections
summary: Singapore reported 15 more Covid-19 deaths, bringing the total to 315, with 8 unvaccinated individuals, 1 partially vaccinated, and 6 vaccinated among the deceased. The country also saw 3,383 new infections, including 2,708 community cases and 667 in migrant worker dormitories. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 172,644, with 17,862 patients in home recovery and 1,738 in hospital. 84% of the population is fully vaccinated, and 85% have received at least one dose.

site_title: iFast's Q3 net profit up 23.3% to S$7.6m, group unveils 5-year plan to further propel growth
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 23.3% increase in group net profit to S$7.6 million in Q3 FY21, driven by a 23.4% rise in revenue to S$55.5 million. Assets under administration (AUA) reached a record S$18.38 billion, up 46.1% year-over-year. The company has set a 5-year plan to grow its business, focusing on increasing scale, accelerating growth in Hong Kong, pursuing more licenses, and building a global business model.

site_title: AUDUSD displays strength amid gains
summary: The AUDUSD currency pair has started in green, extending its third consecutive week of gains, after a 5-month bearish downtrend. Three bullish reversal chart patterns have been identified: a falling wedge, double bottom, and ascending triangle. A confluence of imminent breakouts from these patterns suggests further gains. The Relative Strength Index (RSI) and Moving Average Divergence Convergence (MACD) are also showing bullish bias signals, with the RSI crossing above 50 and the MACD histogram approaching the zero line. A successful weekly close above the neckline at 0.7479 could confirm the breakout and target 0.7746.

site_title: Myanmar says it will cooperate 'as much as possible' with Asean peace plan
summary: Myanmar's military rulers pledged to cooperate "as much as possible" with a peace plan agreed with Asean, despite excluding top commander Min Aung Hlaing from a summit. The five-point consensus plan, backed by the West and China, includes ending hostilities and allowing humanitarian support. Asean foreign ministers sided with the military, excluding Min Aung Hlaing, citing his failure to implement the plan. Myanmar's junta accused Asean of departing from its principles, and a special envoy, Erywan Yusof, was warned not to engage with opposition forces.

site_title: Wealth as a state of mind
summary: ER doctor Jade Kua emphasizes that true success is not measured by wealth, but by leading a fulfilling life filled with meaningful moments with family and opportunities to pursue personal passions. This perspective, shared in a recent interview, highlights the importance of prioritizing personal well-being and happiness over material wealth. Kua's views on success as a state of mind aim to challenge traditional notions of achievement and promote a more balanced approach to life.

site_title: Travellers from Bangladesh, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka to be allowed in Singapore after Oct 26
summary: Singapore will allow travellers from Bangladesh, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka to enter the country after October 26, with the exception of short-term visitors. These six countries will be placed in Category IV, requiring a 10-day stay-home notice (SHN) at dedicated facilities, costing S$1,450 per person. Transit through Singapore remains unrestricted.

site_title: Sembmarine clarifies media reports on Johan Castberg project
summary: Sembmarine has clarified media reports on its Johan Castberg project, stating its scope of work includes constructing the hull and living quarters, while Equinor handles the construction of topside modules and final completion. The company's customer, Equinor, had previously intended to perform these tasks in Norway. Sembmarine's clarification comes after media reports raised concerns about the project's scope and timeline.

site_title: Nutanix chief lays groundwork for profitability amid competitive pressure
summary: Nutanix CEO Rajiv Ramaswami has set ambitious goals for the company to achieve profitability by the end of 2022 and operating profit by 2023. The cloud computing company aims to generate free cash flow by end-2022 and has seen improving underlying profitability, with revenue rising 19% in the fourth quarter. Investors appear to be gaining confidence in Ramaswami's plans, with the stock price up 15% year-to-date. Competition in the market is intensifying, but Ramaswami plans to focus on customer choice and flexibility, with the company expanding its presence in Asia and developing new growth areas such as data governance and data sovereignty.

images.alt_text: Ramaswami sees the industry's renewed focus on data governance and data sovereignty as a big untapped opportunity.

site_title: Malaysia's energy ministry to limit renewable energy exports to Singapore
summary: Malaysia's energy ministry has decided to limit renewable energy exports to Singapore, allowing only non-renewable energy exports to the neighboring country. The decision aims to boost the development of the local renewable energy industry, with plans to increase solar capacity within the national grid system. The ministry also released an additional 300MW of solar quota under the Net Energy Metering program, expected to create 3,600 job opportunities and an estimated RM1.2 billion (S$390 million) in investment value.

site_title: 5-pax dining-out for families to be considered if new cases fall, hospital situation stays stable
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce may consider easing Covid-19 curbs if community cases decrease week on week and hospital situations remain stable. The earliest moves could include allowing 5 members from the same households to dine together and resuming selected group sports and school activities with safeguards. The Stabilisation Phase has been extended to Nov 21, with a focus on monitoring the weekly infection growth rate and hospital occupancy rates. If the infection growth rate falls below 1 and hospital situations remain stable, the taskforce will make calibrated easing in three areas.

site_title: Adobe warns workers to get vaccinated by Dec 8 deadline
summary: Adobe has warned its US workers to get vaccinated against Covid-19 by December 8, as the company seeks to comply with President Joe Biden's order requiring federal contractors to be vaccinated. With 94% of its US workforce already vaccinated, Adobe will consider accommodation requests for employees with medical or religious reasons. This move follows similar warnings from IBM, which has contracts with government agencies and aims to comply with the government's vaccine mandate.

site_title: Epic Games opposes Apple's effort to pause antitrust trial orders
summary: Epic Games opposes Apple's request to pause the antitrust trial orders, arguing that Apple has not met the legal standard for a temporary injunction. US district Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers had previously struck down some of Apple's App Store rules, including a prohibition on developers directing users to alternative payment options. A hearing on Apple's request is set for November 9, with Epic claiming that the public interest favors denying the request and that Apple will not make any changes without an injunction.

images.alt_text: "Fortnite" creator Epic Games on Friday opposed Apple Inc's efforts to put on hold orders handed down in an antitrust trial as a potentially lengthy appeals process plays out.

site_title: WealthBT: How can your investment make a positive difference to climate change? (Ep 7)
summary: WealthBT, a podcast series for affluent individuals, explores how investments can positively impact climate change. Host Genevieve Cua discusses various strategies and investment options, such as sustainable funds and green bonds, that can help mitigate climate change. The episode is sponsored by Prudential and aims to educate listeners on how to make a positive difference through their investments.

site_title: US infrastructure deal close, corporate tax hikes unlikely: Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden said he is close to striking a deal on a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure plan and a $2 trillion social spending plan, despite some issues still under debate. Biden expressed confidence in reaching a deal, but acknowledged that corporate tax hikes are unlikely, instead proposing a separate minimum corporate tax to fund social programs. Negotiations center around four or five key issues, with Biden seeking to balance progressive and moderate demands.

site_title: Singapore gliding towards pre-virus levels of air traffic
summary: Singapore is on track to reach pre-pandemic air traffic levels, with 84% of weekly flights to Europe expected by January, similar to March 2021. The country has seen a significant increase in international flights, with 1,519 flights to Asia, compared to 194 in May 2020. This growth is part of a broader trend in Asia, following North America and Europe in reopening borders.

images.alt_text: Airlines In Asia Are Bringing Back International Capacity As The Region Gradually Follows North America And Europe In Reopening Borders, Led By Singapore, Whose Economy Depends On Open Access.

site_title: BDO issues disclaimer of opinion for Singapore Kitchen Equipment's FY2020 financial statements
summary: Accounting firm BDO has issued a disclaimer of opinion for Singapore Kitchen Equipment's (SKE) FY2020 financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence. The reasons are linked to 8 flagged transactions totaling S$1.4 million, where SKE paid for the transactions on behalf of its major shareholder QKE Holdings in 2019. The matter was reported to the Minister for Finance in August this year. BDO's report states that it cannot provide a basis for an audit opinion on the financial statements.

site_title: US budget deficit falls in 2021 to US$2.8t as economy recovers
summary: The US budget deficit narrowed to $2.8 trillion in the fiscal year ending September 30, 2021, falling $360 billion from the previous year. The economy recovered from the pandemic, with a $600 billion increase in tax revenues. Government outlays increased to $6.8 trillion, partly due to ongoing spending from pandemic aid bills. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen credited the American Rescue Plan stimulus package for the recovery, but warned that the economy remains fragile. The government is working to pass two legislative packages, but faces a looming deadline to increase the federal debt limit to avoid a default.

site_title: Vinyl is selling so well that it's getting hard to sell vinyl
summary: Vinyl records, once considered obsolete, have become the music industry's most popular and highest-grossing physical format. However, the surge in vinyl sales has led to production logjams and delays, causing frustration among artists and labels.
