The pandemic and global supply chain issues have contributed to the shortage, with many pressing machines dating back to the 1970s. Experts cite simple supply and demand as a major factor, with vinyl consumption growing faster than the industry's ability to produce records. As a result, some artists are reconsidering whether vinyl is worth the trouble, while others see it as a legitimate investment and a way to connect with fans.

site_title: New whistleblower accuses Facebook of wrongdoing: report
summary: A former Facebook worker has filed a complaint with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, alleging the platform prioritizes profits over stopping problematic content. The whistleblower claims managers undermined efforts to combat misinformation and other issues, fearing backlash from then-President Donald Trump or angering users who are key to profits. This comes weeks after another whistleblower, Frances Haugen, leaked internal studies showing Facebook's knowledge of potential harm caused by its sites. The complaint adds to Facebook's woes, which have been fueled by criticism over the past month.

site_title: Germany to classify Singapore as 'high-risk area' from Oct 24
summary: Germany will classify Singapore as a 'high-risk area' starting October 24, requiring travelers to complete digital entry registration before entry. Fully vaccinated individuals can enter Germany quarantine-free, while unvaccinated children under 12 must isolate at home for 5 days. This decision affects Singaporeans traveling to Germany, with mandatory digital entry registration and quarantine requirements in place.

images.alt_text: Although fully vaccinated people can still enter Germany quarantine-free, they must complete digital entry registration.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record, capping strong week for stocks
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at a record 35,677.02, marking its first record since mid-August, after a strong week of US stocks. Despite worries about inflation, the Dow gained 0.2% on Friday, while the S&P 500 rose 2.4% for the week. Analysts attribute the gains to solid corporate earnings and companies' ability to pass on price increases to consumers, preserving profit margins.

site_title: Japan to focus on supply chain chokepoints in security push: official
summary: Japan's economic security strategy will focus on two pillars: strategic autonomy and indispensability. The nation aims to reduce its reliance on other countries by investing in areas that are crucial to other countries. The strategy includes addressing supply chain chokepoints, securing sensitive technologies, and promoting domestic production. Japan's government plans to submit a bill promoting economic security next year, with a focus on shifting supply chains to allies or producing goods domestically. The move is part of a broader push to address growing tensions with China and ensure national security.

site_title: J&J loses a round in bankruptcy spat over baby powder suits
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that Johnson & Johnson can't immediately halt lawsuits claiming the company's talc baby powder caused cancer and other health problems in tens of thousands of women. The ruling allows the lawsuits to continue despite J&J's bankruptcy filing of its talc claims unit, LTL Management, which aims to negotiate a trust fund to settle the cases. The judge will consider halting the lawsuits against the parent company, J&J, in a hearing next month.

site_title: Citi becomes first Wall Street bank to agree to racial audit
summary: Citi has become the first Wall Street bank to agree to a racial audit, conducted by Covington & Burling LLP, to examine its business and determine if it contributes to racial discrimination. The audit aims to close the persistent racial wealth gap in the US, where the average net worth of a white family is nearly ten times higher than that of a Black family. The move follows similar initiatives from BlackRock and other companies, and comes after Citigroup investors and regulators urged the bank to conduct the audit.

site_title: Metro Group invests in slew of sectors to ensure resilience
summary: Metro Holdings, a MAINBOARD-listed property investment and development group, has made several investments to ensure resilience in key markets. The company acquired Cherrybrook Village Shopping Centre in Australia for approximately A$132.8 million, and 351 Braddell Road in Singapore for S$121 million. Metro also increased its equity stake in the Australian portfolio to 30% and is managing student accommodation and corporate leases in Jakarta. The investments aim to grow stable and recurring income, with Metro expressing confidence in its partnership with Sim Lian.

site_title: Gold shines dimly despite the spectre of rising yields and an elevated Dollar Index
summary: Gold prices crawled up to reclaim its perch above US$1,800, despite rising Treasury yields and a stronger US dollar, as investors favored rising yields and the dollar. Rising inflation expectations and concerns over China's property sector also support gold prices. Silver prices surged 14.5% in October, driven by supply-side bottlenecks and strong industrial demand. The energy complex, particularly crude oil, also remained elevated, driven by rising demand and supply constraints.

site_title: UK to boost regional transport funds as part of levelling up plan
summary: UK finance minister Rishi Sunak is set to announce a £1.5 billion funding boost for public transport in regional English cities as part of the government's "levelling up" plan to address regional disparities. The funding increase is part of a £5.7 billion transport programme, up from the initial £4.2 billion. The move aims to improve transport links in the North and Midlands, where commuters often face longer wait times compared to those in the capital. The funding will also be extended to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.

images.alt_text: British finance minister Rishi Sunak is set to announce a 1.5 billion-pound (S$2.79 billion) funding boost for public transport in regional English cities as part of Prime Minister Boris Johnson's pledge to "level up"poorer parts of the country.

site_title: Sats appoints food-solutions division chief Kerry Mok as new CEO
summary: Sats appoints Kerry Mok, current chief executive of the food-solutions business, as new CEO, effective December 15. Mok joined Sats in 2018 as chief executive of food solutions, previously holding senior roles at YCH Group and Accenture.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: When busyness in business brings health
summary: Ong Bee Yan, a 65-year-old Singaporean, shares her journey of overcoming a family history of dementia and staying mentally sharp through her entrepreneurial ventures. She credits her busy schedule with keeping her active and engaged, and has become a model and social media influencer, inspiring others to pursue new passions despite age. Her story was documented in a charity e-book and film, "Being Silver," which aims to raise funds for a hospital supporting lower-income elderly patients.

site_title: Vans sneaker maker VF sales stumble on supply hurdles
summary: VF Corp, the owner of Vans, reported quarterly results that missed Wall Street estimates due to supply chain disruptions caused by the Delta variant-driven surge in coronavirus cases in Vietnam and China. The company's revenue from Greater China grew only 9% in the quarter, down from 16% last year, mainly due to lower demand for the Vans brand. VF maintained its revenue and profit outlook for fiscal 2022, but its shares fell 3.3% following the disappointing results.

site_title: Alec Baldwin heart-broken over prop gun accident, problems reported on movie set
summary: Actor Alec Baldwin expressed shock and sadness over the accidental fatal shooting of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins on the set of his Western movie "Rust" in New Mexico. Hutchins, 42, was pronounced dead, and director Joel Souza was wounded. Production on the film was immediately shut down, and an investigation is ongoing. Reports emerged of walk-outs by camera operators over unsafe conditions, including a previous misfire with a prop gun. Baldwin, who is also a co-producer of the film, voluntarily gave a statement about the shooting and expressed his condolences to Hutchins' family.

site_title: Bitcoin's true believers scorn ETFs while welcoming validation
summary: Veteran crypto investors are not planning to buy shares of the new Bitcoin-linked exchange-traded fund (ETF), despite its debut on October 19, which marks a milestone for the asset management industry. The ETF, ProShares Bitcoin Strategy ETF (BITO), attracted $7.68 million in cash from individuals, but retail traders gave it a muted response. Bitcoin's price hit an all-time high the day after the ETF's debut, and experts predict it could reach $100,000 by the end of the year. However, true believers in Bitcoin say they will not invest in the ETF, preferring to buy the actual coins.

site_title: VTL travel: Taking a gamble for rediscovered joys
summary: Singapore's Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) have opened, allowing vaccinated individuals to travel to certain countries, including Germany and South Korea. The VTLs represent a chance for tourism to resume, but associated costs and risks suggest that leisure travel will not return to its pre-pandemic ubiquity. While pre-trip planning and travel processes have become more efficient, Covid-19-related paranoia still lingers, and the risk of getting infected remains a concern. Travelers must weigh the benefits of exploring the world again against the potential risks and logistical challenges.

site_title: Thailand to allow quarantine-free travel from 46 countries including Singapore from Nov 1
summary: Thailand will allow quarantine-free travel from 46 countries, including Singapore, starting November 1, for vaccinated travelers who have tested negative for COVID-19. The move is part of Thailand's "living with COVID" strategy, which aims to gradually relax restrictions and reopen the tourism industry. The country has seen a decline in active cases and an increase in vaccinations, leading to the easing of entry requirements. This is a significant boost to Thailand's economy, which lost $50 billion in tourism revenue last year.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU rises 20.8%
summary: Suntec Reit's Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) rose 20.8% to 2.232 Singapore cents, driven by strong contributions from newly acquired assets in London and Melbourne, as well as lower rent assistance to retail tenants. Distributable income increased 22% to S$63.7 million, and gross revenue rose 16.5% to S$92.7 million. The Reit's balance sheet is expected to be strengthened through active capital management.

site_title: Sembmarine share price dips below S$0.08 offer price; customer to move unfinished vessel out of yard
summary: Sembcorp Marine's share price dropped below the S$0.08 offer price set by Temasek, amid reports of "serious manpower shortages" causing delays on the Johan Castberg vessel project. The project owner, Equinor, will transport unfinished components from Singapore to Norway, and work will be done at another yard in Stord, Norway, instead of Singapore. The contract, worth US$490 million, was secured in 2017 and was set to be completed in Singapore, but the delays and escalating costs have led to the change in plans.

site_title: Evergrande plans to shift main business to new energy vehicles
summary: China Evergrande Group plans to shift its main business to new energy vehicles within 10 years from property development. The company will reduce its property sales to around 200 billion yuan (S$42.2 billion) per year. Currently, Evergrande's property sales reached over 700 billion yuan in 2020. Chairman Hui Ka Yan made the announcement, aiming to overhaul the business and focus on new energy vehicle production.

site_title: Malaysia to examine biscuit makers on cancer claim by Hong Kong group
summary: Malaysia is investigating Hong Kong's consumer watchdog claims that 60 samples of biscuits and crackers, including those produced by Hup Seng Industries, contain cancer-causing substances like glycidol and acrylamide. The Hong Kong Consumer Council found 40% of the products had misleading nutrition labels. Hup Seng Industries, a leading biscuit maker in Malaysia, has fallen 2.7% in share price following the announcement. Malaysia's Food Safety and Quality Division is conducting a verification on the company's premises and citing its existing HACCP and KKM certificates.

site_title: Myanmar rejects Asean decision to exclude junta leader from summit
summary: Myanmar's military government rejected a decision by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to exclude its junta leader from an upcoming summit, citing equal participation rights for Myanmar's heads of state or government. The decision was made despite Asean's earlier statement that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The next Asean summit is set to take place on October 26-28.

site_title: Median price of 5-room HDB resale flats in Queenstown now S$926,000 in record year for market
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore reached a record high in the third quarter, with a median price of S$926,000 for 5-room flats in Queenstown. Prices rose 2.9% from the previous quarter, exceeding the previous peak in 2013 by 0.8%. This marks the steepest three-quarter increase in over a decade, with prices up 9.1% for the first nine months of the year. Resale transactions also rose 19.4% to 8,433 units, while rental approvals decreased 5.1% to 10,417 units.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex gazetted with "refined" incentives from URA
summary: The Golden Mile Complex has been gazetted as a conserved building in Singapore, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) offering "refined" incentives to encourage development. The 16-storey building, completed in 1973, will be the first modern, large-scale strata-title development to be conserved. The incentives include a tax waiver for the conserved floor area and a new tower block of up to 30 stories, with potential extensions to adjacent state land. The move aims to increase development potential and rejuvenate a national icon.

site_title: 14 Singaporeans die from Covid-19 complications; 3,637 new infections
summary: Fourteen Singaporeans, including a 41-year-old man who was immunocompromised and had severe lung disease, have died from Covid-19 complications. The country's death toll now stands at 294. 3,637 new infections were reported, with 3,039 in the community, 592 in migrant worker dormitories, and six imported cases. The majority of infected individuals were above 60 years old. The increase in cases marks the 33rd consecutive day with reported deaths.

site_title: CICT's Q3 net property income more than doubles to S$242.6m, with room for retail recovery
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 2.3-fold increase in Q3 net property income (NPI) to S$242.6 million, driven by its enlarged portfolio from the merger of CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust. The trust's portfolio recorded a 94.4% committed occupancy rate, with retail assets contributing S$136.6 million of the quarter's gross revenue. Despite room for recovery in the retail segment, CICT expects improved economic activity and consumer sentiment to benefit the segment in 2022.

site_title: Capital Group's Jeik Sohn is running to slow time
summary: Capital Group's Jeik Sohn, a 40-year-old executive, credits running for his mindfulness and discipline, mirroring the qualities required for successful long-term investing. To build up stamina, he focuses on small, incremental progress, rather than sprinting and then burning out. Like investing, running requires ignoring external noise and focusing on individual goals. Sohn's experience with running has motivated him to lead a healthy lifestyle for his family, including his two young children, and to prioritize long-term goals over short-term gains.

site_title: China tears up rule book in race to fix its energy crisis
summary: China is taking drastic measures to address its energy crisis, including reversing clean energy goals and increasing coal production to meet power demand. The country is facing a severe power shortage, with rolling blackouts and disruptions to global supply chains. Authorities have ordered coal miners to produce over 12 million tonnes of coal daily, despite President Xi Jinping's commitment to reduce fossil fuel consumption. The measures are expected to ease the crisis but may not be drastic enough, with economists warning of stagflation risks and global growth pressure.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex gazetted for conservation with 'refined' incentives for potential buyers
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has gazetted Golden Mile Complex for conservation in Singapore, offering "refined" incentives for potential buyers. The 16-storey building, completed in 1973, will be the first modern, large-scale strata-title development to be granted conservation status. The incentives include a 30-story tower block, extended site boundary, and a tax incentive to lower development costs. The URA has refined the incentives after owners' feedback, aiming to rejuvenate a national icon and encourage developers to consider the site's potential.

site_title: Japan's prices rise for first time in 18 months on higher energy costs
summary: Japan's inflation rate has risen for the first time in 18 months, with core inflation reaching 1.4%, according to a Bloomberg calculation. The increase is attributed to higher energy costs and mobile-phone fees, which will be temporary. The Bank of Japan's policy path is expected to be influenced by this inflation pulse. Analysts predict that inflation could reach 1.5% in spring next year and potentially 2% if oil prices rise and the yen weakens. This could give the central bank scope to adjust its policy settings, potentially leading to a steepening of the yield curve.

images.alt_text: Japan finally has an inflation pulse and the gains are much stronger than they first appear, a factor that could start to influence speculation over the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy path.

site_title: Sembmarine updates vaccination records of 53% of its workers in Westlite dorm as verification continues
summary: Sembmarine has updated the vaccination records of 53% of its 1,400 workers residing at the Westlite Jalan Tukang Dormitory, with 67% having undergone serology tests. The company continues to provide vaccines, including Sinovac and Sinopharm, for unregistered workers. Following a spike in Covid-19 cases, the company has made improvements to food services and is investigating allegations of foreign objects in the food. Sembmarine has also apologized to its workers and stepped up engagement to explain public health protocols.

site_title: Tottenham's Son flying the Asian flag high in the EPL
summary: Tottenham Hotspur winger Son Heung-Min shared his experiences and insights on life in England, playing under new coach Nuno Espirito Santo, and dealing with pressure and setbacks. The 29-year-old South Korean international, who has made 204 appearances for Spurs, discussed the importance of mental health, his approach to pressure, and the team's philosophy under Santo. He also reflected on his journey from Asia to Europe, where he had to overcome language and cultural barriers. Son emphasized the importance of teamwork, togetherness, and enjoying the game, and expressed his excitement to play in London derbies like the upcoming match against West Ham.

site_title: Wealthy Chinese shift focus from making money to protecting it
summary: China's wealthy elite are shifting focus from accumulating wealth to protecting it amid growing concerns about President Xi Jinping's campaign to redistribute income. With strict capital controls and new rules limiting crypto trading, the rich are seeking alternative ways to move money abroad, such as underground money changers and peer-to-peer transfers. Wealth managers advise clients to diversify holdings, increase international exposure, and consider family trusts and offshore trusts to protect assets. The uncertainty surrounding the government's plans has led to a surge in demand for these services, with some clients paying up to 20% in commissions.

site_title: India's top gas importer sees LNG price surge spurring long-term contracts
summary: India's top gas importer, Petronet, is considering securing long-term LNG contracts with a floor and ceiling price to hedge against extreme volatility, driven by a surge in prices from below $2 to over $56 per million British thermal units (mmBtu) in the last year. The move aims to protect buyers and sellers against price fluctuations, as demand is expected to rise to 15% of India's energy mix by 2030.

site_title: Oil hovers below recent highs; ends week up
summary: Oil prices ended the week up, with Brent crude futures rising 92 US cents to settle at US$85.53 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gaining US$1.26 to settle at US$83.76 a barrel. The week's gain was the seventh in a row, driven by concerns over low supplies and worries about COVID-19 disruptions. However, prices were tempered by concerns from world leaders that the pandemic may not be over, and by a warmer-than-average winter forecast for the US.

images.alt_text: Oil traded just below multi-year highs on Friday with bullish sentiment about low supplies tamped by concerns from world leaders that demand disruptions from the COVID-19 pandemic may not be over.

site_title: Australia: Stocks flat as gains in healthcare temper losses in resources
summary: Australian shares remained steady, closing at 7415.5, after a volatile session with heavy losses in mining and energy sectors offset by gains in healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.02% on Thursday, its fourth consecutive gain, and is up 0.73% this week. Miners fell 1.48% due to plunging iron ore prices and uncertainty over China Evergrande Group's bond defaults. In contrast, export-reliant healthcare stocks lifted the benchmark, driven by a strong US dollar.

site_title: New global rules leave just 10 big EU banks short of capital, draft shows
summary: A draft European Union regulation on new global banking rules shows that only 10 major European banks may need to raise capital, with a shortfall estimated to be less than 27 billion euros, compared to a previous estimate of 52.2 billion euros. The rules, which aim to avoid a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis, set minimum capital requirements between 0.7% and 2.7% by 2015 and 6.4%-8.4% by 2030. The European Parliament will have the final say on approving the rules.

site_title: Pfizer says Covid vaccine 91% effective in kids ages 5 to 11
summary: Pfizer announced a 90.7% efficacy rate for its COVID-19 vaccine in children aged 5-11, based on a trial of 2,250 children. The lower-dose shot raises antibodies against COVID, and safety data showed no new problems. The vaccine's application for emergency authorization is set to be evaluated by an FDA advisory panel on October 26, potentially paving the way for availability by early November.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp Australia (CDG Australia) forecasts a net profit of A$42.1 million in FY2021, a 14.1% year-on-year increase. The company expects a topline of A$672.6 million, with 75 government bus route service contracts generating about A$553 million in revenue. CDG Australia operates over 4,400 vehicles and is pursuing growth through acquisitions and expansion into other modes of transport.

site_title: Australia's central bank tells 'buy now, pay later' firms to drop surcharge ban
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, has told 'buy now, pay later' firms to drop surcharge bans, allowing merchants to pass on fees to customers. The move aims to level the playing field with banks and credit card providers. The decision, following a 2-year review, is opposed by the industry and may impact firms like Afterpay, which relies on high merchant fees to fund its business model.

site_title: Confusion reigns over Queen Elizabeth's health after hospital stay
summary: Queen Elizabeth, 95, spent a night in hospital after undergoing preliminary investigations, contradicting initial claims she was resting at home. The hospital visit was reportedly due to "practical reasons" and was not disclosed to protect her privacy. The Queen returned home to Windsor Castle and was in good spirits. Royal officials have faced criticism for not providing clear information about her health, with some describing the palace's responses as "palace clichés" and "rumours and misinformation."

site_title: Supply chain woes put brakes on Europe's top cycle-makers in Portugal
summary: Europe's leading bicycle manufacturers in Portugal are facing supply chain issues due to a shortage of spare parts linked to Asia. The crisis has impacted production, with companies like InCycles Bike Group, which employs nearly 200 workers, struggling to meet orders through to 2023. Despite the challenges, the sector is expected to continue growing, with Portugal's cycle exports predicted to rise by 30% in 2021, and the European market expected to grow 15% by 2030.

site_title: Malaysia lifts migrant worker ban after 16 months
summary: Malaysia has lifted its 16-month ban on migrant workers, allowing foreign laborers to re-enter the country. The decision was made by the government's pandemic taskforce to meet the needs of vital sectors such as palm oil plantations and rubber glove manufacturing. The country relies on two million documented migrant workers to produce goods, including gloves and iPhone parts. Quotas and entry dates for other industries are still being finalized. The move aims to ease a severe labor crunch and support production in the world's second-largest palm oil producer.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq opens lower after Intel's margin warning
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened lower on Friday after Intel issued a margin warning, while Snap declined due to Apple's impact on digital advertising. The Dow Jones rose 0.01% at the open. The S&P 500 fell 0.08% to 4,546.12, and the Nasdaq dropped 0.38% to 15,158.07.

site_title: Sembmarine share price dips below S$0.08 offer price; customer to move unfinished vessel out of yard
summary: Sembcorp Marine's share price dropped below S$0.08, the offer price set by Temasek, as the company struggles with "serious manpower shortages" due to the pandemic, affecting the Johan Castberg FPSO vessel project. The unfinished components will be transported to Norway, with the turret installation phase now to be carried out at another yard, increasing the scope from 350,000 to 2.5 million man-hours. Temasek's mandatory general offer for Sembmarine is set to close on November 3.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp Australia (CDG Australia) forecasts a net profit of A$42.1 million in FY2021, up 14.1% year-on-year, with revenue of A$672.6 million and contract portfolio of 75 government bus route service contracts. The company expects to become more profitable and pursue growth via acquisitions. It also anticipates opportunities to expand into other modes of transport and tender for new metropolitan bus service contracts. CDG Australia's asset base provides a competitive advantage and defensive earnings base, supporting its growth plans.

site_title: Malaysia to open Langkawi to foreign tourists in bubble plan
summary: Malaysia will reopen Langkawi islands to foreign tourists starting Nov 15, under a three-month pilot international tourism bubble project. Visitors must be fully vaccinated, stay for at least three days, and meet other requirements. The move aims to boost the economy, which contracted in the second quarter of the year. The country has already eased quarantine rules for inoculated visitors and plans to evaluate the Langkawi pilot before applying it to other destinations. Malaysia aims to fully reopen its domestic economy by the end of 2021 and return to pre-pandemic growth next year.

site_title: London Stock Exchange says supply chains to delay tech spend
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group warned that supply chain pressures may delay technology spending this year, citing chip shortages and snarls affecting server-hungry finance firms. The bourse's overall cost and capital expenditure guidance remains unchanged, but income growth is expected to slow in the fourth quarter due to a strong 2020 comparison. The integration of data company Refinitiv is on track, with £125 million in cost synergies expected in 2021.

site_title: STI up nearly 1% over the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 16.64 points or 0.52% to 3,205.14 points on October 22, a 0.98% gain over the week. Analyst Yeap Jun Rong attributes the resilience to investors buying into the endemic economy stance, with regional performance potentially driving the index near its five-month high.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a positive week with gains on Friday, driven by reports that China Evergrande had avoided a default after paying interest on a bond. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.42%, while Evergrande climbed 4.26%. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.34%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.15%. The positive week follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, ahead of GDP data, and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: BTS agency confirms it's leaving Sony for Universal Music
summary: K-pop boy band BTS has ended its distribution deal with Sony Music's Columbia Records and will partner with Universal Music Group instead. The move, confirmed by BTS's management company Hybe, is a coup for Universal Music, which had been pursuing the tie-up for years. The new agreement covers distribution and marketing in the US and other regions, with Universal's Ingrooves Music handling distribution and Geffen Records providing creative support. The deal follows a joint venture label announcement with YG Entertainment and Kiswe, and comes after BTS was the top-selling recording act in the world last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-Singapore Airlines and Qantas Airways are increasing flights as a quarantine-free travel arrangement between Singapore and Australia is set to launch for students and businessmen. HDB resale flat prices saw a 9-month climb of 2.9%, exceeding their previous peak in 2013. Ascendas Reit acquired 11 logistics properties in Kansas City for S$207.8m. Singapore regulators have taken steps to mitigate risks from entities with Myanmar dealings. The STI rose 16.64 points or 0.52% to 3,205.14 points, up nearly 1% over the week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 3.54 points to 1,588.08. The index saw 3.072 billion lots traded worth RM2.183 billion, with 597 losers and 410 gainers.

site_title: Snap's record rout leads US$100b social-media stock selloff
summary: Snap's stock plummeted 24% on its biggest one-day drop record, wiping out US$27 billion of market value, after the company warned of Apple's data collection rules and global supply-chain bottlenecks affecting advertising spending. This led to a US$100 billion selloff across social media stocks, including Alphabet, Facebook, Twitter, and Pinterest. Snap's cautious outlook has raised concerns about industry-wide challenges, with peers' quarterly results set to be released next week.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the open on Friday, following a mixed week for equities. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.1%, while the DAX index gained 0.3% and the CAC 40 increased 0.5%. The rebounds were attributed to a recovery in Tokyo and optimism about US-EU trade talks. The rallies were driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares gain as Evergrande makes interest payment
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.34% as investors reacted positively to Evergrande's interest payment. The Nikkei 225 index climbed to 28,804.85, while the Topix index edged up 0.07% to 2,002.23. The news boosted investor sentiment, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Taiwan delegation irks China with eastern Europe tour
summary: A Taiwanese government delegation, consisting of 66 officials, is visiting three eastern European countries - Slovakia, Czech Republic, and Lithuania - to boost trade ties and investment. The visit has angered China, which views Taiwan as part of its territory and is trying to keep the island isolated. The European Union members have shown signs of wanting closer relations with Taiwan, despite China's opposition. The visit comes after US President Joe Biden stated that the US would defend Taiwan if attacked by China, contradicting the long-held US policy of "strategic ambiguity."

site_title: Singapore's electricity retailer UGS Energy is the latest to bow out
summary: UGS Energy, a Singaporean electricity retailer, has exited the city-state's electricity market due to challenging market conditions. This follows the recent exits of SilverCloud Energy and Valueenergy, which were also retailers for commercial consumers. UGS Energy had entered the Open Electricity Market with the aim of providing a competitive market for consumers but was unable to sustain its business. The exit will take effect on October 27, 2021.

site_title: CICT's Q3 net property income more than doubles to S$242.6m; room for retail recovery
summary: Capitaland Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a net property income (NPI) of S$242.6 million in Q3, more than doubling from S$104.5 million a year ago. The trust's portfolio recorded a 94.4% committed occupancy and a weighted average lease expiry of 3 years. Retail assets contributed S$136.6 million of the quarter's gross revenue, with NPI rising 31.5% year-on-year to S$97.7 million. This marks a significant recovery in the retail segment, providing a positive outlook for the trust's future growth.

site_title: SoftBank in talks to sell French robotics business to Germany's United Robotics: sources
summary: SoftBank Group is in talks to sell its French robotics business behind the Pepper android to Germany's United Robotics Group. The business, which SoftBank once touted as a major growth driver, has struggled. United Robotics Group, backed by German industrial robot maker Hahn, became the European master distributor for SoftBank's Pepper and Nao robots in October. The terms of the deal are unclear, including whether SoftBank will retain a stake and the deal's potential value. Plans are ongoing, and the deal could change.

site_title: UK retail sales fall in Sep despite panic buying of fuel
summary: UK retail sales fell 0.2% in September, marking the fifth consecutive monthly decline, despite a surge in fuel sales. This softness in spending adds to concerns about Britain's economic recovery, with economists predicting a possible interest rate hike. Retail sales are now 1.3% lower than a year earlier, with household goods and food sales contributing to the decline. The data also points to a slowdown in overall third-quarter economic growth, with consumer price inflation expected to exceed 4% by the end of the year.

site_title: SGX opens office in India's Gift City; to launch Gift Data Connect for real-time Nifty data insight
summary: SGX has opened an office in India's Gift City, marking the start of its SGX-International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) office. The office will facilitate SGX's upcoming connect with India's National Stock Exchange (NSE), allowing international members to access real-time Nifty data via its derivatives trading platform, Gift Data Connect. This will provide investors with unrivaled insights into India's equity market. The NSE IFSC-SGX Connect aims to bring together Nifty products trading in Gift City, creating a larger pool of liquidity.

site_title: ICBC Singapore prices US$1.05b green bond notes due 2024 at 1%
summary: ICBC Singapore priced US$1.05 billion worth of green bond notes due 2024 at a 1% coupon rate, with semi-annual interest payments. The 3-year bond will mature on October 28, 2024, and is expected to list on multiple exchanges. Moody's and Standard and Poor's have given the notes an A1 and A rating, respectively, with expected proceeds used to finance or refinance green assets.

site_title: Upcoming Australia-Singapore quarantine-free travel plan excites businesses, airlines
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced a quarantine-free travel arrangement with Singapore, expected to launch within the next week for vaccinated students and business travelers. The arrangement, similar to Australia's travel bubble with New Zealand, will initially allow for free travel between the two countries. This move is seen as a boost to businesses and airlines, with Singapore Airlines and Qantas Airways increasing flights as a result. The travel bubble is the first step towards opening up to tourists, with talks focused on allowing vaccinated individuals to travel freely.

site_title: HDB resale flat prices see fastest 9-month climb in more than 10 years after record Q3
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore have reached a record high, with a 9.1% increase in the first 9 months of 2021, the fastest 9-month climb in over 10 years. Resale prices rose 2.9% in the July-September period, exceeding their previous peak in 2013. The median price of 5-room flats in central areas reached S$950,000. Resale transactions also rose 19.4% to 8,433 units in the third quarter. Experts predict prices will continue to climb, with Lee Sze Teck predicting a 2% increase in the last quarter of the year, bringing the price gain for 2021 to over 11%.

site_title: Huawei, SMIC suppliers received billions worth of licences for US goods: documents
summary: US suppliers to Chinese companies Huawei and SMIC received billions of dollars worth of licenses to sell goods and technology despite being on a US trade blacklist. Between November and April, 113 licenses worth $61 billion were approved for Huawei and 188 licenses valued at nearly $42 billion were granted for SMIC. The licenses, which are typically valid for 4 years, did not authorize shipments of sensitive items. The release of the licensing data has sparked criticism from China hawks in Washington, who argue that it undermines efforts to restrict Chinese companies' access to advanced US technology.

site_title: A love-hate letter to my ex, the office
summary: A former employee shares a nostalgic and introspective letter to her old office, where she spent 10 years learning and growing. The office, which she considers a second home, was a source of comfort and inspiration during a pivotal time in her life. However, with the pandemic restrictions, they were separated, and she eventually left for a new job. Now, she's torn between her new life and the longing for the familiar rhythms of her old office. She wonders if she'll ever find a way to reconcile her past and present selves.

site_title: Electrified cars hit almost a fifth of EU Q3 vehicle sales
summary: Electric vehicles accounted for nearly 19% of EU vehicle sales in Q3, with battery electric vehicles up 57% and plug-in hybrids up 43%. Sales of petrol cars dropped 35% and diesel cars 50% compared to the same period last year. The European Commission aims to ban fossil-fuel vehicles by 2035 to combat global warming. Car makers and consumers have benefited from government subsidies for electric vehicles, contributing to the growth in electrified model sales.

site_title: Chip crunch to hit Renault 2021 production more than forecast
summary: Renault has revised its 2021 production forecast upwards, with estimated losses of nearly 500,000 vehicles due to the global semiconductor chip shortage, more than double the initial forecast of 220,000 units. Despite this, the company maintains its profit outlook due to high car pricing and cost cuts. Renault's order book reached a 15-year high, with a 6-month wait time for the Dacia Sandero, and the company expects to meet 2021 European CO2 emission targets.

site_title: Apec finance ministers to step up vaccine efforts
summary: Finance ministers from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) group agreed to step up efforts to expand COVID-19 vaccine manufacture and supply, and support global vaccine sharing. They also pledged to maintain macroeconomic stability and refrain from competitive exchange rate devaluations. The meeting, held virtually, came ahead of the UN COP26 talks in Glasgow, where APEC members will discuss climate change and inequality. The decision aims to address the "vaccine apartheid" and inequality in vaccine distribution, particularly in smaller, poorer countries.

site_title: Samsung SDI, Stellantis to set up EV battery joint venture in US
summary: Samsung SDI and Stellantis have agreed to set up a joint venture to produce electric vehicle (EV) battery cells and modules in the US. The plant, expected to start by 2025, will have an initial annual capacity of 23 GWh, potentially increasing to 40 GWh. The batteries will be supplied to Stellantis's US, Canadian, and Mexican factories. This joint venture comes as Stellantis aims to secure over 130 GWh of global battery capacity by 2025 and 260 GWh by 2030.

site_title: ARA's Europe arm forms JV to invest in UK logistics, industrial assets
summary: ARA Dunedin, the European arm of ARA Asset Management, has formed a joint venture with Partners Group to invest £250 million in UK logistics and industrial assets. The JV aims to target upgrading, extending, or reletting properties near major UK regions. The initial investment includes 7 industrial properties in the UK, with the goal of achieving value-add returns through intelligent selection, management, and strategic capital expenditure. This move comes as the UK industrial sector experiences high demand amid e-commerce growth and shrinking supply due to competition from other real estate segments.

site_title: Retail rents could see short-term pressure before recovering in 2022
summary: Retail rents in Singapore are under pressure due to the extension of safe-management measures, but analysts predict a recovery in 2022 as restrictions ease and the country introduces more vaccinated travel lanes. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's retail rental index showed a 2.7% decline in central region rents in Q3, while fringe areas saw a 1.2% increase. Despite this, retail prices have eased 6% in the first 9 months of 2021, and the vacancy rate fell across all submarkets. Analysts expect a gradual recovery in 2022 as the economy reopens and tourism picks up, with some predicting a rent recovery as early as the end of the year.

site_title: Bank of Japan discussing phasing out pandemic support as economy reopens: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is discussing phasing out its Covid-19 loan programme, set to expire in March, if infections continue to dwindle. Policymakers are considering ending the emergency programme sooner than anticipated, with some contemplating an early exit in March. This move comes as corporate funding strains ease and the country's economy reopens, with infections falling sharply. A decision is unlikely before December, and a consensus has not been reached among policymakers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.36% and the Topix index down 0.43%. The decline came despite US stocks reaching fresh records, boosted by solid earnings. The US market's performance was overshadowed by Tokyo's opening, with investors possibly waiting for Japan's GDP data.

site_title: China's land sales slump for second month as developers stay away
summary: China's land sales slumped for the second consecutive month, falling 11.15% in September to 570.3 billion yuan (S$120 billion), according to finance ministry data. The decline follows tightened regulations on borrowing, affecting private developers. Local authorities rely heavily on land sales for income, and a prolonged slump could strain their finances. Revenue from government land sales rose 8.7% to 5.3634 trillion yuan in the first nine months of 2021, but analysts predict further decline in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Hot stock: Raffles Education up as much as 19.7% after disclosures
summary: Raffles Education shares surged 19.7% to S$0.073 after a 3-day trading halt was lifted, following disclosures about an investigation into disclosure issues and refutations of allegations regarding executive pay. The counter was among the top 5 traded stocks by volume, with 36 million shares changing hands. The share price movement comes after the company's directors were involved in an investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat; investors eyeing Q3 GDP, chip earnings
summary: South Korean stocks closed nearly unchanged on Friday, marking the fourth weekly decline in five, as investors await third-quarter economic data and earnings reports from major chipmakers. The Kospi index fell 1.17 points, or 0.04%, to 3,006.16, after gaining 1.99% the previous week. The slowdown in economic growth is attributed to robust exports being offset by subdued domestic demand due to the Delta variant. Foreigners were net sellers of $91.48 million worth of shares on the main board, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rising 0.28% and 2.28%, respectively.

site_title: MOM to study NTUC-SNEF taskforce recommendations on workplace fairness and support for workers
summary: The Singapore government will study recommendations from a taskforce on workplace fairness and support for workers, focusing on professionals, managers, and executives. The taskforce, comprising NTUC and SNEF, proposed 9 recommendations, including reviewing the employment pass application process, introducing unemployment benefits, and creating job opportunities for mature workers. The Ministry of Manpower will use these recommendations to design a legal framework for workplace fairness and employment support initiatives.

site_title: Singapore private home prices may jump 6-7% this year, analysts say
summary: Singapore's private home prices may increase 6-7% this year, driven by a strong global economic recovery, low vaccination rates, and a stable political environment. Luxury housing and foreign demand are expected to boost prices, while resale transactions are expected to jump 30% to 13,000 units. Non-landed private homes in the rest of central region (RCR) saw a 2.6% increase, while overall private residential rents rose 1.8% in the third quarter. Analysts attribute the growth to the reopening of borders and a tight supply of completed homes.

site_title: Gold rises, set for weekly gain on softer US dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,785.00 per ounce, poised for a second weekly gain, as a softer US dollar offset higher US bond yields and inflation expectations. A weaker dollar is expected to decline this week, aiding bullion prices. The US Federal Reserve may reduce its balance sheet over the next two years, and interest rates may be raised by the end of 2022. This could limit gold's upside, but it remains an inflation hedge.

site_title: Alec Baldwin fired prop gun that killed woman on film set: police
summary: US actor Alec Baldwin fired a prop gun that killed cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and wounded director Joel Souza on the set of the film "Rust" in New Mexico. The incident occurred on Thursday at the Bonanza Creek Ranch, where Baldwin was filming a 19th-century western. No charges have been filed, and the investigation is ongoing. Baldwin co-produces the film and stars in the lead role. This incident is the latest in a string of prop gun accidents on movie sets, following a similar incident that killed Brandon Lee during filming of "The Crow."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on front foot
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.37% in the first few minutes of trade on October 22, 2021, following a record lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose to 26,114.84, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. A report stated China Evergrande had paid the interest on an offshore bond, alleviating concerns about the developer's financial stability. This development contributed to the positive market sentiment.

site_title: New Zealand sets 90% vaccine target to end lockdown
summary: New Zealand has set a 90% vaccination target to end lockdowns, aiming to minimize Covid-19 spread in the community. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the shift from eliminating the virus to vaccination, allowing fully inoculated citizens to leave their homes without restrictions. As of now, around 86% of eligible New Zealanders have received their first vaccine dose and 68% are double jabbed. The new policy aims to give hope to Auckland residents who have been in hard lockdown for nine weeks, allowing them to enjoy summer activities like going to bars and restaurants.

site_title: Biden says 'yes' US would defend Taiwan against China
summary: President Joe Biden stated that the US would defend Taiwan if the island was attacked by China, contradicting the long-held US policy of "strategic ambiguity." Biden reiterated the US commitment to defend key allies, including Taiwan, and compared it to its defense of NATO allies in Canada and Europe. The White House confirmed that US policy on Taiwan "has not changed," following similar statements in August.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden on Thursday said the United States would come to the defence of Taiwan if the island were attacked by China, which considers it part of its territory.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as weaker miners overshadow travel cheer
summary: Australia's shares remained flat on Friday, as losses in major miners outweighed gains in travel stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.1% to 7,407.4, despite Melbourne emerging from its longest Covid-19 lockdown, which lifted travel restrictions. Travel stocks, such as Flight Centre Travel and Qantas, rose 3.1% and 4.9%, respectively. Major miners, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, fell 1.8% and 2.2%, respectively, due to plunging iron ore prices.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to acquire 11 logistics properties in Kansas City for S$207.8m
summary: Ascendas Reit has proposed the acquisition of 11 logistics properties in Kansas City, US, for S$207.8 million. The portfolio, 92.6% occupied, has a strong retention rate and minimal tenant concentration risk. The acquisition is expected to increase the proportion of logistics properties to 22% of the Reit's total investment properties. The deal is subject to closing conditions and is expected to take place in Q4 2021, with the Reit's manager expecting continuous high demand for the portfolio due to its convenient access to the domestic market and transportation infrastructure.

site_title: What's behind the surprise 3.5% drop in URA's office rental index in Q3
summary: Singapore's office rental index dropped 3.5% in Q3 2021, with Category 1 buildings seeing a 0.8% quarter-on-quarter increase and Category 2 buildings experiencing a 1.3% decline. A "flight-to-quality" by tenants and owners' financial constraints contributed to the drop. Despite this, experts predict a gradual recovery, citing growth in Grade A office rents and a tight supply pipeline. The office market is expected to bottom out, with a potential resurgence driven by economic recovery and the adoption of hybrid working models.

site_title: Japan's consumer inflation turns positive as energy costs rise
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.1% in September, the first increase since March 2020, driven by a 7.4% spike in energy costs. Gasoline costs surged 16.5% and processed food prices also rose, while telecommunication fees plummeted 44.8%. Analysts expect core inflation to reach 1% in coming months, but doubt it will lead to broader price growth. The Bank of Japan will consider the data at its upcoming policy meeting, where it will also release fresh growth and inflation projections.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 5.52 points or 0.35% to 1,586.10. Volume reached 247.68 million lots worth RM139.23 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 288 to 133. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Crypto startup FTX Trading raises US$420m in funding round co-led by Temasek
summary: Crypto startup FTX Trading has raised US$420m in a funding round led by Temasek, valuing the company at US$25 billion. This marks a significant increase from its previous funding round in July, which valued the company at US$18 billion. The platform's user base has grown 48% and average trade volume has surged 75%, with daily volumes averaging US$14 billion. FTX counts celebrity couple Tom Brady and Gisele Bundchen among its backers and is currently not available to residents in the United States.

site_title: Singapore regulators taking steps to mitigate risks from entities with Myanmar dealings
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have taken steps to mitigate risks from entities with business dealings in Myanmar. Following a legal memorandum by human rights groups, MAS has put financial institutions on "heightened alert" and SGX RegCo is in "active engagement" with an independent reviewer looking into Catalist-listed Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC) activities. The move comes after ETC was accused of contributing millions to the Myanmar army in its Golden City development. Until the review is complete, ETC won't be able to raise funds via the Singapore stock market or resume share trading.

site_title: US Fed announces stricter investment rules for central banker officials
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced stricter investment rules for central banker officials, aiming to prevent conflicts of interest. The new rules prohibit individual stock holdings, trading during unusual market stress, and require pre-approval and frequent disclosure of trades. Fed Chair Jerome Powell, who faced criticism for his own trading activities, stated that the rules will help maintain a "single-minded focus on the public mission" of the Federal Reserve. The rules apply to senior officials and staff, and some may need to divest holdings to comply.

site_title: China Evergrande wires funds for bond coupon, averting default
summary: China Evergrande Group wired $83.5 million to a trustee account on Thursday, avoiding a formal default on a dollar bond interest payment due on September 23. The payment is a relief to bondholders, but Evergrande still needs to restructure its debt. The company's shares and dollar bonds surged following the news, with Evergrande's April 2022 and 2023 notes jumping over 10%. This move may be a step towards finding liquidity, but it does not address the underlying debt restructuring issues.

images.alt_text: China Evergrande Group wired funds to a trustee account on Thursday for a dollar bond interest payment due Sept 23, a source told Reuters on Friday, days before a deadline that would have plunged the embattled developer into formal default.

site_title: Melbourne reopens as world's most locked-down city eases pandemic restrictions
summary: Melbourne, Australia, has lifted its pandemic restrictions after 262 days, becoming the world's most locked-down city to do so. The city reopened with relaxed rules, allowing restaurants and cafes to reopen with vaccinated patrons and 10 guests at home. The move marks a significant easing of restrictions and a boost for the country's economy. Australia's vaccination rates have risen to over 70% of adults, paving the way for international border reopenings and flight resumptions.

images.alt_text: Melbourne residents flocked to the city's pubs, restaurants and hair salons in the early hours of Friday after the world's most locked-down city emerged from its latest spate of restrictions designed to combat the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: UK employers tell Johnson to 'get serious' about tax and investment
summary: UK employers are urging Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government to "get serious" about encouraging business investment and reducing taxes, warning against increasing the tax burden on companies. The Confederation of British Industry is urging finance minister Rishi Sunak to focus on investment and public spending in his upcoming budget statement and three-year plan. This comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, posing a challenge to the government's post-Brexit economic plans.

site_title: Japan's private-sector activity grows for first time in six months: PMI
summary: Japan's private sector activity grew for the first time in six months, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 53.0 in October and the services PMI at 50.7, marking the first expansion in 21 months. Supply chain disruptions and raw material demand fueled the growth, despite ongoing coronavirus pandemic restrictions. The expansion was driven by stronger overseas demand and a reduction in pandemic restrictions. This marks the first time the services sector has expanded since January 2020.

site_title: Google cuts its commission on app subscriptions
summary: Google is reducing its commission on app subscriptions to 15% starting in January, cutting the existing rate of 30% for the first year and 15% on renewals. The move aims to provide businesses with more predictable revenue, allowing them to benefit from lower commissions sooner. This change follows Apple's recent reduction of its commission from 30% to 15% for apps earning less than $1 million per year. The decision is seen as a response to pressure from regulators and developers who have criticized the tech giants' grip on their online marketplaces.

site_title: Australia-Singapore travel bubble could happen 'within the next week': Morrison
summary: Australia is nearing a quarantine-free travel bubble with Singapore, with a possible opening within the next week, according to Prime Minister Scott Morrison. The initial plan allows vaccinated students and business travelers to fly between the two countries, before opening up to tourists. The arrangement will also depend on individual state quarantine restrictions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Ascendas Reit, Suntec Reit, Sabana Reit, Raffles Education
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

SIA's shares rose 0.6% after announcing it will resume flying to Sydney from Dec 1, ahead of a potential quarantine-free travel bubble with Australia. Ascendas Reit proposed a US$207.8 million acquisition of 11 logistics properties in Kansas City. Suntec Reit reported a 20.8% increase in distribution per unit for the third quarter. Sabana Reit reached a 85.3% portfolio occupancy rate and removed its Shari'ah compliance status. Raffles Education's shares were halted after the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department requested documents related to loan facilities extended to its subsidiaries.

site_title: US conducts 'successful' test of hypersonic missile technology
summary: The US successfully tested hypersonic missile technology, a capability currently being developed by China and Russia. The test, conducted at a NASA facility in Virginia, demonstrated advanced hypersonic technologies and prototype systems. The US Navy aims to deploy its first hypersonic weapons by 2025, following concerns raised by China's recent test of a hypersonic missile with nuclear capacity. The development is seen as a response to the growing threat of hypersonic missiles, which can fly at speeds over Mach 5 and evade traditional defenses.

site_title: Singapore looking forward to resuming close connectivity with Australia: PM Lee
summary: Singapore is looking forward to resuming close connectivity with Australia as the country moves towards an endemic Covid-19 future. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced that his country is nearing a quarantine-free travel bubble with Singapore, which could be established within the next week. The initial plan allows vaccinated students and business travelers to fly between the two countries, with the intention of opening up to tourists later. This move comes after Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed his delight at Australia's decision to allow visa holders from Singapore to enter the country.

site_title: UK public's inflation expectations rocket to record high: GfK
summary: A record 48% of UK public expects inflation to accelerate over the next 12 months, up from 34% in September, according to a GfK survey. This marks the highest share since records began in 1985. The surge in inflation expectations follows recent rocketing gas prices and global supply chain problems. Economists predict the Bank of England may raise interest rates for the first time in November to combat inflation, which is expected to exceed 4% soon.

site_title: Thailand to allow quarantine-free travel from 46 countries, including Singapore
summary: Thailand will allow quarantine-free travel from 46 countries, including Singapore, starting November 1. The move aims to revive the country's vital tourism industry, which lost US$50 billion in revenue last year. Visitors from these countries will need to be fully vaccinated and have a document proving they are virus-free. The country will also lift curfews in key tourist destinations like Bangkok, Hua Hin, and Pattaya, and reopen the capital city.

site_title: Europe: Stocks recoup most losses; weak outlook hits SAP
summary: European stocks rose to six-week highs, offsetting losses in miners and tech companies due to disappointing earnings forecasts, including SAP's weak outlook. The Stoxx 600 index ended 0.1% down at 469.71, despite a 0.8-point increase in euro zone consumer confidence. European miners, particularly Anglo American, fell 3.0% due to plunging iron ore and base metal prices, while tech companies SAP, ABB, and Nordic Semiconductor also declined. Defensive sectors, such as personal and household goods, rose 0.8% on Unilever's earnings beat.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU rises 20.8% to S$0.02232
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 20.8% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02232, driven by strong contributions from newly acquired assets in London and Melbourne. Distributable income rose 22% to S$63.7 million, while gross revenue and net property income also increased by 16.5% and 45.5%, respectively. The Reit's CEO noted the "resilience" of its asset portfolio and plans to strengthen its balance sheet through active capital management.

site_title: Asian economies feel the chill without coal comfort
summary: Asian economies are feeling the effects of a global energy crisis, with coal prices surging and supply staying tight. China, a major coal consumer, is experiencing an energy crunch, forcing parts of the country to curtail output to industrial producers. This has raised concerns about inflation, trade, and external accounts, as well as a possible fiscal impact. Indonesia and Malaysia, the only two Asian countries benefiting from higher energy prices, will face inflationary pressures and a demand shock from slowdowns in their export markets.

site_title: Barclays Q3 profit doubles amid global deal frenzy, beats market expectations
summary: Barclays reported a doubling of third-quarter profits to £2 billion, beating market expectations, driven by strong investment banking fees from advisory mandates and equities trading. The bank's advisory and equities business had a record performance, with a return on equity of 16.4% compared to 10.5% last year. Despite a turbulent UK economy, Barclays upgraded its economic forecasts and expects the UK's GDP to reach pre-pandemic levels by early 2022.

images.alt_text: Barclays is alone these days among British banks in competing with Wall Street rivals on their home turf across the main investment banking businesses of advisory, equities and fixed income.

site_title: US mortgage rates surge to 6-month high
summary: US mortgage rates reached a 6-month high of 3.23% in the week ended Oct 15, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This is the highest level since early April and marks a quarter percentage point increase since July. Mortgage applications fell 6.3% to the lowest since July, with refinancing applications down 7.1% and homebuying applications down 4.9%. The US homebuilding unexpectedly fell in September, and global interest rates continue to rise as central banks signal the end of crisis-era accommodation.

site_title: European countries reach digital services tax deal with US
summary: European countries, including Austria, Britain, France, Italy, Spain, and the US, reached a deal to transition from national digital services taxes to a global tax deal. The US agreed to drop proposed trade retaliation against the countries, which had been targeted for unfair taxation of US companies. The agreement follows a deal among nearly 140 countries on new international corporate taxation rules. The European countries will withdraw their national digital services taxes, and the US will drop its trade retaliation, marking a significant compromise in the international tax debate.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II spent night in hospital: Buckingham Palace
summary: Queen Elizabeth II spent a night in hospital due to medical advice to rest for a few days. The 95-year-old monarch, who has been on the throne since 1952, underwent preliminary investigations on Wednesday afternoon and returned to Windsor Castle on Thursday. She remains in good spirits and is undertaking light duties after the overnight stay. The decision to spend the night in hospital was not related to the coronavirus and was for "practical reasons." The Queen had been due to attend an ecumenical service in Northern Ireland, but the trip was cancelled.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record as earnings extends stocks rally
summary: US stocks ended at a record on Thursday, with the S&P 500 climbing 0.3% to 4,549.78, its first record close since early September. Solid earnings from Tesla, American Airlines, and Union Pacific drove the rally, despite weak IBM results. The Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.6% to 15,215.70, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat. New unemployment claims fell to 290,000, the lowest level since March 2020. The yield of the 10-year US Treasury note pushed higher, highlighting inflation concerns, but investor optimism for the end-of-year rally countered that.

site_title: Home truths
summary: A new play, "Straight Acting" by rising playwright-director Thomas Lim, tackles the struggles of the LGBTQ community in Singapore, exploring themes of love, identity, and acceptance. The story follows two lesbian and two gay couples as they navigate the challenges of finding a home and starting a family in a society that doesn't recognize LGBTQ relationships. Through a mix of comedy and drama, the play highlights the complexities of self-acceptance, job discrimination, and social stigma, ultimately offering a hopeful and heartwarming conclusion.

site_title: 'What about us?' Thai budget businesses fear government's focus on premium tourists
summary: Thailand is shifting its focus from budget-friendly tourism to premium tourists, aiming to revive its economy after the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting November 1, the country will waive quarantine for fully-vaccinated visitors from 10 low-risk countries, with a goal of drawing 1 million high-spending tourists by April. However, budget businesses in tourist areas like Chiang Mai fear being left out, citing concerns that the new focus will exclude mid-priced guesthouses and other businesses catering to backpackers. Critics argue that prioritizing premium tourists may not necessarily reduce environmental impact.

site_title: Few options for G-7 trade chiefs to alleviate supply pinch
summary: G-7 trade ministers will discuss ways to address supply chain woes and fight protectionism, but experts say they have few options for a rapid fix. The issues are driven by market forces, including excess demand for goods following the pandemic, and may take up to six months to ease. The US, UK, and other wealthy industrial democracies are exploring investments in ports and infrastructure, diversifying supply chains, and cooperation to quickly identify and address supply bottlenecks. However, experts say the key solutions are likely to be longer-term fixes, and the supply chain crisis may have already peaked, with improvement expected by the second half of 2022.

site_title: A redesign of Singapore's property landscape
summary: Singapore's property landscape is undergoing a redesign, incorporating more green spaces, space-efficient designs, and low-carbon features. Developers are incorporating these needs into residential and commercial projects. The pandemic has accelerated this shift, with companies like Far East Hospitality adopting sustainable practices. The government's vision for a low-carbon future is driving this change, with a focus on reusing urban space. As a result, property developers are creating more sustainable and efficient buildings.

site_title: Oil dives, forecast of mild US winter spurs retreat from multi-year highs
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Thursday as a forecast of a warm US winter put an end to a rally that reached a three-year high above $86 a barrel. Oil prices fell $1.21 to $84.61 for Brent crude and $0.92 to $82.50 for US West Texas Intermediate crude. The forecast, released by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, indicates drier and warmer conditions in the US, putting pressure on the complex. This marks a retreat from multi-year highs driven by tight supply and a global energy crunch.

site_title: 2021 Porsche Macan review: Macan Sutra
summary: The 2021 Porsche Macan has received a facelift, introducing subtle exterior changes and a sleeker interior with a touch-sensitive console and a new 10.9-inch infotainment screen. The updated Macan features a simplified menu and improved voice control, while maintaining its powerful engine options, including a 380hp Macan S and a 440hp GTS. Despite not being particularly fast, the Macan excels behind the wheel, offering precise steering, crisp gear shifts, and refined suspension. The facelifted model is available in Singapore starting at S$260,088.

site_title: UN chief 'very worried' over possible COP26 failure
summary: UN chief Antonio Guterres expressed concern over the possibility of COP26 failure, stating that a 2.7°C warming above pre-industrial levels is a "one-way ticket for disaster." The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to cap warming at below 2°C, but current estimates indicate a catastrophic warming. Guterres blamed the carbon pollution of a handful of countries, particularly China and the US, for the impending disaster, urging them to take more action. The COP26 conference in Glasgow is seen as crucial in setting worldwide emission targets to slow global warming, but time is running out.

images.alt_text: UN chief Antonio Guterres said on Thursday that the current climate situation was "a one-way ticket for disaster" and stresed the need to "avoid a failure" at the COP26 climate conference in Glasgow.

site_title: Amazon faces new union organising push in US
summary: Amazon faces a new union organising push in the US, with workers in a New York City warehouse seeking to form the company's first union. The Amazon Labor Union (ALU) plans to file with US officials on Monday, aiming to hold an election. The effort is led by former employee Christian Smalls, who sued Amazon over his dismissal and pandemic conditions. The ALU is seeking better wages, job security, and working conditions, while Amazon opposes unionising efforts, citing that unions hinder continuous improvement. A US labour official recently recommended nullifying a failed unionising effort in Alabama, potentially paving the way for a new election.

images.alt_text: Workers at an Amazon warehouse in New York are seeking to unionise, the organising group said on Thursday, six months after a similar attempt in Alabama failed.

site_title: Trump says he has plans to launch new social network - Truth Social
summary: Former US President Donald Trump announced plans to launch his own social network, Truth Social, owned by Trump Media & Technology Group (TMTG), amid speculation of another presidential run in 2024. The platform, expected to begin its beta launch next month, will feature "non-woke" entertainment programming and is seen as a response to his ban from Twitter and Facebook following the January 6 US Capitol attack. TMTG plans to merge with Digital World Acquisition Corp to become a publicly listed company, valuing it at $875 million.

site_title: Emboldened Bitcoin bulls shoot for the moon after topping record
summary: Bitcoin has reached a fresh record high of almost US$67,000, with the cryptocurrency now holding at about US$64,650. This marks a 120% rally this year, with some believers predicting a potential US$100,000 target. The successful launch of the first US Bitcoin futures ETF has contributed to the surge, and institutional investors are increasingly optimistic about the market. Experts predict further growth, with some projecting a US$5 trillion market value by 2024 and US$80,000 or even US$100,000 this year. However, caution is advised, as past price swings have led to corrections.

site_title: Social media abuzz with new names for Facebook
summary: Facebook is reportedly planning to rebrand itself with a new name, sparking a wide range of online suggestions and reactions. The company has refused to comment, but the Twitterati has been buzzing with ideas, from "Meta" to "Ye", with some reflecting concerns about user safety and hate speech. The move is seen as an attempt to revamp the platform's image, which has been deserted by younger users and criticized for its handling of user safety issues.

site_title: Polls suggest Japan's ruling bloc will cling to election majority
summary: Polls suggest Japan's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will likely lose some seats but form a ruling coalition with the Komeito party, maintaining a majority in the October 31 lower house election. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to win a clear mandate to address the pandemic, but weak election results could limit his term.

site_title: Blackstone plans up to record US$30b for flagship buyout fund
summary: Blackstone plans to raise up to $30 billion for its next flagship private equity fund, potentially setting a record for the industry. Fund-raising could begin next year, as the firm ramps up its efforts to secure funds for its next life sciences, energy, and growth strategies. This comes as the private equity industry is experiencing a frenzied time, with over 6,000 funds seeking $1 trillion in investments. The move is driven by low interest rates and robust demand for higher-yielding assets, but there is a risk that there may not be enough appetite to meet the vast supply of investment opportunities.

site_title: Sabana Reit records 85.3% portfolio occupancy in Q3
summary: Sabana Reit recorded a portfolio occupancy of 85.3% in Q3, the highest level since early 2018, driven by multi-tenanted properties with a 90.7% occupancy rate. The Reit has diversified its portfolio and signed 90,600 sq ft of new leases, including with multinational corporations. It has also completed a refinancing exercise and appointed a new CFO and head of real estate. The Reit manager expects the refreshed strategy to bear fruit, despite Covid-19 restrictions, and is poised for the next phase of growth.

site_title: Volvo Q3 profit beats forecast, but chip woes linger
summary: Volvo's third-quarter core earnings exceeded expectations, driven by strong demand for trucks despite chip shortages and production disruptions. The company reported an adjusted operating profit of 9.40 billion Swedish crowns ($1.47 billion), beating analyst forecasts. However, sales and earnings remain below pre-pandemic levels, and Volvo warned of further supply chain disruptions and stoppages in truck production and other areas. Despite this, JP Morgan described the results as "solid" and expects consensus expectations to rise.

site_title: China's absence of intervention on yuan's swift gains keeps markets buzzing
summary: China's yuan has reached its strongest levels in six years, surpassing 6.4 per dollar, with no direct intervention from the authorities despite growing economic concerns. Analysts speculate that the People's Bank of China is allowing market forces to dictate the yuan's trajectory, possibly waiting for the Federal Reserve to begin policy tightening. The yuan's 24-currency trade-weighted index has topped 100, a level not seen since 2015, and is seen as a sign of a stronger yuan reining in rising costs for mainland importers.

site_title: Resurrecting Halloween
summary: Halloween celebrations in Singapore have seen a resurgence this year, with many attractions and events selling out due to travel restrictions and pent-up demand. The National Retail Federation estimates US$10.14 billion in Halloween spending in the US, while the UK is set to match its 2019 figure of £474 million. Local operators have capitalized on the trend, offering unique experiences such as haunted house exhibitions and spooky cruises. The pandemic has also led to an increase in staycation and hyper-local activities, with many tour operators seeing a boost in business.

site_title: Britain's economy finds out what it means to live with Covid
summary: The UK's economy is facing a growing problem as the coronavirus spreads rapidly, despite the lifting of most restrictions in July. Economic growth is slowing, inflation is high, and the Bank of England is expected to hike interest rates soon. The government is relying on vaccination programs to protect the economy, but experts warn of a potential winter wave that could prolong supply chain disruptions and limit output. With households facing a cost-of-living crisis, Chancellor Rishi Sunak is preparing to deliver a budget that may further down the road toward fiscal normalisation.

site_title: More-than-you-can-eat Korean dining at Sura
summary: Sura, a Korean restaurant in Singapore, offers an all-you-can-eat Hanjeongsik meal, a traditional Korean feast, for S$150. The meal features multiple dishes, including pumpkin porridge, fresh oysters, abalone, and seafood hotpot, with the guidance of server Michael Song, who ensures diners know what they're eating. While the cooking isn't stellar, Sura's sincerity and willingness to feed customers more than their money's worth make it a standout experience. The meal is a marathon, but Michael's banter makes it enjoyable, and the restaurant's rating is 6.5.

site_title: Germany's Flixbus snaps up US bus icon Greyhound for US$172m
summary: Germany's Flixbus acquired US bus icon Greyhound for $172 million from British owner FirstGroup.
