The deal will expand Flixbus' low-cost coach offering in the US, with Greyhound serving 2,400 destinations and carrying 16 million passengers annually. Flixbus CEO Jochen Engert sees the acquisition as a major step forward in the US, aiming to make smart, affordable, and sustainable mobility accessible to all. The deal marks a significant expansion for Flixbus, which operates in 36 countries, including Germany and the US.

site_title: The greatest transfer of workplace power in our lifetime
summary: Remote work is expected to continue its upward trend over the next decade, with many companies adopting all-remote work structures. This shift will lead to changes in workplaces, cities, and economies. Key developments include: hybrid work models devolving into inequality, offices becoming hubs for in-person cultural moments, and the "great resignation" solidifying all-remote work for digital businesses. Smaller cities and suburbia will thrive as remote work reduces urban migration, while big cities will forge new identities as people choose to live in other locations. Business and leisure travel will also merge, with remote workers seeking to make the most of location flexibility.

site_title: Sustainability - going green need not be at the expense of profitability
summary: Singaporean firms are adopting sustainable business practices to remain competitive and reduce their environmental impact. The demand for sustainable products and services is expected to rise, with companies like Google Cloud and OCBC Bank investing in energy efficiency and renewable energy. However, there is a need for a mindset shift towards sustainability, and firms must integrate sustainability into their businesses to remain profitable. Experts emphasize the importance of transparency, data-driven decision-making, and collaboration to achieve sustainability goals. Going green can lead to long-term value creation, and firms should avoid greenwashing by backing up claims with facts and being honest about their sustainability efforts.

site_title: Unemployment benefits proposal 'interesting to watch' due to past policy resistance
summary: Singapore's government is considering introducing unemployment benefits for professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) amid economic restructuring and the Covid-19 pandemic. A joint taskforce between the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) has proposed the benefits as part of 9 recommendations to support PMEs. The benefits would need to be triggered at the right time, have a suitable quantum, and duration, while also being mindful of not disincentivizing work. The proposal signals a shift in perception, with industry observers noting that past policy resistance has been due to concerns about the disincentive effect on work ethics.

site_title: Discreet treatment for sex health issues
summary: Two new telemedicine startups aim to provide discreet treatment for sex health issues, addressing the frustration and embarrassment faced by men and women in seeking help from healthcare staff. Dr. Chan, a general practitioner, notes that long wait times and insensitive staff are major deterrents. These startups offer a more private and accessible way for individuals to receive affordable treatment, potentially improving mental health outcomes.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollar slip from highs
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars slipped from their highs, while the US dollar fell against the yen, as profit-taking occurred following a strong rally. The yen reversed its recent losses versus the Australian dollar, with the Aussie reaching its strongest level since 2018. Analysts attribute the reversal to weakness in Asian equities and a pullback in risk appetite, but expect the pullback to be temporary.

site_title: Covid-19, climate change to dominate Apec ministers' meeting
summary: Apec ministers will meet virtually on Oct 22 to discuss recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic and addressing climate change. Despite economic activity recovering across the region, new variants of the virus and varying rates of recovery between countries pose challenges. The meeting will also focus on economic challenges, fiscal policy, and sustainable growth, as well as reviewing 10-year arrangements for fiscal reforms and commitments to trade and sustainable growth by 2040. Climate change and phasing out fossil fuel subsidies are expected to be key agenda items.

site_title: Soaring prices dampen consumer mood in India's festival season
summary: India's Diwali festival season is being dampened by soaring prices, with millions of households facing strains on their budgets. Petrol and cooking gas prices have risen nearly 35% and 50% respectively, affecting over three-quarters of households. Many are cutting back on spending on big-ticket items such as TVs and jewelry, and even reducing meat consumption. Economists say the government's options are limited, and cutting fuel taxes could help alleviate the pain, but may also impact corporate earnings.

site_title: Qantas prepares planes for Sydney's international reopening
summary: Qantas is preparing its international fleet for the reopening of Sydney to fully vaccinated citizens and permanent residents without quarantine on November 1. Most Qantas planes have already been doing limited flying on cargo and repatriation flights, with the exception of its Airbus A380 super-jumbos stored in California. The airline expects to resume flights to London, Los Angeles, and other destinations from Sydney in November, with a total of 8 A380s returning to service by July 2022. Qantas has lost A$20 billion in revenue due to the pandemic, but expects a boost in travel demand.

site_title: Evergrande secures bond extension as chairman foots project bills
summary: Evergrande Group secured a 3-month extension on a defaulted $260 million bond by agreeing to provide extra collateral and Hui Ka Yan pumping in personal wealth into a Chinese residential project. The deal offers respite to the developer after a failed $2.6 billion stake sale in its property services unit. Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan's personal wealth will be used to ensure the project's completion, paving the way for bondholders to receive their dues.

site_title: G-20 split over coal, global warming limit ahead of Rome summit: sources
summary: The Group of 20 (G-20) nations are divided over phasing out coal and limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius ahead of the Rome summit, with major polluters like China and India resisting commitments. Despite recognizing the goal, progress has been slow, and the Rome summit may not see breakthroughs. Key absent leaders include China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin, who have not committed to net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The G-20's failure to agree on emissions curbs may hinder success at the upcoming COP 26 climate talks in Glasgow.

site_title: House for creatives
summary: A 4-storey townhouse in Singapore's Watten Estate is a unique blend of home and art gallery, designed by interior designer Charles Chai for oral and maxillofacial surgeon Tay Suan Chiang and his family. The 3,110-square-foot space features artworks by Chiang and his teenage daughter, while maintaining a cosy feel. Chai balanced the line between home and gallery, incorporating natural light, light wood accents, and a soft neutral colour palette. The design also weaves together the family's interests in art, reading, and dining, creating a versatile and intimate space that feels like a home.

site_title: Thailand scraps mortgage lending cap to support fragile economy
summary: Thailand's central bank has temporarily suspended mortgage lending limits to revive the country's sluggish property market and pandemic-hit economy. The Bank of Thailand allows homebuyers to take loans equivalent to 100% of the property's value until the end of 2022, up from 70-90% previously. This move is expected to boost real estate developers' shares and stimulate the economy.

site_title: Tokyo to lift curbs on most bars, restaurants
summary: Tokyo is set to lift restrictions on most bars and restaurants, allowing establishments that meet health and safety criteria to serve alcohol until 8 pm and stay open until 9 pm. The move follows a decline in coronavirus cases in the city. Approximately 85% of Tokyo's eateries have already met the requirements, including installing perspex screens and adequate ventilation. The decision aims to boost the economy, which has been impacted by ongoing restrictions.

site_title: US existing-homes sales rise 7%, the most in a year
summary: US existing-homes sales rose 7% in September, the largest gain in a year, with an annualized 6.29 million contract closings. This increase suggests a slight easing in home-price growth. Mortgage rates, which had been declining, rose last week, potentially impacting demand. Despite this, buyer demand remains strong, with the median selling price of an existing house increasing 13.3% year-over-year to $352,800. The available homes are selling quickly, with properties remaining on the market for an average of 17 days.

site_title: Point system for Employment Pass can signal what market needs: analysts
summary: Singapore is considering implementing a point system for Employment Passes (EPs) to signal market needs and enhance transparency. The system would award points for set criteria, including non-salary factors, to make the approval process more transparent and efficient. Industry experts, including economists and business leaders, support the idea, citing benefits such as greater differentiation between individuals and firms, and providing market signals on in-demand skills. However, concerns remain about the potential for increased bureaucracy and the need for industry consultation to ensure the system is effective and compliant with free-trade agreements.

site_title: Private equity's strange love affair with hydra-headed leadership
summary: Private equity firms continue to use the dual model of co-chief executives, despite its potential for conflict and power struggles. This approach, which originated in the early days of the industry, has been used by firms such as KKR, Carlyle, and TPG Capital. While some argue that dual leadership can help smooth transitions and reduce internal rivalry, others claim it can lead to difficulties in making decisions and allocating resources. As one partner noted, the outcome of succession transitions is often "determined more by struggles for power than elegant process." Despite the persistence of this model, many predict an eventual shift towards single leadership, citing the benefits of clear executive authority and responsibility under independent boards and chairs.

site_title: Hostile tech: the good, the bad and the iffy
summary: Hostile tech encompasses not only malicious attacks but also unintentional harm caused by technology decisions that fail to consider diverse stakeholder groups, including environmental and equity issues. The problem lies in the lack of consideration for these impacts during the development process. To address this, organisations must adopt a responsible tech mindset, explicitly thinking about the "invisible" stakeholders that could be impacted by technology decisions. This includes considering data bias, accessibility, and sustainability. By asking the right questions and making clear statements about their values and intentions, organisations can reduce hostile tech experiences and build an equal, accessible digital world for all.

site_title: 16 more Covid-19 deaths in Singapore; 3,439 new infections
summary: Singapore reported 16 more Covid-19 deaths, bringing the total death toll to 280, with 12 men and 4 women aged 61-93 dying from complications linked to the virus. There were 3,439 new infections, including 2,937 in the community, 500 in migrant worker dormitories, and 2 imported cases. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 162,026.

site_title: Citigroup Asia assets set to attract DBS, StanChart: sources
summary: DBS and Standard Chartered are among the lenders planning to bid for Citigroup's consumer banking assets in Asia, as the US lender divests units across 5 markets in the region. Binding bids for retail assets in Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Thailand are due, while offers for the India unit are due next week. The sales offer a chance to scale up high-end credit card and wealth businesses, with potential valuations ranging from $1 billion to $4 billion. Citigroup plans to raise $150 billion in new money and hire 2,300 staff in Asia for wealth management by 2025.

site_title: After 16 months of talks, UK and NZ strike free trade deal
summary: The UK and New Zealand have reached a free trade deal after 16 months of negotiations. The agreement will eliminate tariffs on 97% of products, boost New Zealand's GDP by almost NZ$1 billion, and take the UK closer to joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). The deal, sealed by Prime Ministers Boris Johnson and Jacinda Ardern, aims to improve services trade and reduce barriers to trade between the two nations. The agreement comes as the UK seeks to diversify its trade ties post-Brexit and align with its foreign policy push in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Freight rates to continue uphill climb into 2022
summary: Freight rates are expected to remain high into 2022, with rates stabilizing at 50% higher than 2019 levels. The Shanghai Containerised Freight Index has climbed to 4,558.07 points, exceeding 3,000 points for the first time in over a decade. Peak season periods, including the Chinese New Year, will continue to drive elevated rates. Industry experts, including Flexport and McKinsey, attribute the surge to strong demand, tight supply, and equipment imbalances. Air freight rates are also expected to remain high, with e-commerce and healthcare driving volumes.

images.alt_text: FREIGHT rates will likely continue their upward trajectory into traditional peak sales periods and even when shipping rates "normalise", they are unlikely to be at the rates seen in 2019.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims drop to 19-month low
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped to a 19-month low of 290,000 for the week ended Oct 16, according to the Labor Department. This is the lowest level since March 2020 and the second straight week below 300,000 claims. The decline suggests a tightening labor market, but a shortage of workers may keep hiring moderate in October. Initial claims have declined from a record high of 6.149 million in early April 2020.

site_title: Palm oil surges to fresh all-time high on edible oils shortage
summary: Palm oil futures surged to a fresh record high due to a shortage of edible oils and an extended rally in petroleum. Prices rose 2.9% to RM5,220 a tonne, amid tight supply and external support from energy markets. Malaysia's palm oil production fell behind expectations, with yields only showing a year-on-year improvement towards the end of 2021. Analysts predict prices will continue to rise until policies are implemented to cool the commodity market, such as higher interest rates.

site_title: Among chardonnays, Chablis is not better, just different
summary: A recent wine tasting of Chablis from the 2019 vintage revealed that Chablis is distinct from other chardonnays, with a unique stony, chalky minerality. Contrary to popular perception, Chablis is not inherently buttery or oaky, but rather a product of its terroir and the winemaking process. The 2019 vintage, influenced by cooler weather, produced wines with a more characteristic Chablis flavor profile. Oak use in winemaking is not inherently bad, but rather a matter of technique. Ultimately, the issue lies with the producer, not the grape or container, with many problems in wine attributed to human error rather than the wine itself.

images.alt_text: Vintages can affect the character of a wine, and this can be especially telling with a wine like Chablis.

site_title: Pinterest deal to top charts in tech's US$1 trillion M&A
summary: PayPal is reportedly discussing a $45 billion acquisition of Pinterest, which would be the largest tech takeover this year, surpassing Square's $29 billion purchase of Afterpay and Microsoft's $20 billion deal for Nuance Communications. This deal would push tech M&A volumes past the $1 trillion mark for the first time, following a record-breaking year for tech deals, with $971 billion in M&A announcements so far this year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall for a 2nd day as mood sours over Evergrande
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.19% for a second day, weighing on investor sentiment due to concerns over China's property sector and Evergrande's financial strains. Despite this, preliminary trade data showed a 36.1% surge in exports for the first 20 days of October, easing supply-chain concerns. Foreigners were net buyers of 42.4 billion won worth of shares. The benchmark Kospi rose 4.66% this year but lost 6% in the previous 30 sessions.

site_title: Sustainability lessons from Helsinki's climate moonshot
summary: Helsinki, Finland, has implemented a "moonshot" approach to sustainability, aiming to become carbon-neutral by 2025, with a focus on transforming its district heating system. The city's then-mayor, Jan Vapaavuori, launched the Helsinki Energy Challenge in 2020, which attracted over 250 proposals from international groups. Four winning proposals, including a design firm, adopted a patient and systemic approach to accelerate the city's green transition. Helsinki's success offers lessons to the world, including the importance of balancing competition with collaboration and devising new ways to materialize innovation, particularly in the face of the climate crisis.

site_title: Europe: Miners pull London's FTSE 100 lower, Unilever gains
summary: London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.5% on Thursday due to miners' decline, driven by China's property sector troubles and concerns over rate hikes. Anglo American and other miners slid 2.4-4.2% despite production growth. Unilever gained 1.2% after beating sales growth forecasts, while engineering firm Renishaw rose 11.7% after reporting a 146% profit rise.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat, IBM results weigh on technology stocks
summary: US stocks remained flat on Thursday as losses in IBM pressured technology stocks, with investors monitoring supply chain disruptions and labor shortages. The Dow Jones Industrials Average retreated after hitting a record high, while the S&P 500 index fell short of its September record. Technology stocks, including IBM, were the biggest losers, with analysts expecting a 33.7% profit increase for S&P 500 companies. Mega-cap stocks like Tesla and Facebook rose, while Apple and Amazon were mixed.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Freshfields working on possible Porsche IPO
summary: Goldman Sachs and law firm Freshfields are advising on a possible initial public offering (IPO) of Porsche, Volkswagen's luxury unit, according to a report. The move could unlock tens of billions of euros in value, with Porsche's enterprise value estimated at around 75 billion euros. Volkswagen's CEO Herbert Diess has stated that a planned battery ramp-up is the priority, but the company continues to review options for a potential separation or listing. No decision has been made on whether the IPO will happen, but the news has prompted a 3% rise in Volkswagen shares.

site_title: Tesla looks to pave the way for Chinese battery makers to enter US
summary: Tesla plans to adopt iron-based lithium phosphate (LFP) batteries, considered cheaper and safer, but lacks energy density, in its standard-range vehicles globally. The company aims to localise battery production closer to its US factories, but faces challenges due to ongoing US-China disputes over tariffs, intellectual property rights, and regulatory crackdowns. China dominates LFP battery production, and patents are set to expire soon. Tesla's move is seen as a strategic shift, with Apple also exploring LFP batteries, but US-based battery makers are also investing in alternative technologies to challenge China's dominance.

site_title: Ferrari SF90 Assetto Fiorano review: A prime asset to own
summary: The Ferrari SF90 Assetto Fiorano is a high-performance hybrid supercar that redefines the brand's legacy. With 1,000 horsepower and a 6.7-second 0-200kmh acceleration, it's a game-changer. The Assetto Fiorano trim features a fixed setup, stripped-down cabin, and a pop-down rear wing, making it a track-focused machine. Despite its complexity, the SF90 delivers a seamless driving experience, thanks to its advanced hybrid system and sophisticated computing power. With a base price of over $2 million, it's a luxurious and exclusive ride that embodies Ferrari's commitment to innovation and performance.

images.alt_text: A leading Financial Times journalist has been given seven days to leave Hong Kong as a backlash mounted on Monday against an unprecedented challenge to freedom of the press in the city.

site_title: Unilever's finance chief sees little let-up in inflationary pressures next year
summary: Unilever's finance chief expects inflation to accelerate next year, potentially impacting consumer goods companies' ability to offset rising energy and other costs through price hikes. The company beat Q3 sales growth forecasts and maintained its full-year profit margin guidance, defying analyst fears of a cut. Despite a 2.5% underlying sales rise, Unilever's volumes declined due to stringent lockdowns in South-east Asia, where the company is highly dependent. Analysts say this makes it a tougher task for Unilever to cope with inflationary pressures compared to competitors like Nestle.

images.alt_text: Unileiver, the maker of Ben & Jerry's ice cream, says underlying sales rose 2.5 per cent in the 3 months ended Sep 30, above the 2.2 per cent forecast by analysts in a company supplied consensus.

site_title: Foodpanda partners with Indian cloud kitchen firm Rebel Foods
summary: Foodpanda, a Singapore-based online takeaway delivery firm, has partnered with Indian virtual kitchen company Rebel Foods to roll out its virtual restaurant brands at 2,000 outlets across 10 Asian countries. Rebel Foods, valued at $1.4 billion, offers multiple cloud kitchen brands, and the partnership aims to expand Foodpanda's offerings and compete with rival companies like Deliveroo and Grab Holdings. This deal is part of Foodpanda's strategy to expand into grocery delivery and cloud kitchens, and is seen as the largest virtual food brand partnership of its kind.

site_title: Singapore has financial leverage to pressure Myanmar: US official
summary: A senior US official, Derek Chollet, stated that Singapore has significant financial leverage to pressure Myanmar's military rulers to return to democracy. The US has imposed sanctions on individuals and entities associated with the military. Chollet emphasized the importance of regional partnerships in pressuring Myanmar, which risks becoming a "failed state in the heart of Asia."

site_title: China sets 2025 efficiency goals for energy-intensive industries
summary: China has set 2025 efficiency goals for energy-intensive industries such as steel, aluminum, cement, and oil refining, aiming for over 30% of production capacity to meet tighter energy efficiency standards. The goals are part of China's plan to peak carbon emissions by 2030 and become carbon neutral by 2060. Industries must cut energy consumption by specific percentages, with some plants to be permanently shut down or restructured. The move aims to consolidate capacity and reduce energy consumption, helping China meet its climate goals.

site_title: Shares of Malaysia glove maker Supermax sinks after US seizes goods over forced labour
summary: Malaysia-based glove maker Supermax's shares plummeted 8.9% after the US Customs and Border Protection ordered personnel to seize its latex gloves due to alleged use of forced labor. The US identified 10 of the 11 International Labor Organization indicators of forced labor, prompting Supermax to speed up compliance with ILO standards. The company had begun working on compliance since 2019 and plans to divert affected shipments to other markets. Other glove makers, including Top Glove and Hartalega Holdings, also declined in value following the news.

site_title: Singapore employment agency hacked, IC scans and salaries of 40,000 job seekers uploaded online
summary: A cyber attack on Protemps Employment Services in Singapore has leaked the personal details of approximately 40,000 job applicants, including identity card scans, phone numbers, salaries, and home addresses. The hackers, known as Desorden Group, claimed responsibility and uploaded the stolen files online, demanding a ransom. The incident has been reported to the Personal Data Protection Commission, and Protemps' website has been partially restored. The attack is believed to be the work of the Desorden Group, a known hacking group targeting supply chain organizations, and the stolen data is currently being sold on the black market.

site_title: Ya Kun outlet in Nanjing under investigation over Taiwan issue
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) is investigating a Singapore coffee chain, Ya Kun Kaya Toast, in Nanjing over listing Taiwan as a country in its promotional material. The outlet in Nanjing's Golden Eagle shopping mall was ordered to close after netizens complained. Ya Kun's other two Nanjing outlets are not under investigation. This incident is part of China's crackdown on corporations referencing Taiwan, with similar punishments given to Japanese retailer Muji in 2018. The outcome of the investigation will determine if the Nanjing outlet can reopen for business.

site_title: Sabana Reit records 85.3% portfolio occupancy in Q3, drops Shari'ah compliance
summary: Sabana Reit achieved its highest portfolio occupancy of 85.3% as of September 30, driven by multi-tenanted properties and its new lifestyle mall NTP+. The Reit has also diversified its risk profile, with 86.7% of gross rental income coming from multi-tenanted properties. A new CFO and head of real estate were appointed, and the Reit completed a refinancing exercise, securing up to S$225 million in unsecured term and revolving loan facilities. The Reit's aggregate leverage remains at 34.8%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.70 points to 1,591.62. The market saw a 753-349 loss-gain ratio. Volume reached 3.856 billion lots worth RM3.476 billion.

site_title: US bars Malaysian glove maker Supermax over alleged labour abuses
summary: The US has barred imports from Malaysian glove maker Supermax Corp over alleged forced labour practices, the fourth Malaysian firm to face such a ban in the past 15 months. The decision targets factories that make medical gloves, iPhone components, and other products. This move comes as Malaysian factories face increasing scrutiny over allegations of abuse of foreign workers, who form a significant part of the manufacturing workforce.

images.alt_text: Malaysian factories - which make everything from palm oil to medical gloves and iPhone components - have increasingly come under scrutiny over allegations of abuse of foreign workers.

site_title: Thailand scraps mortgage lending cap to support fragile economy
summary: Thailand's central bank temporarily suspended home-mortgage lending limits to revive the sluggish property market and pandemic-hit economy. Home buyers can now take loans equivalent to 100% of the property's value until the end of 2022, up from a 70-90% loan-to-value range previously. The move aims to boost the property sector, which accounts for 9.8% of Thailand's economy and employs 2.8 million people. The Bank of Thailand believes the move will not exacerbate household debt, as it mainly stems from personal loans and credit card spending.

site_title: US consumer watchdog to query tech giants over financial data: sources
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) plans to send a 55-page request for information to tech giants including Facebook, Amazon, and Google, inquiring about their handling of consumer financial data. This follows the arrival of new director Rohit Chopra, who has emphasized boosting consumer protections and financial sector competition. The request aims to inform the development of an open banking rule, which would require financial companies to give consumers more control over their financial data. The CFPB's move is seen as a signal that these companies may be subject to future regulation.

site_title: STI slips 0.3% as China property sector appears to weigh on regional sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 9.58 points or 0.3% to 3,188.50 points, affected by the China property sector and Evergrande's impact on regional sentiment. Analysts attributed the decline to Evergrande's weak performance and the overnight weak Nasdaq performance. Several STI stocks, including UOB, OCBC, and DBS, closed lower, while builder King Wan rose 11.77% after announcing a joint venture. The market's turnover was S$964.14 million over 1.9 billion securities, with decliners beating gainers marginally.

site_title: IMF appoints Singaporean Shirin Hamid as chief information officer
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has appointed Singaporean Shirin Hamid as its chief information officer and director of the information technology department, effective January 4, 2022. Hamid will modernize the digital workplace and oversee capital improvements. Her previous roles include stints at the Asian Development Bank, United Nations Development Programme, and Keppel Group. The appointment is seen as a critical move by IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva to address digital transformation and modernization efforts.

site_title: China vows to keep property curbs; Evergrande risk seen limited
summary: China's banking regulator reaffirmed its property market curbs, dismissing concerns that the Evergrande crisis will impact the sector's credit profile. The regulator stated that the property controls have achieved good results and will not be used as a short-term economic stimulus measure. Evergrande is considered an "individual" case, and its risk is seen as limited to the overall Chinese economy. Property lending growth at Chinese banks slowed to 8.6% in the first nine months of the year, and new-home prices in 70 cities fell 0.08% in September, the first drop in six years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 0.45% due to China Evergrande's resumption of trading after a 17-day suspension. Evergrande's planned sale of its property services unit fell through, and it warned of struggling to meet its debt obligations. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.22%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.16%. Evergrande's shares ended down over 12%.

site_title: Barclays third-quarter profit doubles amid global merger frenzy
summary: Barclays reported a doubling of third-quarter profits to £2 billion, beating market expectations, driven by bumper investment banking fees and a strong performance in its US business. The bank's advisory and equities business had a record performance, with a 16.4% return on equity. CEO Jes Staley expressed optimism about the UK economy, despite concerns over inflation, and upgraded its economic forecasts, predicting the country's GDP to hit pre-pandemic levels by early 2022.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: PSA Singapore ramps up resources to ease global supply chain disruptions by reopening berths and adding thousands of workers. Ryde Technologies meets Land Transport Authority requirements for ride-hail and car pool services. A Standard Chartered study reveals a widening gap in financial confidence and risk appetite among Singapore's affluent during the pandemic. Grab Financial Group expands merchant services and DBS launches a new "traveller kit" with over 700,000 travel deals. The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.3% due to China's property sector weighing on regional sentiment.

site_title: Micron's US$150b global expansion plan aims to capture demand for memory
summary: Micron Technology plans to invest over $150 billion globally over the next decade to boost memory manufacturing and research. Despite potential easing of pandemic-driven demand, memory and storage space is expected to continue growing exponentially due to secular growth drivers like 5G and AI. This growth is expected to expand usage in automotive and user devices, with memory and storage currently representing 30% of the global semiconductor market.

site_title: ABB downgrades 2021 sales forecast on supply shortages
summary: ABB, a Swiss engineering group, downgraded its 2021 sales forecast to 6-8% growth due to global semiconductor shortages. Initially, the company expected 10% growth as the economy recovered from the pandemic. Third-quarter orders rose 29% to $7.9 billion, but sales only increased 7% to $7 billion, below expectations. Supply chain constraints, mainly related to semiconductors, impacted revenues, and the company reported an 86% profit slump to $652 million.

site_title: Energy price spike is bad news for emerging Asian economies: Report
summary: A recent report by BNP Paribas warns that the energy price spike will have a negative impact on emerging Asian economies, despite containing inflation risks. Energy exporters Indonesia and Malaysia will benefit from higher oil prices, but Thailand is expected to be significantly affected due to its dependence on oil imports and a large negative oil balance. The report notes that higher oil prices will lower growth, worsen trade accounts, and raise producer prices across Asia, even affecting energy exporters. Fuel subsidies in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand may spare consumers but burden fiscal accounts.

site_title: Prices hikes help Unilever top sales forecast, keep margin goal
summary: Unilever reported a 2.5% increase in underlying sales in the third quarter, beating forecasts, despite a 1.5% decline in volumes due to higher prices. The company raised prices to cope with rising costs, including energy and edible oil prices. Unilever kept its full-year profit margin guidance, defying concerns of a cut, and its shares are down around 13% this year. The company's reliance on emerging markets, where inflationary pressures are fiercest, presents a tougher challenge.

site_title: URA launches Dairy Farm Walk GLS site for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 15,663.2 sqm residential site at Dairy Farm Walk for public tender, with a maximum gross floor area of 32,893 sq and expected yield of about 385 units. The site, under the confirmed list of the second half 2021 government land sales programme, is located in a quiet enclave near Hillview MRT station. The tender, set to close on March 8, 2022, is expected to attract up to 8 bidders and a top bid of between S$900 and S$1,000 psf ppr.

site_title: UK manufacturers raise prices by most since 1980
summary: UK manufacturers raised prices by the most since 1980 over the past three months, driven by rising raw material costs and labour shortages. The Confederation of British Industry's survey showed manufacturers face global supply challenges, with stocks at a record low and skilled labour shortages at their highest since 1974. The Bank of England may consider raising interest rates as soon as next month to combat inflation, which is expected to rise above 4% this year.

site_title: Deepening energy crisis boosts flurry of green IPOs in Europe
summary: Several European companies are going public to capitalize on the energy crisis, emphasizing their green credentials. Volvo, Ebusco, Pod Point, and Harmony Energy Income Trust are leading the charge, highlighting their electric and sustainable offerings. The surge in power and natural gas prices has accelerated the need for diversified energy sources, prompting investors to bet heavily on green assets. Governments have long pushed for sustainability, and these IPOs aim to contribute to a greener future. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for cleaner energy sources.

site_title: Labour market scarcity set to last years, says outgoing CEO of Randstad
summary: Labour market scarcity is expected to persist for years to come, according to Jacques van den Broek, outgoing CEO of Randstad. He attributes the shortage to demographic changes, with older employees leaving the workforce and fewer entering. In-demand jobs include healthcare, education, technology, and logistics. Despite his departure, Randstad reported a 50% increase in earnings before interest, taxation, and amortisation to 298 million euros, and a 21% rise in revenues to 6.3 billion euros for the third quarter.

site_title: Growing gap in financial confidence, risk appetite among Singapore's affluent: study
summary: A Standard Chartered study found that the COVID-19 pandemic has widened the gap among Singapore's affluent in financial confidence and risk appetite. Over 36% of affluent consumers feel the pandemic has diminished their confidence, with emerging affluent being the most hit, at 41%. The affluent are becoming more future-focused, with 43% prioritizing a comfortable retirement. However, there is a disconnect between current actions and future expectations, with 20% of respondents who haven't retired not starting to save for retirement, despite 42% relying on investment income.

site_title: Australia: Shares end almost flat as Evergrande worries weigh on miners
summary: Australian shares closed almost flat on Thursday, influenced by worries about China Evergrande Group's potential debt default. The benchmark index rose 0.02% to 7,415.4 points, despite a 0.25% decline in the metals and mining sector, which relies heavily on exports to China. Financials sector stocks, however, remained strong, adding 0.28% despite some banks ending lower. Melbourne's lockdown lifting and tech stocks' earnings-fueled rally also contributed to the market's stability.

site_title: DBS rolls out new travel deals as more VTLs go live
summary: DBS has launched a new "traveller kit" for its card holders featuring over 700,000 travel deals and discounts, including 15% off worldwide hotel bookings and accelerated earn rates on online flights and hotels. The move comes as more vaccinated travel lanes (VTLs) open to 9 countries, including the UK and US, with traffic into DBS's travel portal doubling in the first 2 weeks of October. This is part of a broader trend of increased demand for travel deals as holiday-starved consumers look for deals amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Stocks head lower on Evergrande woes, mixed earnings
summary: European stocks fell 0.4% due to concerns over China's property sector and mixed quarterly results. The Stoxx 600 index retreated from its highest level in 6 weeks, with miners, automakers, and industrial stocks leading the decline. ABB and AB Volvo were among the biggest losers, citing component shortages, while Unilever rose 1.2% after beating sales growth forecasts. The losses came ahead of a slate of corporate earnings and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: China developers rally as regulators' remarks boost confidence
summary: Chinese developers led stock gains in Shanghai and Hong Kong after regulators stated that their funding needs are being met, easing concerns over policies affecting industry giants like China Evergrande Group. Vice-Premier Liu He and central bank deputy governor Pan Gongsheng said risks in the property market are controllable, and financing is becoming normal. This boosted confidence in the sector, with property shares adding at least 2% on Thursday, and led to a recommendation to buy shares of several developers, including Sunac China Holdings and Poly Developments. Regulators downplayed concerns over the Evergrande crisis.

images.alt_text: Chinese developers led stock gains in Shanghai and Hong Kong after regulators said their funding needs are being met, soothing concerns over policies that have made industry giants like China Evergrande Group suffer.

site_title: Crypto market tops US$2.7t as rally reaches beyond Bitcoin
summary: The cryptocurrency market has reached an all-time peak of over $2.7 trillion, driven by optimism about digital assets and the recent surge in Bitcoin's value. Bitcoin hit a record high of almost $67,000 before dipping below $65,000, while Ether rose 3.3% to within striking distance of its highest value of almost $4,400. Strategists predict Bitcoin will breach $100,000 by year-end, and the market's bullish sentiment is expected to continue, despite the potential for a reversal in Bitcoin's price.

images.alt_text: Optimism about digital assets stoked by Bitcoin's run to a record high has helped push the overall value of cryptocurrencies to an all-time peak of more than US$2.7 trillion.

site_title: China Evergrande Group secures extension for US$260m bond: REDD
summary: China Evergrande Group secured an extension of its US$260 million bond, which matured on October 3, after agreeing to provide extra collateral. The extension period is more than three months. The agreement was reached with bondholders early this week. Evergrande did not comment on the matter. The move comes as the company faces financial struggles and debt issues.

site_title: Top ByteDance investor weighs US$500 million stake sale
summary: Susquehanna International Group, a top investor in ByteDance, is selling about $500 million of its shares in the TikTok owner, valuing the company at over $400 billion. The sale comes as China's tech crackdown intensifies, with ByteDance facing scrutiny over its algorithms and data security. Despite its massive valuation, the company has repeatedly said it's not ready for an initial public offering. The sale will represent a small portion of Susquehanna's overall holdings, which could deliver one of the highest returns in venture capital investment history.

images.alt_text: Susquehanna International Group, one of ByteDance's earliest and largest backers, is looking to sell about US$500 million of its shares in the TikTok owner, seeking to diversify its portfolio during China's tech crackdown and profit from the startup's growth.

site_title: New Zealand to make banks report climate impact
summary: New Zealand has passed a law requiring banks to disclose the climate impact of their investments starting next year. The law, described as a world-first, aims to increase transparency in the financial sector's environmental record. Climate Change Minister James Shaw said the disclosures will outline the real-world consequences of investment choices, encouraging entities to become more sustainable. New Zealand is the first country to introduce mandatory climate-related reporting for the financial sector.

site_title: Bitcoin edges off all-time high but momentum for more gains this year seen intact
summary: Bitcoin fell 1.3% to $65,184 after reaching an all-time high of $67,016, but momentum for further gains remains intact. Analysts attribute the surge to the launch of the first US bitcoin futures ETF, which is expected to attract more retail and institutional investors. Despite concerns of overextension, some predict Bitcoin could reach $80,000 to $90,000 by the end of the year. Meanwhile, smaller cryptocurrencies like Ether and altcoins saw gains, with average weekly flows to bitcoin funds increasing to $121.1 million in October.

site_title: Rich should pay for greater carbon footprint: study
summary: A study by the World Inequality Lab suggests that the richest 1% of the global population, who emit 110 tonnes of CO2 per head in 2019, should pay more tax to compensate for their greater carbon footprint. This would help governments invest in green infrastructure and reduce emissions. The study also found that the poorest 50% accounted for only 12% of global emissions, highlighting the disproportionate burden of climate policies on low-income consumers. Experts recommend progressive and ecological wealth taxes as a more politically sustainable solution.

site_title: Barclays beats Q3 expectations on bumper trading performance
summary: Barclays reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings with a profit before tax of £2 billion, driven by strong investment banking fees and advisory mandates. The bank's advisory and equities business saw its best performance on record, with a return on equity of 16.4%. Despite a turbulent economy, Barclays upgraded its UK economic forecasts, citing low default rates. The bank's CEO, Jes Staley, attributed the success to a consumer recovery and a favorable rate environment.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 1.8%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 1.87% or 546.97 points to 28,708.58, amidst rising US bond yields and China Evergrande's struggles. The broader Topix index fell 1.32% or 26.86 points to 2,000.81. The decline was attributed to various factors, including global economic uncertainty and market volatility.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up at Thursday's open tracking Wall Street gains: STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,200.14 on Thursday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The move comes as the country extended Covid-19 restrictions for four more weeks, but received additional support with a S$640 million package. Banking stocks were mixed, while tech stocks advanced. The US markets also rose, with the Dow and S&P 500 narrowly missing records.

site_title: Gold nudges higher as weaker US dollar lends support
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,784.96 per ounce, supported by a weaker US dollar. The metal has traded between $1,759 and $1,788 this week. Two US Federal Reserve officials said it's too soon for interest rate hikes, contradicting market expectations. Russia's gold reserves stood at 73.9 million troy ounces as of October, while its Nornickel, the world's largest palladium producer, reported a 9% increase in palladium production.

site_title: Melbourne readies to exit world's longest Covid-19 lockdown
summary: Melbourne is set to exit the world's longest Covid-19 lockdown after Victoria reached a 70% vaccination target, allowing for restrictions to ease. From Thursday, pubs and cafes can have 20 fully vaccinated patrons indoors and 50 outdoors, while hairdressers can allow entry for five customers. The city of 5 million has spent nearly nine months under stay-home orders, exceeding the 234-day lockdown in Buenos Aires. Daily infections rose to 2,232, but the city is preparing to welcome customers as businesses restock supplies.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up, Hong Kong swings as Evergrande sale fails
summary: Asian markets rose, with most indices up, despite Hong Kong's volatility and Evergrande's 12% decline after a failed property services sale. Positive US corporate earnings and a strong Wall Street lead contributed to the gains. The Dow and S&P 500 closed near record highs, while the Federal Reserve reported "significantly elevated prices" in the US. Evergrande warned it may default on a bond, raising concerns about the impact on the wider economy. Despite this, investors remained optimistic, with Bitcoin reaching a new record high of $66,976.

site_title: Asia-Pacific real estate investments up 30% in first 9 months of 2021: JLL
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investment volume increased 30% in the first 9 months of 2021 compared to the same period last year, reaching US$125 billion, according to JLL. Investors favored income-resilient assets in the office and logistics sectors. Despite ongoing unpredictability, the commercial real estate sector remains attractive and resilient, according to JLL's chief executive Stuart Crow.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.76 points lower, 0.17% down, at 1,603.56. Volume was 231.18 million lots worth RM151.18 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 198 to 187.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Oct 21, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.28% due to China Evergrande's 10% drop after a deal to sell a property services unit fell through. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.08%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat.

site_title: Ryde meets LTA's requirements for full ride-hail, car pool service licences
summary: Ryde Technologies has received full ride-hail and car pool service operator licences from Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA). The licences, valid for 3 years, follow Ryde's demonstration of meeting LTA's regulatory standards. Other operators, including Grab, Gojek, and ComfortDelGro, have also received full ride-hail licences. Ryde is the only other operator with a car pool service operator licence, held by Grab. This move marks an expansion of ride-hailing services in Singapore.

site_title: Grab Financial Group expands merchant services, offerings
summary: Grab Financial Group (GFG) is expanding its merchant services, including "buy now pay later" (BNPL) options, through new partnerships with payment gateways. The move aims to increase merchant adoption of its PayLater service, with a 3X increase in transactions in 5 months. GFG is competing in the highly competitive BNPL space, despite scrutiny from the Monetary Authority of Singapore over consumer debt risk. The company has also launched GrabMerchant Commerce, a platform to aid businesses in e-commerce.

site_title: Australia accuses China of undermining world trade
summary: Australia has accused China of undermining the World Trade Organization and failing to implement promised economic reforms. China has imposed sanctions on Australian exports, including dairy products and infant formula, which Canberra claims is a "politically motivated" move. The Australian government believes China's actions are inconsistent with its WTO commitments and threaten the multilateral trading system. This comes as China is set to mark 20 years of WTO membership, an event expected to bind China to Western-designed institutions and spur reform. China has vowed to accelerate market-opening efforts, but Australia remains skeptical.

site_title: Taskforce calls for tighter review process for employment pass, and for unemployment benefits for PMEs
summary: A joint taskforce of trade unions and employers in Singapore has submitted recommendations to the government to tighten the review process for Employment Pass (EP) applications and introduce unemployment benefits for Professionals, Managers, and Executives (PMEs). The taskforce suggests a point system to consider factors beyond education qualifications and salary, as well as differentiation in foreign worker access by occupations. The government is expected to consider these recommendations, which aim to enhance workplace fairness, strengthen the Singaporean core, and provide support for PMEs, especially older ones who are involuntarily unemployed.

site_title: Britain, New Zealand agree trade deal, including haka clause
summary: Britain and New Zealand have agreed on a comprehensive free trade deal, including provisions to protect the Maori cultural tradition of the haka. The deal, sealed after 16 months of talks, aims to prevent the haka from being misused and includes a commitment to recognize Ngati Toa's guardianship of the Ka Mate haka. The agreement will eliminate tariffs on British exports and imports, estimated to be worth £2.3 billion, and is seen as strengthening Britain's friendship with New Zealand and cementing London's ties in the Indo-Pacific.

site_title: Wilmar to post better Q3 performance on strong plantation, sugar mills segment: UOBKH
summary: Wilmar International is expected to post a stronger third-quarter profit due to better performance from its plantation, sugar mills, feed, and industrial products segments. The brokerage UOB Kay Hian forecasts core net profit of US$450-480 million, up from US$309 million in Q2 2021. The company's tropical oil division is expected to be a star performer, while the food products segment may struggle to meet its strong performance in 2020. Adani Wilmar's initial public offering is also on track, with a target listing in India by end 2021 or Q1 2022.

images.alt_text: The brokerage expects the agribusiness giant will post core net profit of between US$450 million and US$480 million, up from US$309 million in Q2 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to rising US bond yields, despite overnight gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.50% to 29,110.52, while the Topix index lost 0.27% to 2,022.25.

site_title: Maybank KE raises crude estimates on likely demand pick-up, tighter supply
summary: Maybank Kim Eng has raised its crude oil price estimates for 2021 and 2022 to US$70 and US$75-80 per barrel, respectively. The research house attributes this increase to stronger demand growth due to "revenge spending" post Covid-19 and tighter supply due to Opec+'s production policy. This could lead to further upside in 2022 if the global energy crunch worsens.

images.alt_text: Maybank Kim Eng is raising its in-house crude oil price estimates for 2021 and 2022 to US$70 and US$75-80 per barrel, respectively.

site_title: Australia should change laws to accommodate crypto: Senate report
summary: Australia should introduce new regulations for digital asset miners, including tax discounts and a licensing regime for crypto exchanges, to remain competitive with Singapore, the UK, and the US, according to a Senate report. The report also calls for clarity on bank rules regarding cryptocurrency involvement. Despite the sector's growth, many top financial institutions have not engaged with cryptocurrency due to its high risks. The report aims to address these issues and create a more favorable environment for the cryptocurrency sector in Australia.

site_title: Evergrande to resume trading after talks end on potential deal
summary: Chinese property giant Evergrande is set to resume trading in Hong Kong after a potential deal to sell a 50.1% stake in its property services arm fell through. The company had suspended trading on October 4 amid concerns over its $300 billion debt and warned it may struggle to meet financial obligations. Evergrande will implement measures to ease liquidity issues and has a 30-day grace period for an offshore note. The firm's collapse could have significant implications for the Chinese economy, which has been under tightened scrutiny due to a government clampdown on the property sector.

site_title: US bars Malaysian glove maker Supermax over alleged labour abuses
summary: The US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has barred imports from Malaysian glove maker Supermax Corp due to alleged forced labour practices at the company, citing 10 of 11 forced labour indicators. The ban, the fourth for a Malaysian firm in the past 15 months, follows similar allegations against Top Glove, Sime Darby Plantation, and FGV Holdings. Labour rights activist Andy Hall, who filed a petition, claims workers faced debt bondage, unlawful wage deductions, and cramped living conditions. Supermax's shares fell over 9% after the announcement.

site_title: Thai electronics sector to report powerful earnings growth after Q3: UOBKH
summary: Thailand's electronics sector is expected to report strong earnings growth in Q3 2021, driven by robust demand for 5G services and the electric vehicle trend. UOB Kay Hian projects a 21% year-over-year increase in sector sales to 35.5 billion baht, despite softer earnings growth due to lockdown restrictions and higher raw material prices. The brokerage notes that all electronic stocks under its coverage reported improved sales, with KCE Electronics and Hana Microelectronics outperforming the market.

site_title: Evergrande's US$2.6b unit stake sale fails as Chinese officials seek to calm nerves
summary: China Evergrande has abandoned plans to sell a $2.6 billion stake in its Evergrande Property Services arm to smaller rival Hopson Development Holdings due to concerns over the "prerequisite to make a general offer" being met. This move comes as Beijing officials sought to calm nerves about the property sector's troubles, with Vice Premier Liu stating the risks are controllable and authorities will handle default risks. Evergrande's debt-laden peers have faced credit rating downgrades, and the company is struggling to raise funds to pay its many lenders and suppliers.

site_title: China Evergrande shares plunge as unit sale deal falls through
summary: Chinese property giant Evergrande's shares plummeted 10.5% on Thursday after a unit sale deal fell through, deepening fears the company will collapse and send shockwaves through China's economy. Evergrande has $300 billion in debt and has missed several payments on dollar-denominated bonds. The company will continue to implement measures to ease liquidity issues, but a 30-day grace period on an offshore note is up on Saturday. Fears of a potential collapse have rattled markets and the Chinese economy, which has already shown signs of weakness, including a slowdown in economic growth and falling home prices.

site_title: Trump announces plans to launch new social network 'TRUTH Social'
summary: Former US President Donald Trump announced plans to launch his own social networking platform, TRUTH Social, which is expected to begin its beta launch for "invited guests" next month. The platform will be owned by Trump Media & Technology Group and will feature "non-woke" entertainment programming. The company will merge with Digital Acquisition Corp to become a publicly-listed company, valued at $1.7 billion. Trump aims to reclaim his internet platform after being banned from major social networks following the January 6 Capitol insurrection.

site_title: Asean should rethink non-interference policy amid Myanmar crisis: Malaysia foreign minister
summary: Malaysia's foreign minister, Saifuddin Abdullah, has called for Asean to rethink its non-interference policy due to the worsening human rights crisis in Myanmar. The bloc has excluded the leader of the junta from a regional summit, citing a lack of progress on a peace plan. Saifuddin argued that non-interference has hindered Asean's ability to make effective decisions, and suggested a new policy of constructive engagement or non-indifference. The move is seen as a rare bold step for Asean, which has traditionally favored consensus and engagement over criticism of member nations.

site_title: Bitcoin surges to all-time high in crypto's 'validating moment'
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high of $66,000, surpassing its previous April high, as optimism for mainstream acceptance grew following the launch of the first Bitcoin-linked exchange-traded fund (ETF) in the US. The fund's debut saw over 29 million shares change hands, with demand continuing to surge. The milestone is seen as a validating moment for the cryptocurrency market, with many quarters of Wall Street establishing a deeper skepticism about Bitcoin's role in finance.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin rallied to a record, topping US$66,000 for the first time as optimism surged for greater mainstream acceptance in the wake of the successful launch of the inaugural exchange-traded fund for US investors.

site_title: Nestle raises outlook again, shares surge higher
summary: Swiss food giant Nestle raised its growth outlook for the second time this year after nine-month sales beat expectations, with sales rising 2.2% to 63.3 billion Swiss francs. The company attributed the growth to coffee and vegetarian products, despite signaling further price increases due to rising input costs. Nestle's share price surged higher in response to the positive news, indicating consumers are willing to accept price hikes.

site_title: Qantas expects return to 100% of pre-pandemic domestic capacity by January
summary: Qantas expects to return to 100% of its pre-pandemic domestic capacity by January as Australian state borders reopen due to surging vaccination rates. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce stated that by Christmas, most states would be open, with Western Australia possibly opening in early February. This follows the airline's recovery from the pandemic, with a focus on domestic travel as international borders remain closed.

site_title: Supply bottlenecks, labour shortages slowed US growth: Federal Reserve
summary: The Federal Reserve's "beige book" report revealed that supply bottlenecks and labor shortages have slowed US economic growth, contributing to sharp price rises. Despite a modest to moderate increase in economic activity, supply chain disruptions, labor shortages, and uncertainty about the Delta variant of Covid-19 have constrained growth. The report cited child-care issues and vaccine mandates as contributing factors, leading employers to raise wages and offer incentives to retain workers. The Fed is expected to announce plans to pull back on stimulus measures amid concerns about rising inflation.

site_title: UK pay awards set to regain pre-pandemic pace: XpertHR
summary: Pay awards for British private-sector workers are expected to regain pre-pandemic pace, averaging 2.5% in the 12 months to August 2022, according to a survey by XpertHR. This increase is driven by recruitment and retention difficulties due to Brexit and labor shortages. The Bank of England is monitoring inflation pressure, and investors expect its next policy decision on November 4 to include the first interest rate hike since the pandemic. Annual pay awards typically lag behind headline pay growth, which has been inflated by workers returning from furlough.

site_title: PSA ramps up capacity, resources amid global logistics convulsion
summary: PSA Singapore ramps up resources and capacity to ease global supply chain disruptions amid the ongoing pandemic. The port has reopened berths at Keppel Terminal, added 2,500 workers, and started using yards at Tuas Port, increasing yard capacity by 2,000 TEUs. This move has helped mitigate delays, with global vessel schedule reliability averaging 35-40% this year, down from 75% in 2018-2020. Singapore has become a key port for shipping lines to catch up on lost time, with PSA assisting in rerouting ships and cargo during the Suez Canal blockage and China's Yantian port closure.

site_title: IMF urges training boost to handle pandemic job shift
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged European countries to boost training programs to address the pandemic-induced job shift. The tourism sector has been severely hit, while IT companies face recruitment challenges due to the shift to online shopping. The IMF recommends training assistance for vulnerable workers, especially those with low qualifications, and smaller companies, which often lack resources for training. The IMF also suggests incentives for companies to hire newly qualified workers and aid for workers to cushion wage losses, as automation is expected to continue and accelerate, putting pressure on the labor market.

site_title: More Britons struggling to pay their bills: poll
summary: A poll by Kantar Public found that 39% of Britons are struggling to meet their monthly budget, a 9% increase from the previous month. 62% are concerned about not being able to afford heating their homes this winter, up 9 points from September. British utility bills rose 12% earlier this month, with the Bank of England expected to raise interest rates soon due to inflation, now at 3.1%. The country's economy has also shrunk for the second month in a row.

site_title: Pinterest shares jump on reports of PayPal merger talks
summary: Pinterest shares jumped 14% to $63 per share after reports of possible takeover talks with PayPal. The companies discussed an acquisition price of $70 per share, valuing Pinterest at $44 billion. The talks come as Pinterest seeks to improve monetization and online payments. PayPal, which has more than doubled its market capitalization, is looking to expand through acquisitions. The news sent PayPal's stock down 5% to $258.

images.alt_text: Shares of Pinterest, a platform combining social networking and photo sharing, soared on Wednesday after reports of possible takeover talks by online payment service provider PayPal.

site_title: South Korea seeks space race entry with first home-grown rocket
summary: South Korea is set to launch its first fully homegrown rocket, the Korean Satellite Launch Vehicle II (Nuri), on Thursday, aiming to put a one-tonne payload into orbit and become the seventh country to achieve this feat. The three-stage rocket has been in development for a decade at a cost of $2.1 billion. A successful launch would mark a significant milestone for South Korea's space program, which has faced setbacks in the past, including a failed launch in 2010.

site_title: Citigroup Asia retail units set to attract DBS, StanChart: sources
summary: Citigroup is divesting its retail units in 5 Asian markets, including Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, and India, as part of its refreshed strategy. The US lender plans to raise $150 billion in new money and hire 2,300 staff in Asia for wealth management by 2025. Banks such as DBS, Standard Chartered, and Kotak Mahindra Bank are planning to bid for the assets, with potential sales valuing between $2 billion and $4 billion. The sales will allow buyers to scale up high-end credit card and wealth businesses in regions no longer aligned with Citigroup's strategy.

site_title: Spotify teams up with Shopify to allow in-app merch purchases
summary: Spotify has partnered with Shopify to enable in-app merchandise purchases, allowing artists to sell their merchandise directly to fans through Spotify. The service is available in the US, Canada, Australia, Britain, and New Zealand. This partnership comes after Shopify's similar deal with TikTok two months prior, aiming to empower artists to monetize their brands through commerce and expand their entrepreneurial ventures.

images.alt_text: Canadian e-commerce giant Shopify announced on Wednesday a partnership with music streaming giant Spotify that will allow in-app sales of artists' merchandise.

site_title: US authorises 'mix and match' Covid vaccine boosters: regulator
summary: The US FDA has authorized a "mix and match" strategy for Covid-19 vaccine boosters, allowing people to receive a booster shot from a different vaccine type, such as Pfizer, Moderna, or Johnson & Johnson. Eligible individuals include those 65 or older, high-risk groups, or those with occupational exposure. The decision comes after emerging research was reviewed by the FDA, and while it aims to boost public health, it also cautions against rare side effects associated with the vaccines.

site_title: Companies urged to tap resources to improve their HR capabilities
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng urges companies to tap resources to improve HR capabilities, citing the sector's central role in tackling Covid-19 challenges and transformation. The government has launched various resources, including a HR playbook for the food services sector and a free online tool to diagnose human capital strengths and weaknesses. The Institute for HR Professionals (IHRP) offers a national HR certification framework, Communities of Practices, and HR playbooks addressing specific challenges, aiming to support firms in driving strategic workforce planning, redesigning jobs, and developing talent.

site_title: Dollar steadies, risk appetite boosts Aussie, New Zealand dollars
summary: The US dollar remained steady against other currencies on Wednesday, after riskier currencies gained due to improved global risk appetite. The dollar index was unchanged at 93.819, following a decline to a one-year high last week. The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose 0.2% each, while the Canadian dollar gained 0.1%. The euro was flat, despite news of the European Central Bank's president quitting. The dollar's recent decline is attributed to a combination of market closures and a benign risk environment, with no clear catalyst to support its recovery.

site_title: Oil rallies as US crude stocks decline in tight market
summary: US crude stocks declined by 431,000 barrels, hitting their lowest level in three years, and nationwide fuel stocks fell sharply, signaling rising demand. Oil prices rallied, with Brent crude futures rising 0.9% to $85.82 a barrel and November WTI crude settling at $83.87. Supply remains tight, with refiners boosting output due to high margins. Analysts warn of potential concerns about a drop in inventories when refiners ramp up production to meet strong demand for petrol and distillate.

site_title: Covid-19 recovery poses dire climate, health risks: Lancet
summary: A major assessment by the Lancet Countdown warns that countries' fossil-fuel powered Covid-19 recoveries will exacerbate climate change-related health risks, food and water insecurity, heatwaves, and infectious diseases. Up to 19% of Earth's land mass was affected by extreme drought in 2020, and climate change poses a major threat to food security, affecting over 2 billion people. The report also finds that the global population of over-65s lived through 3.1 billion additional extreme heat days last year, and climate change is creating ideal conditions for infectious diseases such as dengue fever and malaria.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, Oxley, Hong Leong Asia, BH Global
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust acquired a 2-year-old logistics facility in South Korea for S$153.8 million, expected to boost e-commerce strength and generate a 4.2% net property income yield. Oxley Holdings provided a loan of S$15.7 million to its subsidiary Pindan Group, which will repay within 6 months. Hong Leong Asia's China Yuchai formed a joint venture to develop fuel cell powertrain systems, and BH Global clinched a contract for a hybrid bunker tanker's propulsion system.

site_title: Oil drops as China considers intervention to ease coal crunch
summary: China's efforts to ease a power shortage by ensuring coal mines operate at full capacity led to a drop in oil prices on October 20, 2021. Chinese coal and commodity prices plummeted, pulling oil prices down from an earlier uptick. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to tame record high coal prices and mitigate a power shortage.

site_title: Tesla profits surge on higher auto sales despite chip crunch
summary: Tesla's third-quarter profits surged 4,200% to a record $1.6 billion, driven by 57% revenue growth to $13.8 billion and a record 241,391 vehicle deliveries. Despite a global semiconductor shortage affecting the auto industry, Tesla's sales significantly ramped up in North America and China. The company's strong performance was attributed to higher auto sales, with sales in these regions showing notable growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit six-week highs as Nestle shines in mixed bag of earnings
summary: European shares reached six-week highs on Wednesday, driven by Nestle's strong earnings. The Swiss food giant's upbeat sales outlook, boosted by strong coffee sales and price hikes, lifted its stock 2.7%. Despite losses from Kering and ASML, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 0.3% higher. Oil stocks also contributed to gains as crude prices recovered slightly.

site_title: Australia to make permanent rules that allow firms to hold virtual AGMs: AFR
summary: Australia will introduce permanent rules allowing companies to hold virtual shareholder meetings and electronically distribute documents. The new rules, introduced during the COVID-19 pandemic, will give companies the flexibility to hold a mix of in-person and online meetings if shareholders are given a "reasonable opportunity to participate." The Federal Treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, will introduce the proposed legislation in parliament, citing the shift to online business during the pandemic. Companies can now email or post links to annual reports and other information instead of physically mailing them.

site_title: Lebanon's car culture questioned in crisis
summary: Lebanon's economic crisis is driving a shift away from car culture, with growing numbers opting for greener or collective transport options. The crisis has made petrol unaffordable, forcing many to rely on tuk-tuks, bicycles, carpooling, and affordable buses. Car imports have fallen by 70% over two years, and the local currency has lost 90% of its value against the US dollar. Start-ups like Hadeer, which provides affordable bus transport, are breaking stereotypes about mass transit and gaining popularity. The crisis is also prompting rethinking of traditional transportation models, with some residents embracing alternative modes of transport.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 rise again, nearing all-time records
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 rose on Wednesday, narrowly missing records, as investors became more confident in the economy despite inflation and supply chain concerns. A report from the Federal Reserve showed "significantly elevated prices" in the US, but corporate earnings eased worries. The latest batch of results showed that higher consumer prices may not derail the recovery. The Dow and S&P 500 edged to fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty and split views from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Of shots and supply-chain snarls
summary: The US supply chain is experiencing delays and shortages due to a surge in consumer demand, particularly for goods, which has outpaced services since April 2020. This demand spike is attributed to stimulus checks and the pandemic, resulting in a 34% rise in real personal consumption expenditures on durable goods over 13 months. To resolve the issues, emergency measures such as keeping ports open 24/7 and investments in infrastructure are proposed. However, the biggest solution lies in getting the pandemic under control by increasing vaccination rates, which can help undo the skewed demand and alleviate supply chain pressures.

site_title: Britain sets out net-zero strategy as it gears up to host COP26 climate talks
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled a 368-page net-zero strategy, aiming to lead the world in green economies and hosting the COP26 climate talks in Glasgow, Scotland. The strategy, set to be implemented by 2030, aims to secure 440,000 jobs and £90 billion in private investment, while powering the country entirely by clean electricity by 2035. It also targets 40 GW of offshore wind power and 5 GW of hydrogen production capacity, with plans to cut oil and gas emissions by half.

site_title: Rice set to climb as fertiliser rally drives up farm costs
summary: Thailand, the world's third-biggest rice exporter, is bracing for high fertiliser costs, which are on track to double from 2020. The current price of fertiliser in Thailand is 16,000 baht (S$644) per tonne, affecting rice farmers who need fertiliser for the upcoming planting season. This surge in fertiliser costs is attributed to a global energy crunch and is expected to raise costs for many farmers in the region, potentially prompting government intervention to boost farmer subsidies.

images.alt_text: Prices of Thai white rice 5% broken, a benchmark grade, have tumbled about 30 per cent from a February high.

site_title: Will Singapore employers be able to keep the Great Resignation at bay?
summary: Singapore's workforce may not be experiencing the same level of dissatisfaction as the US, with the seasonally-adjusted resignation rate holding steady at 1.6% for the first two quarters of 2021. Despite some polls suggesting that 49% of respondents in Singapore are considering leaving their current jobs due to feeling overworked and exhausted, actual resignations have remained low. The Manpower Ministry's Labour Market Report shows that the resignation rate is below pre-pandemic levels, with professionals and managers having the lowest rate at 1.3%.

site_title: China raises US$4b in US dollar bond after attracting strong demand
summary: China raised $4 billion in a US dollar sovereign bond issue, attracting $23.2 billion in bids, nearly six times the amount raised. The sale comes amid concerns about China's slowing economy and regulatory crackdown, as well as the debt problems of developer Evergrande Group. Despite these issues, finance ministry officials assured investors that Evergrande posed no systemic risk. The bond offerings were priced at low spreads, the lowest ever for a Chinese sovereign bond issue, with yields ranging from 6 to 53 basis points above US Treasuries.

site_title: Indonesia's GoTo looks to shore up price ahead of mega-IPO
summary: Indonesia's GoTo Group is preparing for a mega-IPO worth over $28 billion, with Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund ADIA investing $400 million to secure early investors. The investment aims to avoid the IPO price surge and subsequent decline seen by Bukalapak, Indonesia's first e-commerce player, which fell 50% from its IPO price. GoTo's CEO Andre Soelistyo believes the investment underlines Indonesia and South-east Asia as emerging tech destinations. ADIA's investment also highlights the growth of the digital economy in the region.

images.alt_text: GoTo was formed in May after a merger of ride-hailing giant Gojek and e-commerce firm PT Tokopedia.

site_title: Global tax agreement unlikely to meet 'ambitious' time frame: experts
summary: A global tax agreement aimed at setting a floor for tax rates and dismantling digital services taxes is unlikely to meet its "ambitious" time frame, say tax experts. The agreement, reached by 136 of 140 countries, includes two pillars: Pillar One, which reallocates profits from multinational enterprises to market jurisdictions, and Pillar Two, which imposes a global minimum tax rate of 15%. Implementation of the measures, including updating legislation and removing existing digital services taxes, is uncertain due to unclear timelines and potential resistance from some countries.

images.alt_text: The recent global agreement reached - to set a floor for tax rates and to dismantle digital services tax structures around the world - is not going to happen without much wrangling and unlikely to take place within the "extremely ambitious" time frame set by world leaders, say tax experts here.

site_title: Facebook planning to rebrand itself with new name, says The Verge
summary: Facebook is planning to rebrand itself with a new name, reportedly to focus on the metaverse, a digital world where people can interact in a virtual environment. The name change, set to be announced next week, would position the flagship app as one of many products under a parent company overseeing brands like Instagram and WhatsApp. This move comes amid scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers over Facebook's content moderation practices and harms linked to its platforms. The rebranding is seen as a way for Facebook to shift its focus towards the metaverse, a concept popularized by tech firms and popularized by games like Roblox and Fortnite.
