The added countries include France, Denmark, Italy, and Canada, following the initial VTLs announced for Brunei and Germany. This move is expected to boost travel to Europe and America, with the VTLs set to kick off on October 9.

site_title: Under new chief, Cognizant is aggressively hunting for acquisitions
summary: Cognizant Technology Solutions, a Nasdaq-listed consultancy, is aggressively pursuing acquisitions under new CEO Brian Humphries. Despite a 5% decline in stock price this year, the company has reported strong growth in revenue (14.6% in Q2) and bookings (12%). Net income and earnings per share have also increased. Humphries aims to grow digital services to 50% of revenue by the end of the year and is allocating half of free cash flow to fund acquisitions. However, the company faces challenges including high attrition rates (31% in Q2) and a management exodus.

site_title: Top Q4 stock picks: financials, property, reopening plays
summary: Phillip Securities' Q4 top 10 stock picks include financials and property sectors that are expected to perform well despite rising inflation. The research head, Paul Chew, attributes this to asset reflation, economic recovery, and rising interest rates. Stocks in these sectors are expected to benefit from these trends, providing a resilient portfolio for investors.

site_title: Tycoon behind a crisis-era property crash now mired in 8b euro debt morass
summary: Cevdet Caner, a wealthy businessman, is now mired in an 8 billion euro debt crisis with his company Adler Group. A former associate's email warned of a complex financial web to profit at other investors' expense, prompting major banks to investigate. Hedge funds have been targeting Adler, accusing it of "systemic dishonesty." Adler owes its creditors over 8 billion euros, with 600 million euros due in the next six months. The company's stock and bonds have slumped, and it's exploring potential asset sales. Caner denies any wrongdoing, but his ties to Adler and other companies have raised concerns about his influence and business practices.

site_title: Wall St could get 4 Bitcoin futures ETFs by month-end
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is set to approve 4 Bitcoin futures exchange-traded funds (ETFs) by month-end, following a format that SEC chair Gary Gensler has indicated could be favorable. The SEC has been reviewing applications for ETFs based on Bitcoin, with hopes that the approvals will bring the US$6.7 trillion ETF industry into the market. ProShares and Valkyrie Investments are among the issuers with a high chance of approval, following a format that offers higher investor protection.

site_title: Grace period of one week to be given before entry rules on unvaccinated people kick in
summary: Singapore to introduce a one-week grace period from Oct 13-19 for mall operators to familiarize themselves with differentiated safe management measures, including allowing unvaccinated individuals access to childcare and medical services. The measures aim to protect unvaccinated people and reduce strain on the healthcare system, with the goal of lowering transmission risks and slowing down community infections.

site_title: Singapore, US to deepen trade and business ties, will upgrade FTA: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong met with US Trade Representative Katherine Tai to deepen trade and business ties, including upgrading the 20-year-old US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA). Discussions focused on areas such as digital trade, environment, supply-chain resilience, and supporting workers. The two also co-chaired the Joint Committee Meeting of the FTA, aiming to refresh the agreement to reflect changes in the landscape. A partnership for growth and innovation was also signed, with plans to expand to other countries.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong and US Trade Representative Katherine Tai had "substantive discussions" in Washington on Friday (Oct 8), on advancing collaboration in areas such as digital trade, environment and the green economy, supply-chain resilience and ways to support workers.

site_title: CDL settles obligation for corporate guarantee relating to HCP Chongqing Property loan
summary: CDL settles a corporate guarantee obligation of US$213.1 million, exceeding its previous provision of US$213 million, related to a loan to HCP Chongqing Property Development. The settlement includes interest accrued and was made in relation to the divestment of Sincere Property Group. The move is not expected to have a material impact on CDL's financial performance for the year ending December 31, 2021.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for October 8-14, 2021, reveals a strong bull rally in the Capesize market, with the Capesize 5TC reaching a high of $86,953. The Atlantic basin saw a significant premium, while the Pacific basin softened. The Backhaul C16 increased by 16,175, and the Fronthaul C9 closed at $118,950. The Panamax market experienced further pressure, particularly in the Atlantic, with discounted rates agreed upon. The Ultramax/Supramax market remained steady, with demand from the US Gulf. The Handysize market saw gains, particularly in the US Gulf, but some felt the levels were reaching the bottom. The VLCC market was inactive due to holidays in the Far East, while the Suezmax market was active, with reports of a few fixtures. The Aframax market firmed up, with rates improving in the Mediterranean and Northern Europe.

site_title: Yellen confident Congress will pass global minimum tax
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed confidence that Congress will pass legislation to implement the global corporate minimum tax, agreed by 136 countries, as part of President Joe Biden's proposed spending initiatives. The tax deal aims to level the playing field and reallocate taxing rights on companies with over $20 billion in annual revenue. Yellen believes the measure will be included in a reconciliation package, which would allow Democrats to pass it without Republican votes, and implementation may not come until 2022.

site_title: Preparing youths for the workforce
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's global community initiative works with partners to prepare youths for the workforce. The bank's company secretary, Eileen Tay, poses a challenge to her mentee, Kenneth Tan, to describe himself, sparking a discussion about being future-ready. The initiative aims to equip youths with the skills needed to succeed in the workforce, aligning with the bank's corporate purpose. This effort is part of the bank's broader commitment to community development and youth empowerment.

site_title: 9 more Covid-19 deaths bring toll to 162 in Singapore; 2,809 new cases
summary: Nine more Singaporeans aged 70-88 have died from Covid-19 complications, bringing the total death toll to 162. The new cases total 2,809, with 2,176 in the community, 631 in migrant worker dormitories, and two imported cases. Daily new infection numbers have dipped for the first time after exceeding 3,000 for five consecutive days. The MOH attributes the drop to fewer swabs being done over the weekend.

site_title: Details of Singapore-US travel lane coming soon; FTA to be upgraded: Gan
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong announced that details of the country's travel lane with the US will be released soon, pending the resolution of operational issues. Gan also stated that Singapore is looking forward to deepening cooperation with the US on digital trade, environment, and supply chain resilience. The US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is set to be upgraded, with Gan emphasizing the need to refresh the agreement given the significant changes in the digital economy and the green economy.

site_title: US Trade Representative Tai, China's Liu discuss differences
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai and Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He met virtually to discuss trade issues, agreeing to consult on outstanding issues and address US concerns about China's state-led, non-market policies. The US plans to engage China over its performance on the Phase-One trade agreement, which was signed in 2020 and aims to reduce US tariffs on Chinese goods in exchange for increased purchases of American products. A planned virtual meeting between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping is also set for the end of the year, following a series of high-level talks.

site_title: Top fossil fuel lender JPMorgan joins UN climate action finance plan
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co, the largest US bank, has joined the UN's Net-Zero Banking Alliance, committing to reduce carbon financing and investment activities. The move comes ahead of the UN Climate Change Conference, COP 26, in Glasgow. JPMorgan must submit a science-based climate plan by 2023, with 2030 interim targets and transparent reporting. Critics argue the group's targets are too weak, but the bank's global head of sustainability said the move supports greater climate action and collaboration.

site_title: Singapore tightens rules for unvaccinated; simplifies testing protocols
summary: Singapore has tightened rules for unvaccinated individuals, effective Oct 13, restricting them from dining at eateries and shopping malls. The move aims to protect unvaccinated individuals and reduce strain on the healthcare system. The country will streamline its healthcare protocols, reserving PCR tests for symptomatic cases and using antigen rapid tests for individuals who are well. A revised quarantine system will also be introduced, with a focus on self-isolation and home recovery. The move is part of Singapore's strategy to live with Covid-19 endemically, with the goal of easing restrictions in a calibrated manner.

site_title: Singapore expands Vaccinated Travel Lanes to 11 countries including US, UK
summary: Singapore has expanded its Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) to 11 countries, including the US and UK, allowing fully vaccinated travelers to visit Europe and America without quarantine upon return. The new additions include France, Denmark, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Canada, and eight other countries, with the VTLs set to launch on October 19. This move aims to facilitate travel, reduce costs, and simplify testing protocols for vaccinated travelers. The expanded VTL network is expected to increase daily arrivals to up to 3,000 travelers, with Singapore's top trading partners and communities among the participating countries.

site_title: Australia braces for more Covid-19 infections as country moves towards reopening
summary: Australia prepares for increased Covid-19 cases as the country gradually eases pandemic restrictions. New South Wales, where Sydney is located, will lift some restrictions for fully vaccinated individuals starting Monday. Over 70% of the state's population has been fully vaccinated, with Premier Dominic Perrottet attributing the low case numbers to the high vaccination rate. As restrictions ease, officials warn that case numbers will increase, but the high vaccination rate is expected to keep people safe.

site_title: China presses US to cancel tariffs in test of bilateral engagement
summary: China pressed the US to cancel tariffs in talks with US Trade Representative Katherine Tai and Vice-Premier Liu He, a test of bilateral engagement. The virtual talks focused on implementing the US-China Economic and Trade Agreement and addressing US complaints about China's trade and subsidy practices. China clarified its position on its economic development model and industrial policies, while the US aimed to assess China's performance in implementing the Phase 1 deal. The outcome of the call will determine future engagement between the two countries.

site_title: Apple appeals verdict in App Store battle with Epic Games
summary: Apple has appealed a federal judge's verdict in its App Store battle with Epic Games, seeking to overturn the ruling that ordered the company to loosen control of its App Store payment options. US District Court Judge Yvonne Gonzalez-Rogers ruled that Epic failed to prove antitrust violations, while Apple is seeking to maintain its grip on the App Store. The companies had opted for a bench trial, with Epic planning to contest the verdict. The outcome is uncertain, with Apple chief executive Tim Sweeney stating "we will fight on."

site_title: After week of tensions, China's Xi vows 'reunification' with Taiwan
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to achieve "reunification" with Taiwan, following a week of tensions. Xi emphasized the Chinese people's opposition to separatism, without mentioning the use of force. Taiwan has pledged to defend its freedom and sovereignty, stating that only its people can decide its future. This move comes amid increased military and political pressure from Beijing. The statement suggests a continued push for Taiwan's reunification with China, raising concerns about the island's democratic government and autonomy.

site_title: Singapore cannot stay locked down, closed off indefinitely: PM Lee
summary: Singapore cannot continue to lock down indefinitely due to the manageable nature of Covid-19, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The government plans to simplify healthcare protocols, build up healthcare facilities, and implement vaccinated travel lanes to connect the country to the world. The goal is to "live with Covid-19" and balance public health with economic and social needs. The government aims to resume normal life, reopen borders, and revive the economy within 3-6 months.

site_title: Evergrande says six execs have returned funds from advance redemption of products
summary: Six Evergrande executives have returned funds from early redemptions of investment products, with the company imposing punishment but keeping details undisclosed. The executives made the redemptions between May 1 and September 7, totaling 12 products. Evergrande is in a liquidity crisis with over $300 billion in liabilities, amid concerns of an imminent default and ratings downgrades from S&P Global Ratings and Fitch Ratings. The company has not publicly addressed missing interest payments to bondholders.

site_title: China proposes adding cryptocurrency mining to 'negative list' of industries
summary: China has proposed adding cryptocurrency mining to its "negative list" of industries restricted to investment, despite reducing the number of sectors on the list overall. The move follows a crackdown on cryptocurrency trading and mining this year, with the country's central bank vowing to purge "illegal" activities. The draft 2021 list has been cut to 117, down from 123 in 2020, with industries not on the list open to investment with no approvals required.

site_title: McConnell says Republicans will not again aid Democrats in raising US debt limit
summary: Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that he will not aid Democrats in raising the US debt limit again, following a temporary lift approved by the Senate. The short-term fix, which will allow the US to avoid defaulting on its bills, is set to expire in December. McConnell cited concerns about future spending bills and their impact on Americans and China, as well as comments by Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, as reasons for his stance. A longer-term solution is needed to address the debt ceiling issue.

site_title: New Hong Kong carrier Greater Bay Airlines granted air operator's certificate
summary: Greater Bay Airlines, a Hong Kong startup, received an air operator's certificate, a key step towards launching commercial flights. The airline plans to start operations with three leased Boeing 737-800 planes and aims to have seven planes in service by 2022 and over 30 by 2026. It will compete with Cathay Pacific Airways and Hong Kong Airlines, with plans to operate to 104 destinations across the region. The airline's CEO, Algernon Yau, previously led Cathay Dragon before its closure. Commercial flights are expected to be subject to regulatory approval and market conditions.

site_title: Goldman Sachs settles case over alleged abuse of intern
summary: Goldman Sachs has settled a lawsuit with a former intern, Patrick Blumenthal, who alleged the company fostered a culture of hazing, including physical violence and embarrassing nicknames. The settlement came before a hearing on Goldman Sachs' request to dismiss the lawsuit. Blumenthal claimed he was pressured to consume alcohol and was punched by a supervisor during a happy hour event, resulting in bleeding to the brain. The company denied liability, arguing that Blumenthal's injuries occurred during an after-hours event and should be covered by the state workers compensation system.

site_title: US says to hold first in-person talks with Taliban since Afghan withdrawal
summary: The US and Taliban will hold their first in-person talks since the US withdrawal from Afghanistan, starting Saturday in Doha. The talks will focus on pressing the Taliban to respect Afghan rights, form an inclusive government, and allow humanitarian agencies access to areas of need. The meeting does not indicate recognition of Taliban rule, and the US will also prioritize letting US citizens and Afghan allies leave the country. The talks come after the US has largely cooperated with the Taliban on letting out US citizens, but acknowledges difficulties in evacuating most Afghan allies.

site_title: TSMC and Sony considering joint chip factory, Japan government to help
summary: Taiwan's TSMC and Japan's Sony Group are considering a joint chip factory in Japan, with the government offering to help fund the project. The factory, expected to produce semiconductors for automobiles and other products, is set to start operations by 2024. Japanese auto parts maker Denso is also involved, seeking stable chip supplies. The move aims to address Japan's chip shortage and supply chain stability concerns.

site_title: Facebook apologises for 2nd outage in a week, services back up
summary: Facebook experienced its second global outage in a week, impacting its social media platform, Instagram, Messenger, and Workplace, for approximately two hours. The company attributed the disruption to a faulty configuration change. The outage, which occurred on Friday, followed a nearly six-hour outage on Monday that affected 3.5 billion users. The disruptions have raised concerns about Facebook's reliability and prioritization of profit over content moderation. The company apologized and assured services were restored, with some users joking about the "3-day work week" on social media.

site_title: Singapore could reach 'new normal' in 3 to 6 months: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country could reach a 'new normal' in 3 to 6 months in its fight against Covid-19. He emphasized that progress is being made despite the ongoing pandemic, and a 'new normal' state could be achieved with continued efforts.

site_title: Bitcoin's 'incredible rally' spurs biggest weekly gain in months
summary: Bitcoin experienced its best weekly gain in months, rising about 10% over the past five sessions, and is on track for its best week since August. The cryptocurrency's year-to-date advance is now 87%. Analysts attribute the rally to factors such as a Bank of America report calling Bitcoin a "too big to ignore" asset class, rising inflation, and optimism over institutional investors returning to Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation. The market is also expecting a possible approval of one or more Bitcoin ETFs by the Securities and Exchange Commission this month.

site_title: Shiba Inu now 12th-biggest crypto after 367% rise in just a week
summary: Shiba Inu, a cryptocurrency started last year, has seen a 367% rise in value over the past week following a tweet from Elon Musk about his puppy. The SHIB token has become the 12th-largest cryptocurrency by market value, surpassing Litecoin and Avalanche. The surge is part of a broader crypto market boom, with Bitcoin and Ether also increasing in value. Shiba Inu was founded by an anonymous person, Ryoshi, and has evolved into a vibrant ecosystem.

site_title: Football: Staveley promises Newcastle overhaul, knocks back sportswashing
summary: British businesswoman Amanda Staveley has denied that a Saudi-backed takeover of Newcastle United was designed to "sportswash" Saudi Arabia's human rights record. Staveley's PCP Capital Partners group secured the club in a £305 million deal, promising to rebuild the team into a winning unit. Staveley plans to invest for the long term, with a focus on securing new players, great managers, and improving the academy and scouting network. She hopes to bring in former Newcastle legends Alan Shearer and Kevin Keegan to key roles, and ultimately aims to win the Premier League and trophies.

site_title: Football: Premier League clubs demand emergency meeting over Newcastle takeover
summary: Premier League clubs are calling for an emergency meeting over Newcastle United's takeover by a Saudi Arabia-led consortium, following the league's announcement of the sale. The 19 clubs are opposed to the deal, citing concerns over alleged broadcast piracy in Saudi Arabia and the potential damage to the league's brand. Human rights groups have condemned Saudi Arabia's efforts to "sportswash" its human rights record, with Amnesty International urging the Premier League to change its owners' and directors' test to address human rights issues.

site_title: Nissan unveils high-tech green factory for next-generation EVs
summary: Nissan has unveiled a high-tech, green factory in Japan to produce next-generation electric vehicles (EVs). The 130 billion yen (S$1.6 billion) investment will modernize factories in Japan and the US, featuring advanced equipment and efficiency-boosting technologies, such as VR training systems and automated parts production. The factory will also electrify equipment and source renewable energy, aiming to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 41% by 2030. Nissan plans to start production of its flagship Ariya EV at the Tochigi plant this fiscal year, as part of its "Intelligent Factory Initiative" to serve as a model for global plants.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup makes inroads in Indonesia
summary: A Singaporean fintech startup, Fin (SE) Asia, has partnered with Indonesia's largest Islamic organisation, Nahdlatul Ulama (NU), to provide electronic payment services in Indonesia, the country's largest economy. The partnership aims to expand digital banking services and push Indonesians towards a digital lifestyle. With 90 million members, NU is a significant opportunity for Fin (SE) Asia to penetrate the Indonesian market. The fintech industry is expected to grow rapidly, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, and Fin (SE) Asia plans to expand to other regions, including the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Fin (SE) Asia founder and executive chairman Abu Bakar Mohd Nor (right), with chief strategy officer Wong Ju Han; the company is eyeing expansion in Indonesia by partnering NU.

site_title: SEC investigating Archegos for potential market manipulation
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Archegos Capital Management, the hedge fund run by Bill Hwang, for potential market manipulation. The probe is examining whether Archegos concealed the size of its bets on public companies and bought multiple stakes in the same companies across several banks to avoid triggering public disclosure rules. Archegos' collapse in March triggered massive losses for lenders and internal investigations. The SEC is reviewing whether to revise rules exempting family offices like Hwang's from tougher oversight.

site_title: Europe: Stocks log best week in 2 months
summary: European stocks ended a volatile session lower on Friday but still marked their best week in two months. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 1% for the week, driven by relief over a temporary lifting of the US debt ceiling and easing fears of an energy crunch. Oil and auto stocks led gains, while tech stocks fell 1.4% due to rising bond yields. Analysts said the data showed a slowing jobs growth in the US, but the trend of an improving labor market remains intact.

site_title: When listening to a book is better than reading it
summary: The article argues that listening to audiobooks can be just as good, if not better, than reading the text. It cites examples of popular authors like Liane Moriarty, whose audiobooks are narrated by Caroline Lee, which elevate the stories and make them more engaging. The author suggests that audiobooks are not a shortcut or a lesser form of reading, but rather a unique way to experience stories. The article also highlights the benefits of audiobooks, such as the ability to convey emotion and create a sense of presence, and argues that they should be recognized as a valuable form of storytelling.

site_title: Robinhood sees crypto, order flow payment risks in filing update
summary: Robinhood Markets cited regulatory risks in its amended filing, including potential SEC scrutiny of cryptocurrency trading and payment for order flow arrangements. The firm's crypto trades generated 41% of its revenue in the second quarter, and payment for order flow accounted for a significant portion of its revenue. The company's regulatory landscape is subject to change, with the SEC reviewing these areas. This may impact Robinhood's business, particularly its shareholder stock sale, which is seeking to speed up approval.

site_title: US job growth slows sharply in September; unemployment rate falls to 4.8%
summary: US job growth slowed sharply in September, with 194,000 jobs added, below economists' expectations of 500,000. The unemployment rate fell to 4.8% from 5.2% in August. The modest gain in jobs may temper expectations for swift economic growth, as the labor market remains constrained by pandemic-related shortages. Covid-19 infections are decreasing, and schools have reopened, potentially enabling more people to rejoin the labor force, leading to cautious optimism that the labor squeeze could ease in the months ahead.

site_title: Oil rises 4% in week as energy crunch shows no signs of easing
summary: Oil prices rose 4% for the week as a global energy crunch continued to boost US prices to their highest in almost seven years. Despite growing demand, OPEC+ said it would gradually increase production, while the US government monitored markets but didn't announce immediate action to lower prices. Brent crude futures reached a 3-year high of $83.47 and US petrol futures closed at their highest since October 2014. Experts predict that the price run-up will continue due to tight supplies and a potential cold winter, with some forecasting a 450,000-barrel-per-day increase in crude oil demand.

site_title: VTL with 9 more countries: What's the Covid situation there?
summary:
Singapore has established Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) with nine countries, including South Korea, the US, Canada, the UK, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Denmark, and Belgium. 

Key Covid-19 situation in these countries: 
- South Korea has 64.5% of adults fully vaccinated, with new infections averaging around 2,000 daily and a goal to restore normal routines by November 9.
- The US has a vaccination rate of 55.4%, with new infections decreasing by 24%, hospitalizations by 20%, and deaths by 12% over the past two weeks.
- Canada has a vaccination rate of 71.6%, with new infections decreasing by 8% and deaths increasing by 9% over the same period.
- The UK has a vaccination rate of 66.1%, with new infections averaging around 35,000 daily and Covid-19 related deaths similar to those during a flu season.
- France has a vaccination rate of 66.3%, with new infections averaging around 5,000 daily and a recent improvement in the health situation.
- Italy has a vaccination rate of 68.6%, with new infections averaging below 3,000 daily and a recent surge in August.
- The Netherlands has a vaccination rate of 67.6%, with new infections averaging around 1,946 daily and a recent easing of restrictions.
- Denmark has a vaccination rate of over 96% of those aged 65 and above, with new daily infections capped below 500 and the spread under control.
- Belgium's Covid-19 situation is not detailed in the article.

site_title: Global tax deal seeks to end havens, criticised for 'no teeth'
summary: A group of 136 countries agreed on a minimum global tax rate of 15% for large companies, aiming to end the "race to the bottom" in tax rates. The deal, which includes exemptions and a 10-year transition period, is expected to collect around $150 billion in new revenues annually. However, developing countries criticized the deal for ignoring their interests, and NGOs, such as Oxfam, said it has "no teeth" due to complex exemptions. The agreement must now be endorsed by the G-20 and ratified by countries by 2023.

site_title: US will accept WHO-approved Covid-19 vaccines for international visitors
summary: The US will accept COVID-19 vaccines authorized by US regulators or the World Health Organization (WHO) for international visitors. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced that six vaccines meet the criteria for travel to the US, including those from the FDA and WHO. The decision aims to lift travel restrictions on air travelers from 33 countries, including China, India, and most of Europe, who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19. The new policy is set to take effect in early November 2021.

images.alt_text: The United States will accept the use by international visitors of Covid-19 vaccines authorised by US regulators or the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said late on Friday.

site_title: The new law on foreign interference - what's next for businesses?
summary: Singapore's Foreign Interference (Countermeasures) Bill (Fica) was passed after 10 hours of debate, despite some amendments. The law aims to counter foreign interference in domestic politics through hostile information campaigns and proxy use. Businesses must consider operational risk management and disclosure policies, akin to conflict of interest disclosures, to mitigate the risk of being used for foreign interference. While the government has clarified limits to its powers, further clarification and codification of assurances are needed, and the conversation about Fica's impact on fundamental freedoms will continue.

site_title: China's Xi discusses bilateral ties with Japan's Kishida
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping discussed bilateral ties with Japan's new Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, emphasizing the need to handle sensitive issues like Taiwan "appropriately." Xi also suggested strengthening dialogue and economic policy coordination, promoting regional cooperation. Japan's new government has signaled a more assertive stance on China's Taiwan posture, while reaffirming its close security ties with the US. Tensions over Taiwan, which China claims as its own territory, have been rising, with Taiwan asserting its independence.

site_title: Malaysia premier seeks 'family' unity as political tension rises
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob launched the "Malaysian Family" concept to unite the country amid rising political tensions. The concept aims for healing, development, and high income, and includes 10,000 members of the "Malaysian Family Squad" to help those affected by the pandemic. However, critics argue that the concept may not effectively cater to various political groups, potentially leading to internal discord and instability, particularly with the looming state election and national budget vote.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends lower after September jobs miss
summary: The S&P 500 ended lower on Friday after data showed weaker jobs growth than expected in September. Despite this, investors still expect the Federal Reserve to begin tapering asset purchases this year. The three main indices were mixed before losing ground, with Comcast and Charter Communications experiencing declines after being downgraded by Wells Fargo.

site_title: A new database could make it easier to successfully invest in art
summary: Josh Baer, author of the art industry newsletter Baer Faxt, has launched a searchable database of past auction lots, containing information on 10,000 past auctions, 5,700 sales with buyer data, and 6,100 underbidder entries. The database, costing $200-$500 per month, aims to provide human intel for professionals and serious collectors to use in making informed investment decisions. The database has been fact-checked by peer review and verified by dealers and advisers, but its coverage is limited to evening sales in New York and London's contemporary, post-war, Impressionist, and modern categories, with gaps in data from 2018-2019.

site_title: Samsung forecasts close to 30% jump in Q3 operating profit
summary: Samsung Electronics forecasts a 30% jump in Q3 operating profits to 15.8 trillion won, driven by a 9% year-on-year increase in sales to a record 73 trillion won. The company's smartphone business benefits from the South Korean won's weakness against the US dollar, offsetting disruptions in smartphone shipments. Analysts predict a decline in demand for dynamic random-access memory chips in the fourth quarter due to supply chain issues. The forecast is in line with analyst expectations, but Samsung's shares closed down 0.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Grab raises stake in e-wallet Ovo to 90%, buys out Tokopedia
summary: Grab Holdings is increasing its ownership of Indonesian mobile wallet provider Ovo to about 90% by acquiring stakes from Tokopedia and Lippo Group. The move aims to resolve competitive conflicts with rival Gojek and focus on boosting financial services in the region. Grab's acquisition of Ovo's parent, Bumi Cakrawala Perkasa, has increased its holding from 39% to 90%.

site_title: Four Navis Living Group managing partners join Huttons Asia
summary: Four managing partners of Navis Living Group, a network of real estate agents, have joined Huttons Asia's team. The four co-founders, Jay Ong, Stuart Chng, Gary Chua, and Jackie Mang, will also help transition the Navis team, with some brokers expected to follow. As part of the move, Navis will become an associate of Huttons. The partnership aims to expand Huttons' agency numbers to 8,000 brokers, with the combined team expected to grow and develop the most efficient agency platform.

site_title: Short-term increase in US debt ceiling narrowly passes Senate
summary: The US Senate approved a short-term debt-ceiling increase, narrowly passing 50-48, to avoid a payment default. The $480 billion increase will run out around Dec 3. A deal between Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell allows for a vote in the House, which is expected to pass the measure. The move averts an immediate crisis but sets up a collision course for fiscal and policy battles in December, including a potential government shutdown and a push for Biden's economic package.

images.alt_text: Various fiscal and policy battles are expected to play out simultaneously as funding for US government operations also expires on Dec 3, risking a government shutdown unless lawmakers can complete agency budgets for this fiscal year.
Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (above) struck the deal with Minority Leader Mitch McConnell.

site_title: Women in finance are turning to online poker to boost their careers
summary: Women in finance are turning to online poker to boost their careers through a dozen-course programme called Poker Power. Created by trader Jenny Just, the programme teaches risk-taking and negotiation techniques using the card game, with users adapting skills to workplace scenarios. Over 4,000 women have signed up from 20 countries, with many corporate clients offering the programme to their employees. While it may not address the gender pay gap, Poker Power provides a tangible solution for career development and has been praised for its effectiveness in improving negotiation skills and confidence.

site_title: South Korea 'seriously' looking to join Trans-Pacific pact following China bid, says trade minister
summary: South Korea is "seriously and actively considering" joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a free-trade pact among 11 Pacific Rim countries. This move comes after China and Taiwan submitted formal requests to join the pact, following South Korea's interest. The CPTPP aims to promote economic cooperation and reduce trade barriers among its member countries. The decision to join the pact would mark South Korea's entry into the Asia-Pacific free trade deal.

images.alt_text: South Korea became the latest nation to express interest in joining an Asia-Pacific free trade deal, with the country's trade minister saying the government is "seriously and actively considering" the issue.

site_title: MPA to accredit Singapore-flagged ships in 4 areas
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) will launch the Singapore Registry of Ships (SRS) Notation on November 1, recognizing ship owners and operators that drive digital transformation, cybersecurity, seafarer well-being, and sustainable shipping. The notation will have four categories: smart, cyber, welfare, and green, with green vessels eligible for lower registration fees and rebates from 2022 onwards. This is the first accreditation system by a ship registry, with over 4,000 ships already registered under the SRS.

site_title: UK September house prices post largest monthly increase since 2007
summary: UK house prices rose 1.7% in September to £267,587, the largest monthly increase since 2007, according to Halifax. This pushed the annual growth rate to 7.4%. Despite a scaled-back stamp-duty holiday, the housing market is expected to persist due to factors like low borrowing costs, a robust jobs market, and demand for space. However, some industry measures suggest buyer activity may soften due to rising pressures on the cost of living and impending tax increases.

site_title: China chip firm Horizon Robotics eyes moving US IPO to Hong Kong
summary: China-based AI chip startup Horizon Robotics is considering moving its US IPO to Hong Kong due to increased scrutiny from Beijing. The company, backed by Intel, is weighing a Hong Kong listing that could raise up to $1 billion. The move comes as Beijing proposes tightening rules for firms listing overseas and requires a cybersecurity review for firms with data on over 1 million users. Horizon Robotics is not the only company to change its fundraising plans, with others such as Pony.ai and Ximalaya moving their listings to Hong Kong.

site_title: The problem with corporate 'values'
summary: Corporate values are often touted as a positive force, but in reality, they frequently conflict with a company's bottom line. While 80% of large companies have official value statements, these statements often don't align with the company's actions. The shareholder value model prioritizes profits over people, leading to a power imbalance that's driving individual and collective action. To truly make a positive impact, companies must prioritize values and make governance and policy changes, rather than simply paying lip service to them. Procedural changes, such as distributing voting power and expanding success definitions, can help achieve this.

site_title: China fines Meituan 3.44 billion yuan in end to antitrust probe
summary: China fined Meituan 3.44 billion yuan (S$722.8 million) for violating anti-monopoly regulations, ending a months-long probe. The fine, 3% of its 2020 domestic revenue, also requires the company to return 1.29 billion yuan of deposits from exclusivity arrangements. Meituan must improve its commissions mechanism, protect restaurant partners, and step up protections for delivery riders. The fine is seen as a lenient outcome, given Beijing's scrutiny of the gig economy and millions of blue-collar workers powering it.

site_title: Pole dancing empowers MindFi's Anita Sadasivan
summary: Anita Sadasivan, 33, chief wellbeing officer of MindFi, credits pole dancing with empowering her physically and mentally. She began pole dancing at 5 and now teaches it every Sunday, inspiring her students to become stronger and more confident. Sadasivan's routine includes contortion classes, HIIT workouts, and runs to maintain physical fitness, as well as meditation and mindfulness practices to stay focused and grounded. She believes pole dancing makes her feel strong, powerful, and feminine, and that with dedication and the right support, anyone can achieve their goals.

site_title: US job growth slows sharply in September; jobless rate falls to 4.8%
summary: US employment increased by 194,000 jobs in September, lower than expected, with the unemployment rate falling to 4.8% from 5.2% in August. The modest gain may temper expectations for swift economic growth, as the labor market remains constrained by worker and raw material shortages. Covid-19 infections are decreasing, and economists expect hiring to pick up as people resume job searches. The Federal Reserve may start tapering its bond buying program in November, depending on the employment report.

site_title: David Beckham at 46 - still bending it like before
summary: David Beckham, 46, remains active in the sports world as a co-owner of Inter Miami football club and global ambassador for life insurer AIA. He recently attended a taiji class, a centuries-old Chinese martial art, as part of AIA's virtual event in Singapore. Beckham attributes his fitness to a healthy diet and sufficient sleep, as well as functional training and running. He credits his most memorable football moment to Manchester United's treble-winning season in 1999. When in Singapore, Beckham's must-have dish is chilli crab, a favorite he has developed over his frequent visits to the city.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher despite September jobs disappointment
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Friday despite disappointing September jobs data, with the Dow Jones rising 2.63 points, the S&P 500 gaining 6.75 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 40.70 points. Energy stocks led the gains, while government payrolls declined more than expected. The US jobs data contradicts expectations of a stronger labor market, raising concerns about inflation and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon Tahir enters into nearly S$260m purchase of strata units in freehold Robinson Road building
summary: Indonesian tycoon Tahir is purchasing nearly S$260 million worth of strata units in the freehold Robinson Road building, Crown At Robinson, for around 70,700 sq ft of strata space. The price reflects S$3,650 per square foot on the strata space, comprising 65 strata office units and 8 F&B/shop units. The buyer is Tahir, the founder of the Mayapada Group, an Indonesia-based conglomerate with businesses in financial services, healthcare, and property.

site_title: Singapore-based Shopee to launch online sales in Spain
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce platform Shopee plans to launch online sales in Spain, offering free shipping. The move is part of Sea's global expansion, following launches in Poland and India. Shopee has ramped up activities in Latin America and has a localized website in Spain. This marks another step in Sea's e-commerce operation, which has a market capitalization of $179 billion.

site_title: GIC's past, present and future are defined by a balancing act
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has navigated the COVID-19 pandemic by managing its reserves, with a commemorative book marking its 2035 milestone. GIC's past, present, and future are defined by a balancing act between investing and preserving funds. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. The Singapore government is also under pressure to address China's slowing GDP growth, while policymakers consider a potential stimulus package.

images.alt_text: The book details the lesser known details of the history behind GIC, including how the fund covertly bought gold with US-led embargo on gold purchases in place at the time. It was also refreshed from the 2016 e-book version with a fresh epilogue that discusses both the GFC and the Covid-19 response.

site_title: BOE rate hike would hit a fifth of existing UK mortgages
summary: The Bank of England's interest-rate increase could hurt a fifth of existing UK mortgages, affecting over 21% of outstanding residential mortgages with variable interest rates. A potential 12.5-basis-point rate rise in December could increase £250 per year on a £200,000 loan, exacerbating inflation, energy costs, and a tax increase. Low-income renters are expected to bear the brunt of the impact, constraining affordability for those looking to buy. Experts advise switching to fixed-rate loans, but only if not planning to move home soon or have a small mortgage.

site_title: Dapper, Chainalysis partner to better monitor platform activity
summary: Dapper Labs, the company behind NBA Top Shot, is partnering with Chainalysis to track transactions and customer activity on its platform, aiming to prevent money laundering and manipulation. The partnership will utilize Chainalysis' know-your-transaction (KYT) tools to flag risky and illicit activity in real-time. This move comes as scrutiny grows over suspicious activities on online NFT platforms, following an insider-trading scandal on OpenSea. The partnership is also seen as a step to enhance transparency and trust in Dapper Labs' digital collectibles.

images.alt_text: Just as scrutiny has started to grow over suspicious activities on online non-fungible token (NFT) platforms, Dapper Labs, the company behind the highly popular NBA Top Shot digital trading cards, said it is partnering with crypto-forensics firm Chainalysis to track transactions and customer activity.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: Fortress Minerals reported a 42% decline in net profit to US$3.3 million for its second quarter, with revenue at US$10 million. The company's first half revenue rose 35.8% to US$27.3 million. Ayondo submitted an appeal to the Singapore Exchange after its shares were suspended since February 2019. Raffles Education's auditors highlighted material uncertainty over the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant liabilities exceeding assets by S$196.4 million.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Fortress Minerals reported a 42% decline in net profit to US$3.3 million in its second quarter, with revenue at US$10 million, down from US$13 million last year. The company attributed the decline to lower realised selling prices. Ayondo shares have been suspended since 2019, and the company has submitted an appeal to the Singapore Exchange regarding delisting. Raffles Education's auditors highlighted material uncertainty over the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant net current liabilities.

site_title: China's developers priced for meltdown as contagion risk spreads
summary: China's property developers face a potential meltdown as sales plummet in September, putting pressure on the government to intervene. A missed bond payment by Chinese developer Fantasia Holdings Group and rating downgrades by global risk assessors fueled investor anxiety. Chinese junk dollar bonds are poised for their biggest sell-off in at least eight years, with yields near a decade high. Developer shares have tumbled, and China Evergrande Group's silence on a reported stake sale has left its shares suspended. The government's inaction is re-igniting concerns about the health of China's property sector.

site_title: More than 100 killed, wounded in mosque blast in northeastern Afghanistan
summary: A suicide bomb exploded at a mosque in Afghanistan's northeastern Kunduz province, killing or wounding over 100 people, mostly from the minority Shi'ite Muslim community. No group claimed responsibility, but the attack follows recent blasts at mosques in Kabul, some of which have been attributed to the Islamic State. The Taliban, which took over the country in August, has carried out operations against Islamic State cells in Kabul, highlighting security challenges for the group.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.61 points to 1,563.90. The market saw 4.998 billion lots worth RM3.343 billion traded, with 610 gainers outnumbering 452 losers.

site_title: Evergrande creditors fear imminent default as concerns shake sector
summary: China Evergrande Group, a cash-strapped property developer, is facing imminent default on its US$131 million in offshore dollar bonds, with creditors expressing concerns over lack of transparency. Evergrande missed payments on dollar bonds due on September 23 and 29, and offshore bondholders are demanding more information on the company's plan to divest businesses and use proceeds to settle debts. The situation has triggered contagion risks in the Chinese economy, with other debt-laden property firms experiencing rating downgrades and share price slumps.

site_title: China fines Meituan US$530m in end to antitrust probe
summary: China fined Meituan US$533 million for violating anti-monopoly regulations, ending a months-long probe. The fine, equivalent to 3% of Meituan's 2020 domestic revenue, was imposed by the State Administration for Market Regulation. The company must also return 1.29 billion yuan in deposits from exclusivity arrangements.

site_title: Growing and protecting wealth are two sides of the same coin
summary: Singaporeans are placing greater emphasis on investing in long-term financial and healthcare needs due to the Covid-19 crisis, with retirement policies growing 34% in the first half of 2021. However, many report dissatisfaction with current retirement savings and regret not planning early enough. Securing investments is crucial to protecting wealth and giving individuals the freedom to think differently about their future. A holistic financial plan considers growing wealth, protecting it, and includes home planning, insurance, and retirement. Digital wealth adviser tools and diversification can help navigate market volatility, and early conversations about financial planning are essential.

site_title: US commercial mortgage backed securities face crunch as US$40b of mall debt comes due
summary: US$40 billion of shopping mall mortgages, bundled into commercial mortgage backed securities (CMBS), are approaching maturity over the next three years, with much of it being hard to refinance, particularly weaker properties. Investors are concerned about the sector's prospects, with appraisals showing property valuations decreasing and capitalisation rates rising. Weaker malls, known as Class B and Class C, struggle to refinance, while higher-quality malls can. This is partly due to the pandemic's impact on consumer habits, with consumers increasingly buying online and malls struggling to attract foot traffic.

site_title: Why many companies are choosing not to be listed
summary: Companies are increasingly choosing not to go public, driven by factors such as the allure of private equity, heightened regulation, and the volatility of public markets. In 2021, a record number of companies went private, worth over $800 billion, with aggressive buying by private equity groups. Companies are opting for private listings due to the ease of accessing funds through loans and bonds, reduced regulatory scrutiny, and the potential for illogical market valuations influenced by amateur traders and social media.

images.alt_text: With amateur traders easily able to buy and sell shares through platforms like eToro and Robinhood, company valuations are at the mercy of their whims, as in the case of GameStop shares going through the roof earlier this year thanks to the Reddit group WallStreet Bets.

site_title: Consumer goods companies walk a tightrope as inflation surges
summary: Consumer goods companies, including Pepsi and Levi Strauss, have offset inflation by raising prices, but analysts predict tighter times ahead due to rising costs and supply chain disruptions. Freight and raw material costs have surged, squeezing profit margins. Companies must balance price increases with demand concerns, with some industries facing pressure until mid-2022. Analysts expect margin pressure to be a dominant theme for the rest of the earnings season, with PepsiCo facing "stunning" inflationary pressures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close 0.6% higher as tech and financial stocks gain
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by gains in tech and financial stocks, amid easing tensions between China and the US. The Hang Seng index reached 24,837.85. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, rising 0.67% and 0.79% respectively. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street.

site_title: SingPost to raise stake in Australian logistics service company
summary: SingPost is increasing its stake in Australian logistics service company Freight Management Holdings (FMH) from 28% to 51%, exercising a call option to acquire an additional 13% stake. The consideration for this early exercise is estimated at A$84.5 million. The revised agreement also brings forward the dates for SingPost to acquire the remaining shares. This move is expected to further solidify SingPost's position as a key logistics player in Australia, with FMH's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) increasing to A$29.4 million.

site_title: Digital banks step up competition in S-E Asia but near-term rating impact modest, says report
summary: Fitch Ratings reports that the proliferation of digital banks in South-east Asia will intensify competition in the banking sector, but near-term rating impact is modest for existing rated banks. Digital banks are expected to rapidly grow customer bases, but achieving sustained profitability is uncertain, especially for larger incumbents. Effective execution and targeting under-served segments are key to profitability. Local regulation, including increased scrutiny and levelling of prudential requirements, may pose challenges for digital banks and incumbents.

images.alt_text: The headquarters of digital bank Bank Jago in Central Jakarta.

site_title: Singapore stocks gain on positive global sentiment
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, closing at 3,112.81, driven by positive global sentiment, particularly in the US, where the S&P 500 index gained 0.8% and the Nasdaq rose 1%. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top gainer, while Genting Singapore was the biggest loser. Asian markets also saw gains, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.6% and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 up 1.3%.

site_title: India selling Air India to Tata conglomerate
summary: The Indian government has agreed to sell Air India to the Tata conglomerate for 180 billion rupees (S$3.25 billion). Talace Pvt, a subsidiary of Tata, won the bidding for the airline. The transaction is expected to close by the end of December 2021. Air India, which was founded in 1932, has struggled with debt and losses in recent years. This sale is the latest attempt by the Indian government to privatize state assets, following previous failed attempts to sell the airline.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has announced plans to launch a travel lane with South Korea on November 15, its third Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) after Germany and Brunei. The country also aims to establish a VTL with the US by year-end. The unemployment rate in Singapore dipped to 2.7% in August, following a brief uptick in July. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will introduce an accreditation system for shipowners and operators that drive digital transformation and sustainable shipping. Prime Minister Lee will address the nation on the Covid-19 situation on Saturday.

site_title: IMF board to debate Georgieva's future, with some backing from Europe
summary: The International Monetary Fund's executive board is set to debate Kristalina Georgieva's future as head of the institution amid allegations of her role in a World Bank data-rigging scandal. Georgieva has denied the claims, while some European governments, including France, are expected to back her. The US Treasury has pushed for a thorough review, but has refrained from public judgment. The IMF's largest shareholder governments have not publicly stated their positions, with some former staff arguing that Georgieva should step down to restore credibility.

site_title: PM Lee to address nation on Covid-19 situation at noon on Saturday
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will address the nation on Saturday at noon, discussing the country's Covid-19 situation and the path to a new normal. The address will be broadcast live on Facebook and Mediacorp channels. On Friday, Singapore reported 3,590 new daily Covid-19 infections, bringing the total case count to 120,454, with six more deaths reported. The Ministry of Health (MOH) said the doubling time of community infections has slowed, but the large daily numbers have strained the healthcare system.

site_title: China calls for huge boost in coal output to fight power crunch
summary: China has ordered over 70 mines in Inner Mongolia to increase coal production by nearly 100 million tonnes to combat the country's worst power crunch and coal shortages in years. The move aims to alleviate the shortage and ensure sufficient winter energy supplies. The proposed increase would account for nearly 3% of China's total thermal coal consumption, with the production boost expected to take up to two to three months to materialize. However, experts warn that the shortage may persist, and further measures may be needed to address the issue.

site_title: Singapore-South Korea vaccinated travel lane starts on Nov 15
summary: Singapore and South Korea will launch a two-way Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) on November 15, allowing fully vaccinated travelers to enter each country without quarantine. This is Singapore's third VTL, following schemes with Germany and Brunei. The US VTL is also planned, with efforts underway, and Singapore aims to have it operational by the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore stocks end slightly higher on Friday; STI up 0.4 per cent
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, closing at 3,112.81, driven by positive global sentiment and gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index beat losers 315 to 153, with Jardine Cycle & Carriage being the top gainer. The US government's agreement to temporarily lift the debt ceiling until December also contributed to the market's positivity. Asian markets were mostly up, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.6% and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 up 1.3%.

site_title: Japan's service sector sentiment rebounds in September
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose 7.4 points to 42.1 in September, rebounding from a 34.7 reading in August, as new Covid-19 cases decreased nationwide. This improvement is attributed to the decline in new cases.

site_title: China will keep pushing interest rate reform: PBOC official
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, will continue to reform its benchmark loan rate and make deposit rates more market-based. Deputy Governor Liu Guoqiang announced plans to enhance the quality of banks' quotes used to derive the loan prime rate, making it competitive for banks to become qualified. Historical quotes will be published to increase transparency and promote a more efficient market. The reforms aim to improve the stability and effectiveness of China's monetary policy.

site_title: Thai diners whet their appetites at flood cafe
summary: A Thai restaurant in Nonthaburi, Bangkok, is capitalizing on the city's flooding by offering customers a unique dining experience where they eat while sitting on stools surrounded by murky brown floodwater. The restaurant, Chaopraya Antique Cafe, has seen a surge in popularity since the flooding began, with customers enjoying the scenic view of boats and rice barges on the Chao Phraya River. Owner Titiporn Jutimanon has turned the crisis into an opportunity, saying the experience has proved popular with young people and families.

site_title: Thai Tourism recovery needs at least 3 years, Stanchart says
summary: Thai tourism is expected to take at least three years to recover to pre-pandemic levels, according to a Standard Chartered Bank report. The sector accounts for 15% of Thailand's GDP and its slow recovery will keep economic growth weak in 2022-23. Despite easing restrictions on vaccinated travelers starting next month, the Thai economy will struggle to recover without an improvement in tourism. A low base should provide support in the short term, but overall growth is expected to remain weak over the next two years.

site_title: Japan's new premier appeals to middle class ahead of key vote
summary: Japan's new Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has outlined plans to expand the middle class ahead of the October 31 national election, aiming to bolster support for his government. Kishida pledged bold spending to recover from the pandemic, introducing a "new capitalism" that spreads economic growth benefits more widely. His Cabinet faces a tepid public response, with a poll indicating the lowest support level for an incoming premier since 2008, and opposition parties plan to cooperate in some constituencies to reduce the ruling coalition's majority.

site_title: Tencent shares have 'priced in' gaming crackdown, Jefferies says
summary: Tencent shares have already incorporated the impact of China's gaming crackdown, according to Jefferies, with a 16% revenue growth forecast in the third quarter. The company's recent 6.5% surge in shares, following a five-day selloff, is attributed to the launch of League of Legends Mobile and potential unlocking of gaming patents. Analysts believe concerns over minors' gaming hours and ads are "priced in," with rising ad demand from the Winter Olympics potentially offsetting lost revenue. Jefferies maintains its buy rating on Tencent shares.

site_title: Journalists Maria Ressa and Dmitry Muratov win Nobel Peace Prize
summary: Journalists Maria Ressa of the Philippines and Dmitry Muratov of Russia have been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for their fight for freedom of expression in their countries. The Norwegian Nobel Committee honored them for safeguarding democracy and lasting peace through their work as investigative journalists. Ressa co-founded Rappler, which has focused on critical attention on the Duterte regime's anti-drug campaign, while Muratov has defended freedom of speech in Russia under challenging conditions. The committee emphasized that freedom of expression is crucial for promoting fraternity between nations and a better world order.

site_title: China: Stocks open up on return from break
summary: Mainland Chinese markets opened higher on Friday, with the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 1.15% to 3,609.09, and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 1.13% to 2,422.15. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rallied 1.47% to 25,064.80. The gains followed a global rally as traders returned from a week-long break.

site_title: China developers' sales plunge as Evergrande contagion emerges
summary: China's top 100 real estate developers saw a 36% plunge in combined contracted sales in September from the previous year, with over 90 developers experiencing a decline. More than 60% of them recorded a drop of over 30%. The slowdown in the residential market, fueled by the government's efforts to cool the property market, has raised concerns of a debt contagion. Major developers like Evergrande Group are struggling, with Fantasia Holdings Group defaulting on a dollar bond, and the government has taken measures to limit the fallout, asking banks to cooperate with governments to maintain a healthy real estate market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end the day lower
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Friday, closing 3.16 points, or 0.11%, at 2,956.30, following a third straight week of declines. Tech heavyweights, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, drove the decline, with chip giants falling 0.14% and 1.78% respectively. The Kospi also fell 2.08% on a weekly basis. The declines come ahead of US jobs data later in the day and after Chinese markets returned from holiday.

site_title: Australia: Iron ore miners power shares to end higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to a five-week high, driven by iron ore miners and a strong finish on Wall Street. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,320.1 points, its highest close since Sept 30. Miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto jumped 3% and 4%, respectively, as iron ore prices rose to a one-month high. The gains were partly due to easing of lockdown restrictions in Sydney and optimism ahead of US interest rate changes.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady ahead of US jobs data
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the open on Friday, awaiting key US jobs data. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.3% to 7,098.49 points, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices remained flat and rose 0.2% respectively. The data release is expected to influence the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy, which is set to announce when it will begin withdrawing financial support measures.

site_title: Bonds, shares by Chinese property firms slump as Evergrande angst spreads
summary: Chinese property firms' bonds and shares slumped on Friday as Evergrande Group's debt problems worsened, sparking concerns of contagion risks to the property sector. Evergrande, facing a US$300 billion debt crisis, missed coupon payments and faces three more payments next week. The uncertainty led to rating downgrades, hitting onshore bonds issued by firms like Kaisa Group and Central China Real Estate. Regulators' silence on the issue has fueled worries, with some analysts predicting a possible collapse of one of China's biggest borrowers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1.34% to 28,048.94, and the Topix index firming 1.15% to 1,961.85. Investors continued buying back after recent declines and rallies on Wall Street. The gains were attributed to bargain-hunting, as investors sought to capitalize on undervalued stocks.

site_title: Deals of the week: Temasek bets on cybersecurity; ESOP startup bags US$15m
summary: Temasek invested US$550 million in Orca Security, a cloud security company, in a Series C round. Meanwhile, a US$15 million investment was secured by an ESOP startup. Other notable deals include GoTo shares rebounding after a US$2.2 billion sell-off and OpenAI planning to release a web browser. Chinese AI startup Manus accelerated its move to Singapore amid the AI race.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB downgrades First Resources to 'neutral'; proposes locking in profit
summary: RHB Securities has downgraded its call on palm oil producer First Resources to "neutral" with a higher target price of S$1.70, citing that the company's earnings prospects are expected to improve significantly in the second half of 2021. The brokerage believes First Resources is now fairly valued, trading at 17 times its 2021 P/E ratio. RHB forecasts a 10-12% earnings jump in the second half and a 5-7% FFB growth for FY2021-2023.

site_title: Old is gold, as classic cars steer towards market value of US$35 billion
summary: Classic cars are gaining value, with the global market expected to reach $35.5 billion by 2023, according to Statista. The Knight Frank Luxury Investment Index shows a 193% rise in value over the last decade. However, importing a classic car to Singapore can be costly, with taxes and duties making it difficult to break even. To find a profitable deal, buyers need to know the market well and find a car that is now unloved but will someday become a celebrated model. Experts recommend looking for cars built in small numbers from pedigreed brands with technological breakthroughs.

site_title: Shanghai exchange pauses Fantasia Group bond trade after fluctuations: statement
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange paused trade in Fantasia Group China's onshore bonds after abnormal fluctuations, with the company's December 2021 and November 2022 bonds falling over 20% before the halt.

site_title: Singapore unemployment rate dips to 2.7% in August after brief uptick in July: MOM
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate decreased to 2.7% in August, down from 2.8% in July, after a brief uptick. The rate for resident unemployment fell to 3.6% and for citizen unemployment to 3.8%. The temporary easing of manpower demand during Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) from July 22 to August 18 is cited as the reason for the decline. Despite the slight increase in July, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng believes the unemployment situation is showing a gradual recovery, with uneven growth across sectors.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Friday; STI up 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.02% to 3,101.69. Gainers beat losers 101 to 28, with Sinjia Land and AGV Group among the top performers. In contrast, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust was the top decliner. Globally, stocks rallied on Thursday, driven by relief over a US debt default agreement, while Asian markets followed suit with Tokyo stocks opening higher.

site_title: US special forces quietly training Taiwanese: official
summary: US special operations forces have been secretly training Taiwanese troops for less than a year, despite risking China's ire. The training, which began at least a year ago, involves around 20 special operations and conventional forces. The US supports Taiwan's military based on its defense needs and urges Beijing to honor its commitment to peaceful cross-Strait differences. Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang expressed gratitude for international support in defending national sovereignty and maintaining regional peace. The move comes amid China's rising threats against Taiwan, with Chinese forces conducting record-breaking air incursions and warning of a potential full-scale invasion in four years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.54 points, or 0.03%, to 1,560.75. Trading volume reached 270.77 million lots worth RM158.82 million. The market saw 251 gainers and 174 losers.

site_title: China's Sept services activity returns to growth: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity returned to growth in September, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI rising to 53.4 from 46.7 in August. The sector's recovery was driven by a receding major Covid-19 outbreak in Jiangsu province. However, analysts warn that sporadic outbreaks could impact the economy, particularly consumption, and call for the government to improve epidemic prevention and control. The services sector's growth was accompanied by expansion in new business, prices charged, and employment, but new export business shrank due to the pandemic.

site_title: Japan household spending falls as Covid-19 curbs sap economic recovery
summary: Japan's household spending fell 3.0% year-on-year in August, more sharply than expected, due to state of emergency curbs and pandemic-related restrictions. This decline followed a 0.7% increase in July and marked the fourth straight month of decline. Analysts predict a rebound in consumption in September as infections wane and vaccination rates increase, but supply chain issues and a decline in car sales may hinder the economy's recovery. The economy faces fresh headwinds from supply constraints, including a shortage of semiconductor chips.

site_title: Singapore, US ink deal to implement new Partnership for Growth and Innovation
summary: Singapore and the US have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to implement the US-Singapore Partnership for Growth and Innovation, strengthening trade and investment collaboration between the two countries. The partnership, launched in 2016, will focus on four pillar areas: digital economy, energy and environmental technologies, advanced manufacturing, and healthcare. The agreement aims to promote commercial partnerships and exchanges, and deliver commercially meaningful outcomes on priority topics such as e-commerce and clean energy. The partnership is seen as a significant step towards deepening economic integration between the US and South-east Asia.

site_title: Australia: Miners drive shares to week high
summary: Australian shares rose to a one-week high, driven by strong commodity prices and gains from heavyweight miners, with the ASX 200 index up 0.5% at 7,294.8. Copper prices surged, and miners including Chalice Mining, IGO, BHP Group, and Rio Tinto jumped 1.7% to 1-1/2-week highs. The market also saw gains from technology stocks and energy companies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Aspen, Heeton, Lian Beng, KSH
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings faced a defense and counterclaim from Penang Development Corporation, claiming RM1.8 million in relation to infrastructure construction work. The group countered for damages of RM161.6 million. Heeton Holdings, Lian Beng Group, and KSH Holdings proposed disposing of two Australian properties for A$18.2 million, ending flat before the news. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: 6.1-magnitude quake shakes Tokyo, more than 20 injuries reported
summary: A 6.1-magnitude earthquake struck Tokyo and surrounding areas on Thursday evening, injuring over 20 people and causing widespread disruptions. The epicenter was located in Chiba prefecture, east of Tokyo, with no tsunami risk reported. Several hundred homes were left without power, and emergency services were activated. Newly elected Prime Minister Fumio Kishida urged residents to take action to save lives. Japan, situated on the Pacific "Ring of Fire," experiences regular seismic activity, but the quake was relatively strong compared to recent Tokyo quakes.

site_title: Broker's take: ARA Logos likely has growth levers in S'pore, Australia; merger with ESR-Reit possible
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust is expected to see growth from strong leasing enquiries in its Singapore and Australia portfolios. Analysts at UOB Kay Hian have maintained a "buy" call on the stock, citing a 6% distribution yield for 2022 and potential for acquisitions in Singapore and China. However, the trust may also be a takeover target for ESR-Reit, which owns 67% of the manager of ARA Logos and has acquired ARA Asset Management for $5.2 billion, giving it an indirect stake in the trust.

site_title: Twitch struggles with hackers and hate raid bots
summary: Twitch, a popular live video streaming platform, suffered a data breach when hackers exploited a server configuration error, exposing confidential data, including top streamers' earnings. The breach includes Twitch source code, payout records, and a digital game distribution service. Personal user data was not exposed, but the hack raises concerns about the platform's ability to stop "hate raids" by software bots targeting marginalized streamers. Twitch has reset access keys to all accounts as a precaution and is investigating the incident.

site_title: What US needs to do to counter China's sleepwalking syndrome
summary: The US needs to counter China's growing military power and nationalist sentiment, likened to the pre-World War I era, where complacency and inadequate diplomacy led to unintended escalation. China's "China Dream" and President Xi Jinping's assertive policies pose a threat to global stability, similar to Germany's aggressive pursuit of power in 1914. A successful US strategy requires preserving democratic institutions, investing in research and development, and maintaining alliances, while avoiding ideological demonization and Cold War analogies. The US must also be cautious of inadvertent escalation and maintain its technological advantage, openness to the world, and engagement with China on transnational issues.

site_title: Sydney readies to exit lockdown amid concerns over faster reopening plans
summary: Sydney, Australia, is set to exit its lockdown after over 100 days, with restrictions easing on Monday as the state reaches a 70% vaccination rate. However, the Australian Medical Association warns that a too-fast reopening could put pressure on health systems and risk lives. State Premier Dominic Perrottet defends the move, citing a steady fall in infections and the economic impact of the pandemic. Neighboring Victoria logged a record 1,838 new cases, while the country's overall Covid-19 numbers remain lower than many comparable countries.

site_title: Google to stop pairing ads with climate change misinformation
summary: Google announced it will stop pairing ads with climate change misinformation, prohibiting ads that contradict the scientific consensus on climate change. This policy change affects Google advertisers, publishers, and YouTube creators. Misinformation about climate change, such as referring to it as a hoax or denying its existence, will no longer be monetized. The move aims to reduce the spread of false information and promote accurate climate change information.

site_title: Elon Musk says Tesla moving headquarters to Texas
summary: Elon Musk announced that Tesla is moving its headquarters from Silicon Valley to Austin, Texas, during the company's annual shareholders meeting. Musk expressed excitement about the move, stating that Tesla will continue to expand its activities in California. The decision comes after Tesla's expansion into India and plans for robotaxi services in California and Arizona.

site_title: US Senate advances Bill to lift debt ceiling; final passage awaited
summary: The US Senate has advanced a bill to raise the federal borrowing ceiling, avoiding possible catastrophic debt defaults later this month. The bill, which would raise the ceiling by $480 billion, advanced with 11 Republicans joining all 50 Democrats in support. A final vote is pending. The move relieves debt ceiling pressures but sets up a high-stakes, partisan battle over the rest of the year, with Democrats seeking to pass two major spending bills and the Biden administration facing a government funding deadline.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q3 profit likely highest in 3 years on rising chip prices
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a likely 28% increase in third-quarter operating profit to its highest in three years, driven by rising memory chip prices and brisk sales of new foldable smartphones. The estimated profit is 15.8 trillion won, with revenue likely rising 9% to a record 73 trillion won. Analysts attribute the surge to a 79% increase in chip division operating profit, primarily due to rising memory chip prices and shipments.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics on Friday said third-quarter operating profit likely rose 28 per cent to its highest in three years, helped by rising memory chip prices and brisk sales of its new foldable smartphones.
